I've always heard that [i]Far Cry 3[/i] is the best in the series, but coming off of recently completing that game, I enjoyed [i]Far Cry 4[/i] a bit more. Additionally, I've decided that a good Far Cry game feels like a psychedelic Bond Film with dope weapons and insane villains. Jason from the previous title is probably a more compelling main character, but the stories here are nothing special. Far Cry is clearly about the gameplay and giving you an open world with a lot to explore and combat. 

I enjoyed the major improvements to the UI, which made the crafting system much easier to use. I also really enjoyed the environment; what a beautiful setting, and impressive world. I found myself getting tons of EXP from small tasks such as taking down propaganda posters, destroying masks, and discovering locations. Honestly I had a really good time with this game - it surpassed my expectations and was the quickest I've beaten a game in a long time.

Far Cry 4 is an exhilarating addition to the beloved Far Cry series, and I had an absolute blast playing it. Set amidst the stunning backdrop of the Himalayan mountains, the game delivers a gripping narrative, intense action, and a vast open world ripe for exploration.

As a fan of the Far Cry series, I was immediately drawn into the game's immersive world and engaging gameplay. From liberating outposts to embarking on daring missions, every moment in Far Cry 4 is filled with adrenaline-pumping excitement.

One of the game's standout features is its rich and diverse environment. The lush forests, snow-capped peaks, and bustling towns of Kyrat provide a breathtaking backdrop for the action-packed adventure. Exploring the world on foot or by vehicle never gets old, and the sense of freedom to tackle challenges in any way I saw fit was incredibly empowering.

The game's story is also compelling, with memorable characters and thought-provoking themes woven throughout. From the enigmatic Pagan Min to the brave rebels fighting for freedom, each character adds depth and nuance to the narrative, making every encounter feel meaningful and memorable.

Of course, it wouldn't be a Far Cry game without the signature chaos and mayhem, and Far Cry 4 delivers in spades. Whether I was engaging in intense firefights with enemy soldiers, taming wild animals to aid me in battle, or soaring through the skies in a wingsuit, the game never failed to keep me on the edge of my seat.

In conclusion, Far Cry 4 is a must-play for fans of the series and anyone looking for an epic open-world adventure. With its stunning visuals, immersive world, and adrenaline-fueled gameplay, it's a journey I won't soon forget.

[h1] TLDR: 7/10 A more refined and expansive version of what Far Cry 3 established as the formula, yet still doesn't capture everything that made that game outstanding. [/h1]

[h3] Actual Review (Censored Spoilers) [/h3]
Coming directly off of Far Cry 2 and 3, I was completely blown away by how good this game looks. Literally for my first 5 hours or so, I couldn't help but constantly be baffled by how real the environments look, and my GTX 1060 handled the game pretty well at medium graphics settings.

[h3] Story [/h3]
Storywise its good. Pagan Min is nonexistent save for the beginning and end of the game with various radio dialogue during certain story missions, but he is a pretty well written villain. The concepts the game presents and focus on player choice was also an interesting effort. FC3 has the better story overall, [spoiler] but mainly because some of the main characters in FC4 feel like they're there to serve gameplay purposes rather than serve the story (AKA Sabal and Amnita). [/spoiler]

[h3] How I Wish FC3 Had Some of These New Features! [/h3]
Gameplay wise, its FC3 but enhanced. Some of the new stuff makes the game feel very gamified, so I opt to turn off most of the hud/icon elements. Far Cry historically is a very immersive game series which is why they have so many HUD and accessibility options in the first place, something a lot of other FPS games should be doing as well. But most of the combat mechanics are a straight upgrade from FC3.

For example: being able to move bodies after a kill. FC3 only had the option the drag bodies after performing a takedown and you couldn't move them afterward, so adding that feature enhances the realism of the game. I also found myself constantly cycling between all the new and classic throwables since each (grenade, molotov, throwing knife, and bait) have a distinct use. I probably did use the knives the most since they don't alert enemies. The syringe system from FC3 makes a return as well. To be honest, I never used it at all in normal play because I find it very gamey, and I had no problem with the game by not using it, so it's up to you really.

Player choice is a big focus of the gameplay as well.. You can opt for either stealth or direct attack by calling in friendlies to help in battles or capturing outposts. I definitely used stealth for most of the outposts and missions because stealth makes the game become more puzzle-like and methodical (unless you cheese outposts by taking out all alarms and enemies with a suppressed sniper from a distance, yawn) you also get more rewards/unlockables for clearing outposts and certain missions undetected or with no alarms triggered. I played on normal difficulty, which was probably why going in guns blazing to outposts was stupid easy most times. The enemy AI when in-combat is definitely way easier to deal with than when trying to stay undetected, they rarely push your position or flush you out of cover unless they have somewhat line-of-sight, and when they do, the enemy callout system makes their tactics pretty easy to counter. I don't know if AI difficulty scales with your game difficulty setting either. I definitely prefer the combat of this game to FC3 however, as it is literally just an improved version of it.

[h3] The Completionist Grind [/h3]
One last thing to mention is i'm 50/50 on going for 100% on this game. I did it and it took around 70 hours to do, and the second act of the game I was speedrunning everything that wasn't part of the main story. 100%ing this game, like all Far Cry games, is sort of a collectathon, but also the side mission structure is one of a few missions but in different locations. A lot of elements of this game don't count towards the ingame completion percentage thankfully, but a lot of them you do cause you can along the way, or because the game doesn't feel complete without doing them (discover all locations, loot all lootables, getting gold in all races, etc.).

You also have the arena, which again most of it doesn't count towards the ingame percentage, but the weapon challenges have a star system that feels incomplete if you don't get 5 stars on all weapons (which btw is 39 weapons. Not all weapons in the game but most of them). This isn't hard at all, most weapons I got 5 stars first try, but the arena is definitely the most grindy part of the game. I still enjoyed most of it even when I figured out the formula of it (manipulate enemy spawn locations, get a few chain takedowns to reach 800 points, then play defensive the rest of the 5 rounds, repeat). Mopping up the rest of what I needed to do for 100% was the only time I actually ever used the syringe system, and I only used the focus syringes for the speed boost. If you're a completionist like me, do it if you want, but if you think the grind is too long and boring I don't blame you, I stretched this playthrough out over a couple of months so I didn't get burnt out on it.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
Overall worth the buy for sure. Nothing about the game is outright bad in terms of quality. It does have boring moments and sequences, but the overall package is one of pretty great quality. 7/10

Far Cry 4 is one of the best games in the Far Cry series. The only real things I don't like about the game are the fact that it's too easy (even on hardest difficulty setting) and the story is a little bit anticlimactic.

The story starts out amazing. Pagan Min is a really cool villain and I like how as the game progresses it starts to just seem like you're replacing one dictatorship with another. It's kind of open ended which is cool. The actual game world is the star of the show, as you're in a Phillipines-style fictional country called Kyrat which is full of all kinds of things to do and see. The thing I love about all the open world Far Cry games is that as you're going to explore one area you will often encounter some kind of side quest or activity that leads you somewhere else entirely. This game looks great and while it's full of mountainous terrain it's much easier to explore than most games that have this sort of elevated landscape.

The combat is just too easy, though. If you capture all the radio towers (which isn't hard to do) you can unlock a weapon that obliterates everything in just a couple shots. While it's nice to have overpowered weapons, most of the game's combat is a joke. If you take out the alarms during the outpost capture sequences you have just ten enemies or so to kill. You can see the enemies through the walls if you use a certain item that's easy to obtain, so you always have the upper hand in almost every combat situation.

Some of the side quests are challenging, however. There's this whole side event where you play as an ancient warrior in Shangri-La which is one of the coolest sequences I've ever seen in a Far Cry game. And it's hard. I wish the whole game was this hard because these were my favorite parts about the game.

Beyond that there's always some calamity going on and the game world is very active. Most of the animals in this game are very hostile and you will often see random NPCs fighting each other, like a bear eating a deer or two bears fighting each other, or civilians being attacked by the bears. The game has a 'karma' system and I'm not sure what it even does but it's very easy to get to the highest karma level just by 100% completing the game. There's ton of other stuff too- races, an arena, hunting side quests, assassination side quests. The stealth sequences where the game ends if you are detected are actually kind of challenging and have a puzzle element.

I 100% completed this game in about 30 hours so it's the perfect length, too. I would say this, Far Cry 3 and the original Far Cry are probably the best Far Cry games in the bunch. It's amazing how they immerse you in the world and really get you invested in the story and its characters. It's unfortunate that the story at the end just ends, as I would've liked maybe 2-3 more hours of chasing Pagan Min and an actual climax where you have to make a decision to kill him after some great effort.

After playing Far Cry 3 and falling in love with the story and the setting, I quickly bought Far Cry 4, anticipating a similar experience, however some things fall short in comparison to 3. The characters were so boring or annoying, that I barely cared for them. Even your protagonist, Ajay Ghale is not that refined. The most annoying characters are the radio host who never seems to shut up when driving a vehicle, and talks, and im not kidding, only about shit and hygiene. To be in the middle of a gunfight and having to listen to this fuck talk is psychological torture, I had to bind my key to mute the radio  to my mouse to mute the radio upon vehicle use. THAT'S HOW BAD IT WAS.

The most memorable characters that I will actually remember, are Mumu Chiffon, Longinus and Pagan Min. 

Mumu Chiffon, altho feminine and your typical Art Diva, actually had good dialogue. I was dissapointed at how the story somehow ended with him tho, as I was expecting an event that the devs maybe took out during the work on the game..

Longinus is a smuggler, murderer and supplier of tools and weapons for both you and the Golden Path. His missions are very important when it comes to upgrades, and he offered decent side quests. His redemption arc from his past was sympathetic, and his gift for your last mission is a decent weapon. I wish I saw more of him however..

Pagan Min is by far one of the most charismatic and likeable villains in the whole game. This guy is a literal dictator and I ended up liking him and his conversations and interactions more than the so called Golden Path allies, who only know how to disagree with each other and send you on missions. Every time that I was close to talking to Min I felt excitement as I knew that things would become somewhat interesting. In the end I shot him however, and I regret that decision.

I don't typically write reviews. But since Far Cry 4 is now a decade old, I may as well write one.

If you've played Far Cry 3 I'm sure you've noticed that the movement and physics are the exact same.
This isn't necessarily bad, considering that I personally much prefer this movement system compared to the newer titles (*cough* *cough* Far Cry 6) The skill tree is now split into two trees (The Elephant and The Tiger) instead of the original three. (The Heron, The Shark and The Spider) 

Some skills only unlock after beating certain missions, or side activities. This *can* be a bit drag doing the same missions over and over but it's more than doable

This Far Cry title was the first to introduce open-world Co-Op, where one player plays as Ajay while the other plays as Hurk.
Sadly, when playing Co-Op all story missions are locked until your Co-Op partner leaves. And progression (Outposts and Side Activities) will only save for the host. (Ajay)

This game also features a 5v5 multiplayer mode. However, you very often won't find lobbies due to not many people knowing about this mode. (You can access it in the 'Chronicles' tab in the main menu. "Battles of Kyrat") 

I personally enjoy Far Cry 4 for it's gameplay, but not for it's story. I recommend giving it a shot if you have the time to do so.

Far Cry 4: Himalayan High Jinks, Exploding Yaks, and the Craziest Vacation Ever (a Far Cry shorter)
Forget Nepal, Kyrat's where it's at: snow-capped peaks, roaring elephants, and a dictator named Pagan Min whose fashion sense screams "dictator chic, but with extra explosions." You're Ajay Ghale, tourist turned freedom fighter, tasked with liberating this tropical paradise from Min's reign of, well, colorful tyranny.

Story? Bonkers, mate. Pagan's a villain so gloriously over-the-top, he makes Bond villains look like toddlers playing dress-up. Expect flamboyant speeches, psychotic sidekicks, and enough twists to leave you dizzy like a yak on Red Bull. The supporting cast? Just as wild, from rebel leaders with questionable hygiene to honey badgers (seriously, those things are terrifying).

Gameplay? Chaos in a box. Shoot, stab, grapple, ride elephants into enemy strongholds â€“ the options are as varied as the wildlife (tigers, eagles, the occasional exploding yak...you get the picture). Need a sniper perch? Grapple hook to the top of a radio tower. Out of ammo? Throw a grenade of dubious origins. Kyrat's your playground, and the only rule is: "have fun, don't get eaten by a honey badger."

The world? Breathtaking (literally, the air's thin up here). From lush valleys to ancient temples, Kyrat's a postcard come to life, except everyone's got guns and a questionable moral compass. You'll spend hours just exploring, hunting mythical beasts, and discovering hidden shrines while wondering why your travel agent never mentioned this place (probably the exploding yaks).

So, perfect? Nah, mate. Bugs bigger than Pagan Min's ego, driving like a yak on roller skates, and a story that occasionally gets lost in the explosions. But here's the rub: Far Cry 4 is pure, unadulterated fun. It's a Himalayan fever dream with more laughs than a grenade factory and enough chaos to make a dictator blush. So grab your grappling hook, channel your inner action hero, and get ready for the wildest vacation ever. Just remember, in Kyrat, the only guaranteed souvenir is a tantrum from Pagan Min (and maybe a yak stampede).

P.S. Special thanks to my trusty AI co-pilot, Bard. They may not know how to ride an elephant, but their knowledge of Kyrat lore is deeper than a Himalayan yeti's beard. Plus, they kept me from writing the entire review in Nepali (my language skills are about as sharp as a butter knife). So yeah, give that AI some love too. Maybe a few extra rupees or a shiny new algorithm upgrade. They deserve it.

Now go forth, liberate Kyrat, and try not to get eaten by a honey badger.

Sincerely,

[h1] Far CryÂ® 4 - 2023 review [/h1]

Released nearly 10 years ago, Far Cry 4 was one of my favorite open-world adventure as an early teenager. I went back to rediscover the magic I once felt while playing this title, and even though my experience was decent, there's a lot of tedious downsides that were hidden deep behind nostalgia that resurfaced as an adult. Far Cry 4 isn't a bad game at all, and I still recommend it if you're into the formula, but it isn't an ''incredible'' game per se, and here's why:

[b] Pros [/b]
[list]
[*] The game still looks great even when compared to more recent games. The graphics are realistic, the environment feels alive.
[*] The gameplay has improved a lot from the previous titles. The gunplay feels good, the stealth is mostly fun, hunting is always a nice addition, the wingsuit and vehicules are somewhat challenging to use, all of which I enjoyed. The perk system is simple yet efficient. The bell tower system didn't bother me at all, unlike some. [/list]

[b] Neutrals [/b]
[list]
[*] The story is okay. Pagan is an incredible antagonist, and your involvment with the Golden Path will leave you questionning your choices at the very end of the story, but the side characters are definitely annoying, and Ajay is too close to a silent protagonist for a world that screams for a narrator. A lot of the main missions were also underwhelming.
[*] The level design is somewhat decent, but there wasn't enough variety between environments, unlike Far Cry Primal for example. It felt like there was no rememberable places in the world. The map itself isn't so much of a problem, I liked the fact that the North was separated from the South, but while exploring the world, the amount of tiny hills you cannot climb since they are a little too steep bothered me a lot.
[*] The game length is respectable, it took me around 40 hours to fully complete it, yet it felt like the vast majority of it was done picking up collectibles, which I find to be a sad excuse for bigger game length. The only reason I'm putting it in [i] Neutrals [/i] is because apart for one weapon and driving all the vehicules, fully completing this game was a fun overall experience, even though certainly flawed. The side missions also got boring towards the end of the game, thanks to their excessive repetiveness.
[*] Just like the other entries in the franchise, the AI can sometimes leave a bitter taste in the mouth. On the highest difficulties, an enemy can be completely blind from a certain angle, yet another can spot you easily from a mile away, while you're behind cover. This is mostly why stealth was frustrating on some occasions, because it was inconsistent. It isn't a major complaint, but it could have been a bit better. The NPC AIs are just plain stupid, though. [/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
[*] I don't know if it's the DUNIA engine that is terrible, or if it's just because it's an older game, but it runs like shit. I have a high-end PC rig, and I'm always stuck between 50-70fps, no matter how much I lower the graphics, I barely gain any performances. Wished I could at least experience the whole thing in VSync 60 fps, but that won't even do.
[*] The game is filled with bugs. I encountered several crashes that made me lose a decent amount of progression. I glitched through walls, wasn't able to climb surfaces that indicate clearly they can be climbed, the wingsuit hitbox is awful, etc. And the bugs aren't just minor visual/audio problems, they can definitely influence the outcome of a mission on a lot of occasion. The FOV reseted on many occasions, and the only way to get it back to your liking is to enter a door or to die. It was extremely painful to deal with all of it. [/list]

[b] TL;DR [/b] It pains me to say that this game is overshadowed by awful performance and stability, and since the campaign is weaker than Far Cry 3's, I get why a lot of people won't enjoy this game. I still liked it for what it was, a good open-world with fun gameplay, great graphics, and enjoyable exploration, even though it definitely has its downsides. Long live Pagan Min!

Hereâ€™s my spoiler free review of Far Cry 4 :

Whatâ€™s this game about? Itâ€™s simply about a son who wants to fulfill his motherâ€™s last wish. The journey to Kyrat began. You have to fight all the way there and learn the truth. Along the way you have to decide who you want to side with. There are only 2 leaders to choose from based on your preference or play style. Theyâ€™ll be the future of Kyrat.

What I enjoyed from the game :

1.	I like the atmosphere. Itâ€™s truly outstanding with realistic vegetative and animals. Sometimes I just want to sit and relax and enjoy the view.
2.	The world is full of activities. You might find this a little bit unnecessary, but in my opinion, this is what makes the open-world aspect lively and immersive.
3.	The mechanics are easy to understand but need some time to learn.
4.	Weapon choices are plentiful. Pocket grenade launcher is the most op in my opinion. Itâ€™s sidearm (usable while driving) and also deals lots of damage.
5.	I like the sneak kill aspect. I know that you can just blast outpost all at once, but I enjoyed sneaking more.
6.	Economy is relatively balance not too grindy.

8.	Movement is fluid. It feels like you are there to do everything.

Far Cry 4 is one of the overlooked installments of the Far Cry series. The story of this game is broader than that of previous games, filled with plot twists and many "WTF moments". There are a lot of missions and quests to complete. The gameplay of this game is dynamic like in every Far Cry. There are a lot of weapons to choose from and a lot of ways to play the game. Like in most of the Far Cry games, there are some "survival" aspects in this game (Hunting and skinning animals to make pouches and loot bags from their fur and skin; Cutting plants, obtaining their leafs and crafting various syringes; etc.) The graphics are amazing and they have aged very well over almost 7 years since its release. Soundtracks and music have a peculiar charm, linked with the setting of the game (Kyrat), to them. In my opinion, Far Cry 4 is one of the best, if not the best Far Cry game! I recommend it to everyone, but it holds it's price, so better get it on a sale!

Far Cry 4 was better than I expected. At the time of playing FC3 I had already played FC5 and noticed that Ubisoft apparently found a formula for commercial success in FC3. This lead them down the Call Of Duty route of re-releasing (more or less) the same game. It's a shame. Far Cry 1 had mutant monkeys, Far Cry 2 innovated with their physics engine; bringing fire and moderate destruction to the game. Far Cry 3 was a proper open world game with interesting themes and antagonist-centered gameplay. It's a shame that the pace of innovation reduced. 

My primary gripe with this game is the artificially large world which is filled with repeatable quests. Their only relevance to the game in general is that certain signature weapons and skills are locked behind them. 

The karma events are better. While essentially repeating content as well, they happen pseudo-randomly [i] and at your current location [/i] instead of requiring considerable boring travel in an empty world. In one way, they are the only life in a mostly dead world.

BUT - the campaign is very good. The facial animations, the characters, the story and the cutscenes are all very engaging. It's full of difficult decisions and interesting characters that is it is worthwhile to learn more about. Pagan Min in particular reminded me of Handsome Jack, which is high praise.

As a sandbox single player game, it's fine. It can't compete with games like The Witcher or Red Dead Redemption, but it's not a bad game by any means. There's a lot to enjoy, so I give the game my recommendation.

In short, Far Cry 4 is my favorite Far Cry game and one of my favorite games of all time. Many people think of FC3 as the best FC game but for me it's 4. I highly recommend this game.

FC4 gets some flak for basically copying FC3 in a different setting. The game only had about a year in development so the devs cut as many corners as they could. The game looks good, but not much better than FC3. FC4 retains many of the same elements as FC3 and doesn't push the boundaries to much. In many ways, however, this is a good thing. The game basically takes everything from FC3 and dials it up to 11. FC3 was a great game so you get a lot of the same elements but in a new, bigger setting.

The story isn't amazing but I liked it. I think it's better than FC3's story. It tries to add even more nuance and gray morality than FC3, although it doesn't always do a good job of showing that. Unlike newer games, FC4 has a good mix of serious and silly missions. The game has the best pacing out of any FC game. Instead of opening up the whole map at the start and letting you choose which missions to do when, the game tries to funnel you in a certain direction. You literally start on one side of the map and work your way up. I really like this. I can feel the progression of the story and myself as a player as I gain more and more territory.

The games difficulty is well balanced. I didn't feel to strong or weak even on the hardest difficulty. The AI is very stupid but you don't have a ton of OP weapons like newer entries. There are some annoying aspects though. The animals, especially the birds, are very annoying to deal with. Also, the game does have some annoying bugs like misplaced location makers. One of those is actually under the map but you can still get to it if you want to 100% the game.

**Far Cry 4: Kyrat's Kaleidoscope**

* **A World Alive:** Kyrat isn't just a backdrop; it's a vibrant, teeming ecosystem. Lush jungles crawl with exotic wildlife, ancient ruins whisper forgotten secrets, and snow-capped peaks pierce the sky. You'll grapple through temples, ride elephants into chaotic firefights, and encounter everything from honey badgers to cultists with flamethrowers.

* **Unforgettable Villains:** Pagan Min, the despotic ruler, is deliciously deranged. His flamboyant unpredictability makes him as captivating as he is hateable. His lieutenants, each with their own quirks and agendas, add a layer of twisted depth to the narrative.

* **Mayhem in Paradise:** Far Cry's sandbox freedom reigns supreme. Whether you're sniping enemies from a distance, setting up elaborate traps, or riding a gyrocopter into a propaganda tower, the possibilities for open-world chaos are endless. The grappling hook adds a new layer of verticality, letting you scale cliffs and ambush outposts from unexpected angles.

**Valley of the Yetis: Where Myth Meets Mayhem**



* **Himalayan Chill:** Valley of the Yetis throws you into an icy wasteland straight out of a yeti legend. The desolate beauty of the snow-capped peaks, treacherous ice bridges, and hidden yeti caves creates a unique and suspenseful atmosphere.

* **Face the Beast:** The yetis are more than just furry punching bags. They're intelligent, adaptable, and will stalk you through the blizzard, demanding respect and cunning strategies to defeat.

* **Radioactive Rumble:** Defend your radio outpost against waves of Pagan Min's forces and yeti attacks. The mix of human and mythical enemies keeps you on your toes, forcing you to adapt your tactics and defenses on the fly.

**Together, Far Cry 4 and Valley of the Yetis offer an unforgettable open-world adventure full of explosive action, quirky characters, and breathtaking landscapes. It's a playground for mayhem, a descent into madness, and a chilling encounter with the legends of the Himalayas. So, grab your grappling hook, fire up your gyrocopter, and get ready to paint Kyrat red (and white) in this epic saga of revolution and yetis!**

Remember, this is just the tip of the iceberg. Kyrat and the Himalayas hold countless secrets and stories waiting to be discovered. So, dive into the adventure, embrace the chaos, and let me know what your favorite moments are!

Far Cry 4, another great game in the franchise after Far Cry 3, essentially has the same formula as Far Cry 3, about 90% of its mechanics are exactly the same. The biggest difference regarding mechanics is the mission. One issue I have with the predecessor is there is not much to do besides the main quests. Far Cry 4 makes it up by introducing many more side quests and activities, adding around 20+ hours of playtime if you decide to do all of them. Apart from that, there is no perceivable difference that worth talking about. You can see that the success of Far Cry 4 is pretty much a guarantee because the predecessor sells well, so if you like Far Cry 3, you will find this one interesting as well. 

Like its predecessor, Far Cry 4 offers diverse gameplay. You can choose to go straight up gun blazing, or stealth, or snipping or whatever depending on how you want to play, with its wide range of different weapons. It is not only a decent shooter but also a great stealth and snipping game. The only complaint I have is the weapon customized parts are not differentiated enough. But that does not hurt the gameplay much.

Far Cry franchise always has great stories on a universal theme about how a person deviates from his original path. I first played the game in my adolescence, all I saw was this universal theme and nothing else. But this time when I played it again, I saw much more nuance that its predecessor doesnâ€™t have. The story has more touch on the grey zone of humanity. Characters in the game, no matter the villains, Paul, Noore, Yuma, Pagan, or the heroes, Ajay, Sabal, Amita, Ajayâ€™s father, all have complex personalities. To define what they do is either horrible or noble is just a matter of perspective and there is no definitive black and white. This complexity makes the story intriguing and really sets me thinking. But that being said, the story is not perfect. Most motivations of characters are understandable, but some really donâ€™t hold up. Particularly, the script is sloppy about the character development of Ajay, the protagonist. Ajay just does whatever he is asked to do like a puppet without thoughts. Lacking manifestation of his thoughts and motivations hurt the story. 

As an open-world game, it is very mechanical, just running around doing repetitive stuff. It cannot compare to true open-world masterpieces like The Witcher or The Elder Scrolls. But the diverse sandbox gameplay and the diversified environment that is nice to explore redeem itself a lot, so as a matter of fact, I like it a lot, and in my opinion, it is pretty much the best open-world Ubisoft can construct for being just a little repetitive but not truly annoyingly grindy like some recent installments.

These pretty much wrap up my review. the game has no serious drawbacks, and the graphics are really beautiful if you can go max setting.

Far Cry 4 is a huge game that took me a good 80 hours to complete, and I thoroughly enjoyed every second. The graphics were outstanding and everything felt smooth and optimised. Music and sound design were really well done and the animals and NPCs in this game really made Kyrat feel alive and immersive.

The game builds off of Far Cry 3, and improves alot of the annoyances I had with that game. Driving is now more enjoyable, the combat felt really satisfying with all the variety of weapons. Grappling up cliffs and mountains was a nice addition, elephant riding was great, and all the side missions felt varied and never got boring, especially Shangri-La and Hurk missions. Main story was really good aswell.

My only criticisms are it's a little too combat-heavy at times, it would have been nice to relax a little and explore but you are constantly on edge with all the animals and enemy patrols. I did have a couple of crashes, and a few bugs and glitches but that is to be expected with a game this size.

Overall, my favourite Far Cry game so far, very immersive, tons of content and so much fun to play.

Title: "Pagan Min's Reign: A Glorious Era in Far Cry 4"

In the mesmerizing world of Far Cry 4, players are treated to an unparalleled gaming experience under the benevolent rule of the charismatic and enigmatic Pagan Min. This revolutionary installment in the Far Cry series takes a bold step by placing players at the center of a thrilling narrative, guided by the visionary leadership of the illustrious king himself.

Pagan Min, a man of refined tastes and exquisite sensibilities, transforms the fictional Himalayan country of Kyrat into a utopian paradise. His colorful personality and unwavering commitment to progress make him an unforgettable character in the gaming universe. As players embark on their journey through Kyrat, they find themselves immersed in the splendor of a nation that flourishes under Pagan Min's progressive rule.

The game's graphics and design pay homage to the opulence of Pagan Min's kingdom, with vibrant landscapes and awe-inspiring architecture that showcase the prosperity of Kyrat. The attention to detail in capturing the grandeur of Pagan Min's palace and the surrounding regions is a testament to the game developers' dedication to creating an unforgettable gaming environment.

Pagan Min's leadership style is a breath of fresh air in the gaming industry. His ability to maintain order while embracing diversity and cultural richness sets Far Cry 4 apart from its predecessors. The game encourages players to appreciate the complexities of leadership and the nuanced decisions required to govern a nation with both strength and compassion.

The captivating storyline unfolds with Pagan Min as a central figure, adding layers of intrigue and suspense to the narrative. Players find themselves drawn into a world where alliances are tested, loyalties are questioned, and the true meaning of power is explored. Pagan Min's character development is masterfully executed, leaving players with a sense of empathy and understanding for the man behind the crown.

Far Cry 4 successfully breaks away from conventional gaming norms by offering an immersive experience that challenges players to question their own perspectives. Pagan Min's reign is not just a backdrop; it is the essence of the game, inviting players to navigate the complexities of morality and authority in a world shaped by a visionary leader.

In conclusion, Far Cry 4 stands as a testament to the brilliance of Pagan Min's reign. The game's commitment to storytelling, coupled with its stunning visuals and innovative gameplay, make it a must-play for those seeking a gaming experience that transcends the ordinary. Pagan Min's legacy is etched into the very fabric of Kyrat, leaving an indelible mark on the hearts of players who dare to embrace the glory of his rule.

May Pagan's light shine upon you all.

I'm so torn about this game. I sort of like it...it's also kinda boring. I'm really on the fence but I wouldn't recommend it. Also, the Ubisoft Connect launcher is required.

It's a well made game. All the mechanics are solid. I haven't hit any bugs or even any inconsequential jankiness. 

I just feel like I'm going through the motions already and I'm only 25 hrs in.

I was really excited about the hunting and skin gathering. Then it just became drop bait, predator instantly rushes in, a couple shotgun blasts to the face, gather skin and bait, repeat. There's no tracking or stalking unless you impose limits on yourself. Killing animals with your bow or knife will yield double the skins but it's way faster to just drop bait and shotgun blasts them for the single skin because you can complete that cycle in 4 or 5 seconds. That's really not an exaggeration at all.

The injections are a cool idea but there are very few herbs. Green, Yellow, Red, Blue, Purple, and White. Green gives you the HP injections and the other 3 injections are a combination of two of the other herbs. I honestly don't feel like I ever need them except the HP ones. The one that tracks all wildlife and enemies around you is very useful but it makes much of the game trivial.

I really like the bow to stealthily take over an outpost! I would set up on the highest point I could find near the outpost and use the camera to tag enemies and spot the alarm boxes. I'd usually have to find different vantage points to get a good understanding of the enemies present and where the alarms are located. Then I'd get close and snipe one or two enemies before racing off to another hiding place and picking off more. It is a really fun way to take over a place.

However, it becomes stale and you can simply fire multiple RPGs at them and snipe with a gun or run in with damage reduction injections, all enemies tagged, faster run (with auto-dodge) and wreck the place.

It's one of those games I feel like I should love but it's a slog at best. 

Looting enemies and chests will give money or literal vendor fodder. So, just money. I can't spend it fast enough. It's entirely meaningless.

The collectable are very basic. The masks are sort of neat. A marked area will show up near you and you need to follow the sound to find the mask and destroy it. Sadly, it's really boring too. The grappling hook is actually pretty cool with some neat physics-based swinging. Like most of the mechanics, though, it get's old really quickly. I feel no real incentive to explore.

The skills are nothing new but not the most basic I've seen. The "trees" are actually just ~10 linear paths with 5 skills each (most are passives). I have skill points into a bunch of stuff I never use because the 3rd or 4th node is actually something I want. For the most part, I don't have anything I want to invest in. 

I paid <$10 CDN so I don't feel like I got ripped off. I just don't feel compelled to keep playing.

If you're thinking about purchasing this game off a sale or something for the generous price of 3-10 bucks, here's a piece of advice for you. Fucking don't.
They should be paying you money to sit through this dogshit garbage fire.

This game is so broken you literally cannot finish it without resorting to glitches and bugs (Unless you want the "secret" ending). And if you're into exploring and collecting everything in the game (You know, as you're supposed to in Farcry), you're in for a really bad time. It's doubtful they were to patch anything at this point in time, too.
And no, I'm not just talking about "The Underwater Truck"-incident.

Many of the mechanics within the game such as running, jumping, climbing, grappling hook, windsuit, parachute and driving a vehicle are straight up broken. And they are mandatory to completing the game.
There's invisible walls everywhere that'll make you crash mid-air when gliding or driving a car. 
The hitboxes of trees and branches do not reflect the visual cues of the game.
I genuinely cannot stress the amount of badly optimized assets in the game that are simply invisible blocks to prevent your passage. Windsuiting down a mountain is like a coinflip between life and death, unless you fancy parachuting like IRL.
Clipping through obstacles, walls, floors, boxes happens a lot. Sometimes you may even fall out of the map altogether.
None of the vehicles save for one feel good to drive or are responsive enough to be used within the mountains where this game takes place in. Unless you're planning to drive like your blind, asian grandma.
Genuinely there's only 1 vehicle in the game that feels even remotely acceptable outside of main roads, that being the quad-bike/buggy or whatever the fuck.
I get the impression that travelling in this game was designed by a disabled, satanic slug that wants everyone to be even more crippled than he is. Simply out of spite.
"Oh man, but there's helicopters in the game. You can just fly." 
Yeah, just wait until you accidentally ascend 10CM above the ground and the motor gives up, sending you crashing down to the ground. 

Repetitive sidequests that are all the same thing over and over again remain the blight of Ubisoft.
Much like the Shanath Arena, that forces you to reach rank 10 in order to unlock all guns. 
The Arena is a cheap and trivialized version of the combat in the game where you're encouraged to stay engaged for several hours at a time, yet every arena match feels, is, and plays out as the exact same.
Especially after you figure out how to abuse the infinitely spawning medpacks.
"Oh man, but you can connect your mobile app into it and then..."
Yeah no- fuck off. Literally stop breathing.

Ubisoft recently announced they were ending support and taking all of the servers offline for "The Crew." This game was advertised as having single player content. But it requires you to connect to their servers even if you are not playing online. 

What does this have to do with this game? Well it means that all of their games moving forward are potentially just long term rentals that are not advertised as such. This is a very anti-consumer practice. And I cannot in good conscience recommend any games from this publisher when that has the potential to happen to any buyer. Ubisoft could patch these games to remove the online requirement. But they're choosing not to. So that makes their products a very poor value proposition in my opinion.

[h2]Far Cry 4 Gold Edition Review[/h2]

Review is after 100% completion of the main game, Escape from Durgesh Prison and 100% completion of Valley of the Yetis DLC. Obtained all single player achievements except the 4 co-op and multiplayer achievements. It's vital to note that Ubisoft does [b]NOT[/b] respect you in  [b]ANY[/b] way for achieving 100%. No achievement to showcase, no in game reward, not even a pop-up saying congratulations. However, Ubisoft does force several co-op and multiplayer related achievements (dead now because the game released in 2014), that intentionally prohibit you from earning all achievements.

So why did I 100% this game? It was a mix of: the allure of Kyrat, the Ubisoft open world formulae, vibrant colour palette and lastly just to see if I could 100% a Ubisoft game.

[h3]The Good:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The initial momentum after being introduced into Kyrat helped me tackle the South Kyrat map with gusto.
[*]Interesting allied characters such as Amita, Longinus, Rana, Sabal, Willis. Their voice acting performances were of good quality.
[*]The main villain had 3 lieutenants with backstories and motivations.
[*]The main villain Pagan Min was constructed and presented remarkably well. Is he better than Vaas? Yes I think so, considering he lasts the entire game.
[*]The main highlights are the 5 Shangri La missions. The complete shift in the colour palette and the greater emphasis on stealth made for an incredible experience. The lore and the scenery were engrossing. There were many screenshot worthy vistas. The shift to a different language fit those missions very well. The peak of Far Cry 4â€™s game design here in my opinion.
[*]Arena missions were initially enjoyable and offered a variety of options.
[*]The Buzzer a.k.a Badass Mini Chopper. The ONLY efficient way to travel.
[*]Mini climbing puzzles for the tallest mountains.
[*]Wingsuit and parachute traversal.
[*]17 Bell tower puzzles and unlockable rewards for hijacking all of them.
[*]20 Lost Letters with their separate interesting story.
[*]20 Journals that add more to the history of the protagonist. Essential collectathon in my opinion.
[*]Adequate level of mystery surrounding the protagonist's past. The search for answers is a strong motivation to finish the game.
[*]Valley of the Yetis DLC allowed more playtime in the snowy Himalayas.
[*]While the grind to 100% was gruelling, it did feel worthwhile upon reaching the final 3 missions.
[*]100% completion progress tracker for completionists.
[/list]
[h3]The Bad:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The massive North Kyrat map eroded my motivation to complete the game. Simply no need for that area to be so large.
[*]At the 70% mark I was truly feeling the grind of the collectathon. I had maxed out levels, karma, skills and upgrades while rolling in rupees. The XP rewards and the karma boosts from the collectathon felt pointless due to this.
[*]Skills reducing bow sway and weapon reload speed and weapon switch speed did not feel impactful.
[*]Utterly despised all the drug missions as they always take away control from the player. No weapons, no skills, no syringes or utilities. Absolutely loathed seeing those mission icons on the map.
[*]Missed opportunity to add more ammo types for the recurve bow, e.g. tranquilliser, sleeping gas or smoke screen arrow heads.
[*]150 propaganda posters with only meagre rewards and no final grand reward.
[*]50 mani wheels spun while having max karma, to receive nothing special at the end.
[*]55 masks destroyed to receive only a serviceable reward. Honestly I only used that reward once. Moreover, there is no decisive conclusion to that mystery.
[*]Terrible end fight in the Shangri-La missions. Previous missions can be played in stealth; not the final battle. It's simply a boss + horde mode, with minimal cover and limited ammo.
[*]Sadistic of Ubisoft to lock a weapon (quite powerful) at Arena rank 10. That grind was mind numbing. I needed to muster all my dedication to grind for that.
[*]Escape from Durgesh Prison game mode felt pointless as it was a timed challenge gauntlet. Detested that timer.
[*]Valley of the Yetis DLC took away the protagonistâ€™s guns; then asks that he search for them randomly lying around in the wilderness. All skills were force reset to 0, which I think is the greatest travesty. Since, In the main game I had unlocked the majority of skills prior to entering North Kyrat; therefore, it felt like a pointless chore to skill up yet again in the DLC.
[*]Regrettably the Valley of the Yetis DLC shattered my enjoyment of the game due to the repetitive grind to skill up (again) and obtain weapons and upgrades.
[*]Moreover, the DLC could have benefitted from adding snowstorms to the mix to reduce visibility and allow for stealth gameplay. Sadly a missed opportunity.
[/list]
[h3]The Advice:[/h3]
[list]
[*] [b]DO NOT[/b] play the alternate ending first. I made that mistake out of curiosity and it cost my excitement for the story. Not all mysteries are explained there, but my enjoyment of the story was diminished.
[*]Optimal and chronological order to play the game is: Main game till prison mission, Escape from Durgesh Prison DLC, Valley of the Yetis DLC, Main game till conclusion.
[*]From the beginning it's possible to work towards upgrading all equipment. Grind this out as much as possible as it provides varied options for gameplay.
[*]Snow leopard skins will be out of reach initially; however, there will be Himalayas missions. Once there, reach a vantage point, throw bait, kill any animals that are drawn to it, including snow leopards. Restock bait by looting killed animals. Farm as many skins as needed.
[*]Use the sidearm grenade launcher with the Buzzer to fly close to propaganda posters and grenade them.
[*]For the Mask collectathon throw Molotovs at the general area; the fire can burn the mask.
[*]The Arena grind for the final weapon is tougher now without the companion app. Try to finish it off in one game session.
[*]For the final Shangri-La fight, run straight to the stone sculptures surrounding the arena and hide from enemies and boss attacks. Keep moving along that rim to avoid fire attacks and fireballs. Snipe the boss using the special abilities. Pick up ammo quickly while the boss is temporarily down.
[*]The Survival races were unnecessarily challenging due to bugs with boarding the hovercraft. Enter, exit and enter again to get the hovercraft to move.
[*]Heavily pace yourself to 100% this game. At the 80% mark I just wanted to be done with the game. Even the vibrant Shangri-La missions appeared daunting.
[*]I canâ€™t even imagine 100% completing the game after exhausting all story missions, as the grind is excruciating at times. As such, pace yourself on the story missions if attempting 100% completion.
[/list]

But i had some technical difficulties with it, the thing is [b] if you for some whatever reason try to open a map editor [/b] you would not be able to run the game again and all of the usual stuff wont get it running even if you uninstall it and install it again. 
So what you should do to get it to open again is the following: First do Windows Key + R

Then Type in "regedit"

Look for a folder starting with "S-1-5-21-" (It might have two folders with this name try checking both).

Software > Ubisoft > Far Cry 4

Delete the Far Cry 4 folder.

Close Registry Edit.

Try to open Far Cry 4 again. (Close everything and restart the PC first).

When listing favorite Far Cry games, you might mention 3, 5, or even, God forbid, the 6th installment, but not the fourth. And it's all about the antagonist!

Vaas, Joseph Seed, Castilloâ€¦ They are so charismatic that FOR THEM, you play the game. And the last one is so cool that many were willing to pay up to 70 bucks for zoomer crap just to meet him.

Now, what about the bleached blond guy? What can you remember about him?

Disclaimer: we're going to lay down the facts about Far Cry. It might get stuffy for the kids and the challenged ones. It's better to open a window for some fresh air right away.

ALL Ubisoft games of the last 10 years are built on one concept.

    They introduce you to your friends, show the enemy, show why he's bad.
    Then they throw you into a pit called "Endless mini-missions in an open world to summon a boss."

If it were a fantasy or Souls game, I would say, "Well, it's an RPG, you have to level up."

But is Far Cry an RPG? For those who are not aware, RPG implies a tabletop role-playing game, or as they say colloquially, a tabletop! If anyone's interested, go to YouTube and watch the evolution of RPG games.
And, of course, RPG doesn't just imply character leveling up, but a gradual advantage that you can gain through mini-duels, which will give you an edge by the end of the game!
Example? Any part of tabletop games where you can level up and break the face of another boss with one blow.
Correct, this is done for the serfs who heard the word RPG in the Dota chat one day. The second time when they were yelled at in Minecraft. And a day later, they went to Google to see what your RPG is, went to Steam, found Far Cry, and bought it on torrent trackers.

In other words, with this little flaw, the developers lowered the entry threshold (into your mom).

Now, what about Far Cry? Here RPG is for the sake of RPG, and missions for the sake of running time. Because of the impotence of the writers or laziness? - a rhetorical question.
Go milk cows or collect manure to accumulate the required amount of reputation points to summon a boss. This stupid RPG is what we deserved. Hello Dying Light 2 and goose presentations.
"This is an RPG!" one of the readers of this review will caw. No, this is not an RPG, - I will answer.

An acceptable example of RPG NOT in a tabletop game is Cyberpunk 2077.

In general (by the way, go to hell all those who suddenly started saying "in general and as a whole" because of the son of a prostitute from what was next)... Here... in general, the marketing department and executive directors of Ubisoft are just geniuses who changed the whole industry. They took the concept of Blacklist and turned it into garbage, and even added an RPG tag.

Now again, for the gifted. Ubisoft took a game with a cat-poop scenario and stuffed it with mini-missions up to the top! And this gave them exactly a smooth surface for stamping games on it. Soon, from garage garbage collectors to other companies, everyone picked up this concept, and it became the canon for RPG games.
And you won't finish it! The game has an RPG tag, half the country doesn't even know that it's not the same as an MMO. And the other half is sure that character leveling equals a role-playing game, and screw the fact that there are no roles, and in the case of Far Cry, the protagonist is mute!

With such a "given," it's not surprising that Far Cry 4 became absolutely mediocre and faceless crap. And what carried this franchise on its shoulders, suddenly turned out that besides the clay "bow" and one hundred percent botoxed boobs, it couldn't offer anything else.

While this game is fun at times, it is the last of the decent ubisoft games that have some resemblance of reasonable gameplay. But this game has poor design choices all around. The hit detection is awful, you constantly get bombarded with too many enemies that snipe you with a pistol from 100 meters away and drain 5/6 of your health instantly. The story is poor at best and the acting is bland with the only good character here being the main antagonist. Some of the choices in the game are interesting but have no weight or significant impact. The crafting system is tedious and required for gearing up late game. Some of the games mechanics are fun, such as the wing suit and the glider. When they work properly, they are a blast and exciting way to travel. Co-op is very basic but enjoyable. Combat battles between twitch shooter and slower paced realism which can be annoying but has an addictive 30 second loop of game play. While this isn't the best far cry game, its certainly not the worst either. It just misses the mark and could be better than the sum of its parts. 5.6/10

reskinned far cry 3. same weapon models, same animations, same recycled open world gameplay with an unnecessary amount of outposts/bell towers to capture and repetitive side missions.

you play as ajay ghale, a kid who came to nepal to set his mother's ashes free and somehow gets stuck in the middle of a battle to end a dictatorship. the funny part is, mr. ajay here is an absolute beast at killing both humans and animals alike and does it better than anyone else while having no actual reason to be as skillful and fearless as he is. you just start good, there is no sense of progression, character development nor motivation to help end the war. i mean, sure, the north (where you'd want to set the ashes free) is blocked by the army and you are "the son of the great man who started the revolution", but is this seriously all the motivation the story has to offer? having your main character live in the shadow of their father? 

the game throws 2 dimensional characters in your face multiple times and expects you to give a shit about any of them while forcing you to make nonsensical choices - my favorite being having to pick between 2 characters who 1) want to burn an opium field to stop the distribution of drugs or 2) instead recapture it and use the drugs to fund their war. i chose to burn the opium fields and one of the characters slaps me with a "why did you burn the fields??? we could have used the opium for medicinal purposes!!!!"

then why not just tell me you wanted to use the opium for medicinal uses? why hide this information? your whole argument was using the opium for drug use, not to help people, and now you're trying to be all self righteous when i chose to burn it all.

the whole game is filled with stupid little choices like these that are supposed to make you question your actions but they only make you question the reason you are playing it.

combat is boring, frustrating and unispired. enemies are spongey, never miss their shots and can hit you behind objects or trees most of the time.

i came into this game with high expectations because of how well everybody talks about it but i just don't see it. had a very frustrating time with it and at this point i'm dragging my feet to just end the story.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This game helped me realize that.

Here's my honest review on Far cry 4.
I'll be covering how much this game means to me as well as how it performs with max graphics and what it has to offer along with it's gameplay, story, and dlc.

Graphics.

I was blown away with the difference of graphics with this game compared to the console version of this game, I had my 4070ti running a smooth frame rate of 160-170fps as the average. I believe that it wouldn't have dropped have dropped any lower than that. The graphics during cutscenes felt as if I was watching a film from my monitor (1440p + 170hz) regardless of cutscenes, the game didn't fail to wow me from the attention to detail as you journey your way through Kyrat. For a game almost 10 years old, it was amazing to experience it all. Please notice that this game shows its age. However. When I mention how great these graphics are, they're more than acceptable for anyone.

I never experienced any issues with my time during the game in terms of graphics.

Graphics: 8.3 
Reason: Performs great with no issues with amazing detail, however shows its age with the surroundings and textures such as trees, ground, buildings and hills, etc.

Gameplay.

The gunplay in this game was quite fun, I'd say that its easily enjoyable for the average individual player. I always enjoy the satisfaction of liberating the several outposts along the map and playing through missions with an addiction of taking down my enemies with a suppressed sniper capable to penetrate the dome of your enemies with a simple bullet. Odd? no. FUN. If you loves guns then you may find this game fun to play with the many guns available to you to claim in YOUR hands. Not a fan of guns, choom? not a problem!

Perform takedowns upon your enemies and murder them as the savage you are that we never question in some ways. The possibilities are endless wether its takedowns from ledges, maybe using grenades to combine within your takedown would be your cup of tea! No? WELL MY FRIEND. This game features a GUN TAKEDOWN. Allow me to explain. Performing a takedown on your foes to where you grab their sidearm and dump a mag with their pistol on their comrades. PURELY satisfying.

The driving is meh, I wont say much since I barely ever drive in this game. I find it boring but to be fair this is a 2014 game. The driving is limited with its vehicles and it bores me.

Oh and the game includes grappling which I find incredibly fun.

Gameplay: 7.3 
Reason: Wasn't much to say and this game was very similar with Far Cry 3 in some of the skills and weapons and the driving is the worst part of this game in my opinion.

Story and DLC.

I probably won't say much here since it's quite late at the time of this review however I must say that the main story is an absolute thrill to play through as you are playing through the perspective of Ajay Ghale, a man who comes to Kyrat to find Lakshmana and spread your mother's ashes. You are thrown in Kyrat as it's under a battle of war which you assist with whilst attempting to reach Lakshmana. I personally found myself getting side tracked with the open world as well as doing quests to unlock skill points and hunting animals to upgrade my gear. All to improve my character and preference of experience, it happens to the best of us lol.

The dlc was short for me, this was mainly because of how many times I've replayed the story several times many years ago, in other words I knew what to expect and how to handle situations along with a simple and easy grind. Do I recommend this DLC? yes. It opens a new area to the player along with a new style of environment and enemies which I won't spoil.

Story and DLC: 7.1
Reason: This may be biased towards how I feel but the story may feel incredibly short when you are primarily focusing on it, yes it's fun but after replaying this game several times on console only to finish it once more on pc, the experience isn't the same rather than others so there is my honest review on FC4.

I can't give this game an overall exact rating on my behalf due to how I'm currently rushing this review, however I'll say that this game is around the rating of 7.0-7.6.

Thanks for reading my honest review and apologies on my rushed response on this review. 

As always. BUY THIS GAME DURING A SALE. It definitely isn't worth paying full price for what it has to offer, I'm sure you could find other games.

Anyway. Enjoy your time, Reader. G'day!

MF CLASSIC part 2

Story:
One of Far Cry 4's standout features is its captivating storyline. The game immerses you in a politically charged and morally complex tale, offering choices that influence the narrative's direction. The characters are well-written, and the conflict between the rebel Golden Path and the oppressive King Pagan Min adds depth to the game world.

Gameplay:
Here's where Far Cry 4 stumbles a bit. While the game retains the open-world exploration and combat that the series is known for, it occasionally falls into monotony. Some of the missions and activities can feel repetitive and lack the spark that the story provides. The abundance of collectibles and side missions, while offering depth, can sometimes lead to a sense of sameness.

Graphics and Sound:
Far Cry 4 excels in the visual department. The game's portrayal of the Himalayan landscape is breathtaking, and the attention to detail is commendable. The sound design complements the visuals, further immersing players in the game's world.

Conclusion:
Far Cry 4 is a mixed bag. The compelling storyline and intriguing characters make it worth experiencing, especially if you enjoy narrative-driven games. However, the gameplay, while not terrible, can become boring due to repetition and a lack of innovation in certain aspects. Despite this, it's a journey worth taking for the gripping narrative and the beautiful world of Kyrat.

I started playing this game for free on Goggle Stadia back when it existed, liked the game so much, I believe this was my first Steam purchase. I enjoyed it a lot, especially when you get started in the first part of the map near Banapur. The gameplay barring a few bugs is very smooth, and I love the story, mostly because all the Kyrati NPC's dialogues are in my language (Hindi) which is amazing as I had never played any game with Hindi dialogue before and a protagonist named Ajay and there's a lot of funny interactions. One of the things that drew me into this game is how immersive it can get, for example when you do a mission you gain Karma and based on that the NPC's will start becoming friendlier with you and you get access to new dialogue etc. The first few missions made me feel like a true part of Golden Path, helping their fight against Pagan. "Kyrat is free !" lives rent free in my head lol. The biggest issue I faced though is how boring & repetitive the game gets after the finishing the first section of the map, every other map section is basically the same with the same types of side missions which end up feeling like a chore, the core missions are great but I ended up finishing the main story line before I even explored the last section of the map, and once that was done I am only going through the side remaining side quests cause I don't like to leave a game unfinished. Also I feel some of the ongoing parallel storylines don't get resolved properly, for example I was expecting a final confrontation with The Goat, especially cause he was leaving messages behind for Ajay, same thing with Mr. Chiffon  just disappearing after spending all this time getting those animal hides. Overall it's a good game that I would recommend people get, if nothing else then just for the Pagan Min cutscenes alone, the voice actor killed it. But wait until it's on sale.

Pros:
- combat wise it's more of Far Cry 3, just better
- A large arsenal of weapons to choose from
- Fun and challenging outposts with the ability to replay them if you want
- Traversing the map is fun an offers so much choice
- There's a ton of stuff to do if you care to do it all
- Having a grenade launcher as a sidearm

Cons:
- The story. it's just not that interesting, and [spoiler] everyone just turns out to be awful except for Pagan.[/spoiler]
- The missions with the two dope heads (can't even remember their names) are probably meant to be trippy and interesting, but they just come off as running simulators.
- Basically, all of the main missions aren't really all that fun.
- The platforming can be inconsistent at times. Especially in the bell towers or when dropping from what seems like a very short distance.

IMO this game is at it's best when you try to play it stealthily. I also personally found it more fun to go treasure hunting or blowing up enemy vehicles with my grenade launcher as I pass them on the road than do any of the main missions. Kirat is a beautiful world to run around in and is one of the few exceptions to the many emptier open worlds. It's just a shame that the story doesn't follow the same golden path. Not worth replaying to find out what you missed out on. Make your decisions and watch YouTube to see what could have been.

Far Cry 4, released in 2014, offers players a thrilling open-world experience set in the fictional Himalayan nation of Kyrat. The game boasts stunning visuals, with lush landscapes and detailed character designs that immerse players in its richly crafted world. The storyline, centered around a civil war and a ruthless dictator, adds depth to the gameplay, though it occasionally lacks the emotional resonance of its predecessor.

Gameplay is a highlight, featuring a vast open world ripe for exploration, a variety of vehicles, and a wide array of weapons to choose from. The game introduces the verticality of its mountainous setting, which enhances both combat and traversal. Additionally, the inclusion of wildlife adds unpredictability to encounters, as dangerous animals can suddenly disrupt your plans.

One drawback is a repetitive mission structure, which can make the game feel a bit formulaic over time. However, the wealth of side activities, including hunting and outpost liberations, offers plenty of opportunities for diversions. Overall, Far Cry 4 delivers an engaging open-world experience with a captivating setting and satisfying gameplay.

This is one of my favourite games of all time, I have gotten 100% about 3 times (on other platforms) and although it's not perfect, it really doesn't get enough credit for the details and depth it does have. Aside from pretty graphics and landscapes, If you pay attention to some NPCs you'll often find that they move and interact with the world like a normal person. one of my favourite things is finding an NPC with a broken down car, and being able to fix for them, and seeing them actually get in the car and drive away, after thanking you, of course. 

This also applies to animals as Sometimes in the wilderness you'll find two animals fighting it out, or you'll see an eagle grab a small pig and carry it away. 

While this game doesn't have the detail and depth of Red Dead Redemption 2, for example, the world feels more alive than people give it credit for, and with a decent amount of lore and a solid storyline, I highly recommended experiencing Kyrat at least once in your life.

As for gameplay...it's genuinely fun, and you'll probably spend hours trying to stealth outposts or fortresses in the most bad ass way you can. Gunplay is solid, the enemy AI is decent, and there is enough side content to keep you invested for a while, although that aspect can get repetitive. 

the last point I need to make is that there are bugs, and while some are hilarious, there are others that can get frustrating, but this is entirely subjective. I've played through this game a total of 4 different times across multiple platforms, and 3 out of 4 play-throughs were relatively polished experiences.

Overall, I highly recommended this game, especially on sale!

Far Cry 4 takes gamers on an adrenaline-pumping journey to the breathtaking and treacherous mountains of the Himalayas, and it's a wild ride that delivers on many fronts.

First and foremost, the game's open-world setting is nothing short of stunning. The fictional country of Kyrat is a visually captivating blend of lush forests, snowy peaks, and vibrant villages. The attention to detail in creating this world is commendable, and it offers a truly immersive experience.

The gameplay is where Far Cry 4 truly shines. The freedom it provides is exhilarating, allowing players to approach missions and objectives in a multitude of ways. Whether you prefer stealthy takedowns, explosive mayhem, or utilizing the game's extensive arsenal of weapons, Far Cry 4 caters to your playstyle. The introduction of the gyrocopter and grappling hook adds new dimensions to exploration and combat, making the game even more enjoyable.

The game's antagonist, Pagan Min, is a charismatic and memorable character, brilliantly portrayed by Troy Baker. His unpredictable nature keeps players engaged in the story, and the moral dilemmas presented throughout the game add depth to the narrative.

Far Cry 4 also excels in its variety of side activities, from liberating outposts to hunting exotic animals, all of which contribute to character progression. The co-op mode is a blast, allowing you to wreak havoc with a friend in the open world, adding a social dimension to the chaos.

However, the game does have some minor drawbacks. The story, while engaging, may feel less memorable than its predecessor, Far Cry 3. Additionally, some players may find the pacing a bit uneven at times.

Overall, Far Cry 4 is a thrilling and visually stunning open-world experience that successfully builds upon the strengths of its predecessor. It offers a vast playground for exploration and destruction, with a compelling antagonist and a diverse range of activities to keep you entertained for hours on end. If you're a fan of the open-world FPS genre, Far Cry 4 is well worth a playthrough.

An Exhilarating Himalayan Adventure!

Far Cry 4 is an absolute gem in the open-world shooter genre. Ubisoft has once again delivered a breathtaking world to explore, this time in the Himalayas, and it's nothing short of spectacular.

The game's protagonist, Ajay Ghale, finds himself in the midst of a civil war in the fictional country of Kyrat, and the storytelling is engaging from start to finish. The character of Pagan Min is a standout, a charismatic yet unpredictable villain that keeps you on your toes.

The gameplay is where Far Cry 4 truly shines. The vast open world is teeming with wildlife and activities, and it's a blast to take on outposts stealthily or go in guns blazing. The addition of the gyrocopter and the grappling hook adds a new dimension to exploration and combat.

Graphically, the game is stunning. The attention to detail in the environment is top-notch, from the snow-covered mountains to the lush forests. And the use of color in the game, especially the vibrant reds and blues, creates a visual feast.

Co-op mode is a blast, allowing you to team up with a friend to tackle missions and wreak havoc together. It adds a new layer of fun to an already fantastic game.

My only minor gripe is with the occasional technical glitch, but they were far from game-breaking and didn't detract from my overall enjoyment.

In summary, Far Cry 4 is a must-play for fans of the series and anyone looking for an immersive open-world experience. It's a thrilling adventure that will keep you hooked from the first shot to the last.

This is such an interesting game to review.

One part is being the new game in the franchise.
The other, its almost similar to previous entry, only with different world and story.

First, i'm gonna talk about the negative thing from this game and then work our way up :
- ONLY ONE SAVE SLOT, Like, Why? Far Cry 3 has 4 save slot if i remember correctly, and this game has different ending too. I mean, you can backup the save before playing
new game for different ending. But it obviously so much better if there is more than one slot.
- Unskippable cutscenes. Again. Why? It should be common option to have choice to skip cutscene.
- It plays too similar to far cry 3, for example like outpost, tower, gunplay, skinning animal sounds similar, the stealth also similar. I don't really mind with this,
as long as it still fun, but for some people, it can be pretty stale.
- Comparing to far cry 3, the story is pretty weak here in my opinion, the motive just doesn't make sense. And there is no character development. You're just getting
stronger and thats it. 
- The mission can be a bit dragging at some part, by just pouring more and more enemies.
- Bugs still exist and some can be annoying. One of them is a location can't be explored and has to be exploited to get there. And i encounter some unnecessary death.
- Crash also still happen, but only when i do shangri-la mission, which really annoying, because if you crash, you gonna start from the beginning of the mission, instead of checkpoint.
- The enemies can also be annoying, like some enemies can shot gun very rapidly and drain your health so quickly even on normal.
- I don't know about the multiplayer or co-op, but i heard it doesn't work anymore. So thats bad.

The Positive : 
- The main villain is always key role in far cry games. And this one isn't disappointing. The charm and vibe is so much calmer than far cry 3, but still intimidating at some point. 
Probably one of my favorite character in video games. It voice by troy baker, which already one of the most iconic video game voice actor, and he did so well in this one.
- The World is beautiful and stunning. I like the settings in this game. I just wish we can fully explore the snowy mountain part more and it become permanent place instead of just there for certain mission.
- More sandbox than previous game, even tho i said its almost similar to far cry 3, gunplay still fun.

With the exception of a few minor changes to the plot and setting, "Far Cry 4 (2014)" largely uses the same gameplay systems as its direct predecessor. Those two factors are fairly major in setting it apart, though. This time, the thing loses all pretences of being a satirical look at the complicity in violence of its player-base, instead focusing on delivering a relatively nuanced story with more straightforward narrative theming. It also removes the 'white saviour' aspect of prior titles by having its protagonist return to the place of his birth at the start of the game. Of course, he gets caught up in a civil war, participating in bringing down a local regime simply to find some personal closure. The thing does a great job of tying these two aspects together, especially as it reaches its conclusion. It also features branching mission paths that don't change the overarching story so much as emphasise the 'give and take' aspects of each route. For example, whether you blow up a drugs farm or reclaim it - a choice between morals and money - will have ramifications for the next generation far after your time here is over. Obviously, the game and its world don't continue when you turn off your console, but they almost feel like they do; the choices you make may not have all that much impact - they don't affect the gameplay, for instance - but they still feel important. The game itself consists of clearing out bases, climbing up towers, finding hidden caches, hunting to make equipment, delivering arms to resistance fighters and working your way through the story, ultimately aiming towards a clear goal outlined at the very start of the campaign. It's highly enjoyable and doesn't get dull. The ending is actually satisfying, too. (I got the worst one) Overall, this is probably the best game in the series. 8/10

even if the story isn't the best, you can't complain about FarCry4. The game aside from the story is a lot of fun and has a lot of creative approaches. After all, it's an open world game that gives you whole side missions and freedom over the possibilities.

Of course there are other downsides besides the story, such as shooting. The weapon physics are weirdly created in FarCry4. the AK47 does not fire at its target and it is not an isolated case. *But you notice it quickly with her, because it's one of the first weapons in the game* Generally, all auto weapons are so poor in accuracy, even though you only fire single bullets. Semi auto guns, pistols and shotguns have been made better since then.

Another thing that bothered me was the enemy spawn probability. If you destroy a convoy, the next one comes after about 15 seconds. this restricts the calmness of the game a bit, but fortunately there is almost travel for that.

I would say that you should give the game a chance and that you should focus more on the positive sides, such as the graphics or the quiet approach to missions and outposts.
