As an avid gamer, I recently had the pleasure of immersing myself in the captivating world of Far Cry 4, and I must say, it was an extraordinary experience from start to finish! Ubisoft has truly outdone themselves with this installment of the beloved Far Cry series, delivering a game that combines heart-pounding action, stunning visuals, and a richly diverse open-world environment.

One of the most impressive aspects of Far Cry 4 is the breathtaking landscape of Kyrat. The lush, Himalayan-inspired setting provides players with a vast and visually mesmerizing playground. From towering snow-capped mountains to dense forests and picturesque valleys, every corner of Kyrat is a sight to behold. The attention to detail is remarkable, making exploration a sheer delight as I found myself constantly getting lost in the beauty of the world around me.

The narrative of Far Cry 4 is equally compelling, as it takes players on a roller-coaster journey through political intrigue, rebellion, and personal discovery. The complex characters, particularly the enigmatic Pagan Min, add depth to the storyline, leaving players emotionally invested in the outcome. The freedom to approach missions in multiple ways also enhances the game's replayability, ensuring that each playthrough feels unique and personal.

Gameplay mechanics are fluid and polished, making combat encounters feel natural and satisfying. Whether it's engaging in intense shootouts or employing stealth to take down enemies one by one, Far Cry 4 offers a wide range of options to suit any playstyle. The introduction of a vast array of weapons and tools adds spice to the action, allowing players to experiment and adapt their tactics to different situations.

Moreover, the game features a wealth of side activities and collectibles, which kept me constantly entertained between main missions. Hunting exotic wildlife, liberating outposts, and participating in thrilling races and challenges added depth to my adventure, offering countless hours of enjoyable content beyond the main storyline.

Let's not forget the delightful co-op mode, which allowed me to team up with a friend and embark on unforgettable adventures together. The seamless integration of co-op into the single-player experience made for an even more engaging and memorable time.

Lastly, I must commend the game's impeccable sound design and a phenomenal musical score that heightened the overall immersion. The subtle sounds of wildlife, the echoes of gunfire across the mountains, and the stirring soundtrack all contributed to making Far Cry 4 an audiovisual masterpiece.

In conclusion, Far Cry 4 is an exceptional gaming experience that excels in every aspect. With its captivating world, engaging storyline, diverse gameplay, and impressive multiplayer options, it's a must-play for any gamer seeking an enthralling and immersive adventure. Ubisoft has truly raised the bar with this installment, and I can't wait to see where they take us next in the Far Cry universe!

KILL KILL KILL I HOPE GHALE DIES KILL HIM KILL HIS STEP-FATHER TOO KILL HIM!!! I HATE THEM I HOPE THEY BOTH GET STUCK IN A CAVE AND DIE. I HOPE THEY BOTH GET TO RELIVE THEIR WORST MOMENTS IN THEIR LIVES. GOD I HATE THEM

Anyway, this is a fantastic game with a great story, a breautiful atmosphere and generally beautiful graphics. I could not recommend it enough, even though I may be biased since this is my special interest ^^' I Think the thing that stands as one of the strongest points in the story of this game is Pagan Min and Ajay Ghale's relationship, especially since we get to see the relationship through the eyes of Mr. Ghale ourselves. I love how Ajay never got the hints Pagan gave him that they were semi-related, for example, Pagan refering to himself as Uncle infront of Ajay, talking in a fatherly manner towards him every time they talk, sometimes going to the point of trying to save his life too, etc.

 Even in the "Escape From Durgesh Prison" DLC, Pagan refers to himself as "Daddy" infront of Ajay two times, (and perhaps even more times that I have not counted,) yet Ajay still doesn't pick his hidden message up. He is so stupid and that's why I love him so much. (Platonically!!)

Ajay and Pagan's dynamic is just so interesting in general. We have the step-son, who literally is trying to kill his step-father, and the step-father who loves his step-son and thinks that all of what is happening is a game and not really that serious. That is at least what I interpret from their interactions... But that is why I love their dynamic. To summerize it, I usually just say "Son hates father, father loves son." And I think that this type of dynamic is kind of hard to find, which is why I might like it so much. They are just!! So special to me!!! And they are a big part of the reason I still play this game. The other parts are just as awesome though.

As I've said before, this game is STUNNING. The graphics are actually fantastic for a game made in 2014, and the entirety of the map is a pleasure to walk and ride through, however I don't think this would have been possible if the developers had not gone to Nepal to get research on how the landscape, buildings and civilzations looked like. You can tell they put a lot of effort into trying to get everything right to it's respective original source, and I sincerely hope they got everything right. All I know is that Kyrat and it's people are beautiful and amazing.

The contrast between the fantastic landscapes and horrific gunshots everywhere is definitely noticable though, and I think it's certainly interesting how they chose to portray war here. If you didn't already know, the war between Pagan and the Golden Path is inspired by the Nepalese Civil War. It was a tragic time period in the history of Nepal I can imagine. <:( I will not go over it here though since I do not have much knowledge about the topic. 

Even though this is a Far Cry game we're talking about, it's still nice that they tried to include some serious moments. War is serious, and I do not think it would look good for them if they made war look like it was all fun and games.

But the characters.... Ooohh the characters... I love how they are all different and distinct from each other, like in terms of appearance, personality, etc. The backstories for each important character are so well written I think, though a bit obscure sometimes. The character designs are top notch though, and you can see that many of the important character outfits are impacted by their wearers respective culture(s). Even the NPCs have culturally impacted clothes and accessories on, which is really cool! There are ethnic features on every character as well, which is really nice to see. :)  But talking about the story again, I do think Ubisoft could have at least given people like Noore, Paul and Yuma more screen time, as well as some of the side characters like Rabi Ray Ranna, Mumu Chiffon and Longinus some more attention as well. They are all lovely and loveable characters, but the fact that they have so little screen time makes them more forgettable, sadly :(( And don't even get me started on Pagan. God I wish he had more screen time, both cutscene wise and radio call wise. I loved seeing and hearing Pagan and Ajay interact, specifically because Pagan was probably the most well-written character in the game. No but everyone in the game did such a fantastic job with their voice acting, and motion capture as well! And even though many players like to hate on Ajay, mostly because of his vocal absence in the main game, he does actually speak from time to time. If you go through the side quests, you can see that he really has quite the personality! ^^ He apparently likes taking risks, and seems more humble than Jason from Far Cry 3. You can see that a lot through out the story, but a great example is also when he laughed for the first and only time in the entire game. He accidentally laughed at a man's story about his wife getting eaten alive by Honey badgers, thinking it was a joke. In the end though, he realized it was a real story, and quickly apologised. You could physically hear him feeling bad, and that is also why I think James A. Wood, Ajay Ghale's voice actor, should get more credit for his work here. He is a fantastic voice actor, just like everyone else in the game, and he did an amazing job giving Ajay more personality when he finally did speak in the game. Thank you James A. Wood, your performance won't be forgotten.

But anyways, enough rambling from me, thank you for reading! Would definitely recommend buying this game, it's especially fun with friends. Still hate Ajay though I hope he and Pagan dies. Right now. Ubisoft please

Far Cry 4 was such a good game that took so many risky chances. 

Having a non-white protagonist in a Nepal inspired country, setting up multiple endings where none of them can be considered clear-cut good, tackling so many social issues in a less cartoony way compared to Far Cry 3... I think playing this game is a great experience that still holds up today.

Tried replaying FC 3 lately and really gave up due to how old the gameplay feels, but this one feels smooth even after several iterations of the game. 

It's curious that in Far Cry 6 they also went back to the idea of leading a guerilla insurrection against a dictator, but instead of having you choose the paths taken by the guerilla and shaping the future of the country in the process, it just gives you a (good but) linear story where you can really only have one experience. 

Wish they would go back to trying what they did with FC 4. Give you options to shape the country according to whose vision you associate with the most. Address the gray areas of a revolution. Make you have more of an impact in the story.

What I liked
1. Great open world and graphics
2. Elephants
3. Conquering the outposts and other similar quests are very fun
4. The gunplay feels good, especially with the better weapons
5. Humorous dialogues and monologues  

What I didn't like
1. On the missions where you choose which leader you are going to support, the voice acting is off
2. Checkpoints could be better in some quests
3. I found the driving quests to be boring, irritating and out of place and the driving in general felt a little off
4. The "radio show" monologues, although funny, were very repetitive
5. Some irritating and illogical criteria to complete some quests, as well as illogical behavior from the npcs. Why should I use a particular type of gun to kill the commanders? And why are the guard's first priority to shoot at the hostages instead of me, when I'm obviously shooting at them.
6. "Shangri-la" and any other drug/dreamy related quest was by far the biggest con of the game. Fortunately, only a couple of those are forced. Still, I didn't spend my time looting to buy the best weapons, just to fight the boss in a drug-induced dream sequence with a magical arrow. If I wanted that, I would play assassin's creed origins again.  
7. The endings are badly written and the characters are not well developed. The whole "choice and consequence" theme was not well done - it felt like your actions didn't and couldn't have any significant impact. 
8. The music was unimpressive
9. Unskippable scripted scenes


Summary
I have played far cry 1 and 2 and watched extended reviews and gameplay of far cry 5 and 6.
I did not like any of them, so Far cry 4 is the first game of this series I like. 
Personally I prefer tactical/team shooters because they are more realistic, thus more immersive for me. In this case, even though it's not a tactical shooter and I did not like the how the "choices and consequences" theme was handled, the open world, the gunplay, the humor and most of the quests were more than enough to keep me entertained. 
It was a very fun game to play. If you like the "one-man-army FPS" genre, then you will most probably like this one.

So my boyfriend and I have gone back and forth on whether I should buy this game for an actual year. He said yes, I said nah. I was a moron just fyi... So I got it on the Summer sale and my Lord. I loved it!! For reference, Fallout was my ride or die, but now I'm feeling like a divorce might be in order. It's small things like character stories, the mini map that helps you work out a route to get to where you have to be, Fashion Week, yes Fashion Week! Gun skins, all sorts of vehicles, everything wrapped up into Far Cry 4. I love this game and I wish that more devs would look at small convenient ways to make my life easier and more creative, like Fashion Week!! I'm serious ya'll, it's a ride and you will be getting something out of it!

Now for the critique, so I would have liked a story with a bit more oomph if that makes sense. Beware, there might be spoilers ahead. Sabal and Amita are lovely but in the end I hated both of them and fell head over heels for King Min. Now others might disagree with me here and that's actually a good thing since we're all gonna have our own experiences with this game! But to me personally, I would have liked an option where I did something that actually felt like the right decision to make. So without giving too much away, both Amita and Sabal are fighting for a Fucked up overall vision. Keep in mind that I did extra reading on both Amita and Sabal and what they're actually fighting for. I did not want to fight for either of them. I would have liked if there were an option to fight for a country free from them both. Now I know that this is not always possible, but it would have been nice. But this is just my opinion and you might love the story so don't think too much of it and go play it to figure it out for yourself!

The beginning is hard in terms of staying alive, finding your gun bestie and figuring out what everything is, just keep playing and I promise you it will get better!

If you enjoyed Far Cry 3 you're gonna enjoy this one as well. The gameplay was extended new features were added like grappling hook, revised hunting (no more hunting deers with a RPG-7) etc.. Graphics wise the game still looks beautiful after all these years, it aged well.

The story might seem basic at first but if you notice the red flags througout the game you're gonna realize who the real villan is. I disliked the story at first, felt a bit boring but after the my recent playthrough I found the story to be good along with the characters. Although there are some annoying, the game would-be-better-without-them characters. Also if you want to learn more about the background lore I recommend to collect Mohan's diaries as they greatly expand the story.

--------Word of warning!-------------------------------------------------------
Don't open the map editor. It's going to break your game, you won't be able to launch it afterwards. It is a major issue that Ubisoft never bothered to fix or even tell us. It's going to break the .reg file for Far Cry 4 which is going to cause the game to close every time you open it, making it unplayable, and a simple un and re-install is not going to fix it.

But good news that there is a fix for it. You can download the fix through this link: https://steve.farcry.eu/files/FC4_Steam_StartupFix.zip

Despite this issue I still recommend to buy Far Cry 4. It is an overlooked entry and it only went downhill after this game. As for the DLC, Valley of the Yetis I can recommend but the rest are pretty meh.

Far Cry 1 & 2 focused on a hero that had military training. So, it made sense they were a "one man army". But, for some reason, with Far Cry 3+ they went all "extreme tourism". It feels meta, like you're a rich person that paid West World for some "X-treme adventure holiday!" package that lets you go around living out your fantasy of being an extreme super soldier / hiker / adventurer.

"Would you like the 'white savior' sub-plot for an additional $1000 credits, Mr. Quaid?"
"Sure, why not."
"How do you like your women, Mr. Quaid?"
"Sassy. Domineering. Like I have to prove something to them while they don't have to prove anything to me. (getting sleepy) But, I also want to be their alpha male."

(I know, I'm mixing West World and Total Recall analogies together. It's a hodge-podge, just like this game.)

The heroes in 3 & 4 have no indication of military training. But, they are instant experts in anything they pick up that shoots of blows stuff up. Meanwhile, you're going up against enemies that have supposedly had some military training. But, they're easily slaughtered, and no match for a person that has no skill or background in soldiering.

The games play this off as "oh, you're just a natural! A natural soldier! A natural killer!"

Again, feels like what a rich person would want to hear during their West World fantasy vacation.

And what's with all the "savior complex" all of a sudden?

Far Cry 1 had you stopping some mad scientist. Not the most original plot. But, oh well.

Far Cry 2+ are all about you being the "chosen one" that's railroaded into saving some oppressed people from an oppressor. All their armies and guerrilla tactics couldn't overthrow their oppressors. But, you, some rando that comes along, will "one man army" them to victory. It was entertaining in Far Cry 2. It was delirious but passable in Far Cry 3 as a "rich boy's" fantasy. But, by the time we get to it being repeated in Far Cry 4, it's wearing thin.

If you haven't noticed, my biggest aggravation is the repetitiousness of it all. There's little innovation from Far Cry 3 to Far Cry 4.

They reused a lot of animations (eg: climbing, searching bodies, etc).
They reused a lot of weapons.
The enemies look darn-near the same as Far Cry 3 (red clothes and all).
There's a nut-job Vas replacement, but not as entertaining.

The graphics are the same, yet have some how gotten a little worse. Maybe it's because Far Cry 3 was in a lush jungle environment that had colors that popped while Far Cry 4 is in the mountains with more drab colors. But, it feels like they got rid of fresnel lighting that was helping add "body" to things when seen at an extreme angle. Feels like the specular lighting is... odd. I can't quite put my finger on it. But, it's not as nice-looking at Far Cry 3 even when cranked to Ultra settings.

They included some Nvidia-only settings like soft shadows, enhanced god rays, etc. I have an Nvidia 2040 super, and when I tried the Nvidia-only awesome settings.. they didn't work. They disabled the feature that was supposed to work. So, I had to turn it all back to regular settings.

So, with all this bagging on the game, why do I recommend it?

Because, like other Far Cry games, it's a "summer popcorn movie" / switch your brain off game.

I come home from a long day at work, and I just want to switch my brain off and go shoot things in the face. Far Cry 4 accomplishes that. The familiarity of it from Far Cry 3 means I was able to get into it easier without much learning curve. The bog-standard "kill this, collect this, etc" busy work that dots the landscape can be ignored or engaged with as you see fit. The game is filled with "hundreds of hours of game play!" but most of it is repetitious scavenger hunts or respawnable "kill this convoy, kill this messenger" junk. You can knee-jerk react to it and go do it on a whim, or just ignore it and go find something else to do. The game world is your sandbox play ground.

I just wish they had innovated a bit more rather than produce what essentially looks like a reskinned DLC for Far Cry 3.

Far Cry 4 is definitely more of a middle of the road game then a "good" or "bad", although i do lean a little positive on this. game play wise, it feels like almost every other far cry game, noticeably most similar to 3 (which i haven't played yet), gunplay, towers, annoying collectibles, the whole lot. Personally, I wasnt a big fan of the geography of Kyrat, it felt so copy paste all over, you could barely tell what corner of the map you were on without looking at the map, same goes for the villages. However, where Far Cry 4 makes up for all this is in its story, and the amount of culture makes this fictional country feel so REAL! Im not too familiar with Himalayan culture, so im not sure if they just utilised parts of their culture and ported it in, but either way it definitely aids the game. What kept me going was learning more about Kyrat culture, and the struggle between keeping old tradition vs new, a heavy theme in this game. The story, and more specifically Pagan Min, was such an interesting character to me, especially how he treats you throughout the game. He's clearly always aware of your actions, seeing you kill his people, his territory he stole, and at times even acknowledges it, but still has an odd form of caring for you. He doesn't even hide when he tries to manipulate you, he knows youre aware and plays with it, teasing you almost like old friends. id love to see more of pagan min, im definitely checking out his far cry 6 dlc when i get that game. overall, its an alright game, i wouldnt recommend it for more than Ten Dollars however, as, especially if youve played a ubisoft game before, itll feel a bit stale in terms of gameplay.

Title: A Hilarious Adventure with an Engaging Story - Far Cry 4

Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… (5/5)

Far Cry 4 is a remarkable open-world first-person shooter that effortlessly blends humor and a captivating narrative into an unforgettable gaming experience. With its witty dialogue, hilarious characters, and a compelling storyline, this game surpasses expectations and leaves players thoroughly entertained from start to finish.

One of the standout features of Far Cry 4 is its remarkable sense of humor. Right from the opening moments, the game embraces a light-hearted tone that permeates throughout the entire journey. From the quirky and eccentric characters to the absurd situations you encounter, the game never fails to elicit genuine laughter. Whether it's Pagan Min's flamboyant personality, the entertaining banter between allies, or the unexpected encounters with wildlife, Far Cry 4 masterfully infuses comedy into its gameplay, making it an absolute joy to play.

However, Far Cry 4 isn't just about humor; it boasts a strong and engaging story as well. Set in the fictional Himalayan region of Kyrat, the game revolves around Ajay Ghale, a young man returning to his homeland to fulfill his mother's final wishes. As Ajay becomes entangled in a deadly civil war between the eccentric dictator Pagan Min and the local rebel group, the Golden Path, players are thrust into a complex narrative filled with political intrigue, personal dilemmas, and moral choices.

The story in Far Cry 4 is expertly crafted, blending intense action with thought-provoking themes. The characters you encounter are multifaceted, with their own motivations, fears, and desires. The game's writers have done a commendable job of creating a narrative that keeps players engaged and invested, ensuring that every decision you make feels significant. The moral gray areas presented throughout the story provide an added layer of depth, challenging players to question their own beliefs and values.

In addition to its compelling narrative, Far Cry 4 offers a stunningly detailed open world to explore. From lush forests and towering mountains to bustling villages and ancient ruins, Kyrat feels alive and brimming with secrets waiting to be discovered. The gameplay mechanics, including stealth, gunplay, and the use of a vast array of vehicles, are finely tuned, allowing players to approach missions and challenges in various creative ways.

The visuals in Far Cry 4 are breathtaking, showcasing the beauty of the Himalayan landscape with impressive attention to detail. The game's sound design is equally impressive, with a dynamic soundtrack that enhances the immersive experience and ambient sound effects that bring the world to life.

In conclusion, Far Cry 4 is a true masterpiece, earning a perfect 5 out of 5 rating. Its seamless blend of humor and an engrossing storyline creates a gaming experience that is both entertaining and memorable. Whether you're a fan of the Far Cry series or new to the franchise, this game is an absolute must-play for anyone seeking an adventure filled with laughter and a captivating narrative.

It is not a bad game, but it is not a good game either. It is yet another open world fps game with some Far Cry vibes. Story is uninteresting, characters are boring, gunplay is mediocre and scenario is badly written. If you are a huge fan of the series, you might consider buying this on a sale.

Dive into Kyrat, a stunning atmospheric and gorgeous fictional place, in which you play Ajay, who fights with the rebel group 'Golden Path' against Dictator Pagan Min. 

While the story is very linear, one can chose between story paths and therefore who leads the golden path, ultimately resulting in two separate endings. Even though this is fun, I would not say this is a selling point of the game.

As mentioned in my opening sentence, it is rather the amazing visuals and locations which make this game so incredible. 

I have played the game to 100 % completion three times and have 200 hours in it, which shows that one can definitely fall in love with Kyrat and play this game multiple times, if one wishes to do so. However - and this is based upon my 200 hours in it - there definitely are quite some bugs in this game, but if you look passed this, you will have a great time.

If you are a fan of Single Player games, this one is for you. 

If you are more into co-op, Far Cry 4 only allows you to attempt outposts and other aspects but not the story, which in my opinion is very sad, but was luckily fixed in the future games of the series.

However, if you are a fan of the co-op mode, I highly recommend the DLC 'Valley of the Yetis', which I have played through three times, as it takes place in an entirely new location and with a short but sweet story and is lots of fun to play together.

If you look past Far Cry 4's story, its a very good game. The stealth is fun, the gun play is fun and you never feel out of action. But then we see its story, Ajay Ghale, a tourist from America, who just wants to bury the remains of his mother where she would of wanted. Instead goes on this insane trip to help a revolution that he had nothing to do with. But lets back it up, Jason comes across emperor Pagan Min, who claims to have known Ajay's mother. When Min offers the chance to help Ajay, Ajay instead goes on a murderous rampage. But why? He could of just took the offer, and if you think about it, is the best ending to Far Cry 4. But lets look at Amita and Sabal. The two leaders of the Golden Path. Both of which, are worse than Pagan Min. Amita wants to turn the country into a drug run economy, with cocaine in every household. But Sabal isn't any better, he wants to turn the Country of Kyrat back to it's traditional ways. The worst thing about this, Ajay just follows them both as a dog, he just does what they say. If you play Far Cry 4 just for fun, as you should. Its a very good game, it will have you wanting to play more when you are done. But when you see it for what it is, It shows you that you were fighting for the wrong side.

TL:DR: If you like action games, its a must buy. But make sure you have a CPU with good single core IPC performance (Ryzen 5 3600+, i5 12400F+), and disable Hyper-threading and E-cores.

This was my second Far Cry game I ever played, after Far Cry 3, so I might be a little biased. Also, ever since Far Cry 3, I think Ubisoft has created a trend where the protagonist actually works for the villain, and this is game is very much that.

The Story:

You play as Ajay Ghale, an American-Kyrati man, who served in the US Army with the 82nd Airborne Division, going back to his birthplace, Kyrat, to fulfill his mother's dying wish: "Take Me to Lakshmana", and gets tangled into a civil war started by The Golden Path, against the dictator Pagan Min. Now, Pagan knows Ajay Ghale, since both his parents were related to Golden Path, and Ishwari, Ajay's mother, was romantically entangled with Pagan, while working undercover for Mohan Ghale, Ajay's father. Golden Path's new leaders, Sabal and Amita, want Ajay's help to reunite Kyrat and gain Independence from Pagan's rule, through two very different idealogies. Sabal is a right-winger, Amita is a left-winger, and you decide the fate of Golden Path, by deciding who leads it (PS, both are idiots, although Amita is sexier). Within all this politics, Pagan Min regularly keeps contacting you to parle with him, but Ajay is dissillusioned, and is hell bent on killing Pagan for killing his father (who, later revealed, was also an idiot).

Pagan is an amazing character, the 3 other bosses, are also amazing characters and brilliantly acted out, especially Noore, who is possibly the most beautiful video game woman ever created, Yuma is hot, and De Pleur is downright terrifying. Amita and Sabal are terrible characters, and I hate them from the core of my heart. But Amita's "honey pot", due to her great looks, make her the better character. Plus. she does have a decent plan for furthering Kyrat's economy, although a bit dictator-ish like. Side characters like Yogi, or Longinus are.. fine, and have small little drug induced side quests that are very entertaining.

Agent Huntley makes a return, and provides with 3 action-packed missions that make you feel like James Bond, also low-key reiterating the mid-air plane hijacking sequence from GoldenEye, which GREAT!

Gameplay:

Its Far Cry 3.5, with all the Ubisoft tropes, towers, outposts, so many damn sidequests, and a skill tree progression system. New features include the ability to ride elephants, a mini-copter, and a grapple, that allows you to act like Lara Croft from Tomb Raider Anniversary, while you're killing fauna all around the map.

Graphics:

It looks AMAZING! Even pushing settings to High makes you realize, this game is a Looker! The performance is mid-tier, however, on modern systems. It appears to be Thread 3 bound, so I'd suggest using a super fast CPU, disabling E-cores, and disabling hyper-threading through Process Lasso, and hope to make it past 60 FPS. Even an i7 11800H, I was CPU-bound, and the game regularly dropped to 35-40 FPS. The only way to make it GPU bound was by pushing 4x MSAA on my RTX 3050, which makes no sense.
The same issues are present in most 2011-2015 Ubisoft games, including AC2/3/4, Far Cry 3/BD, and Watch Dogs etc, so you have been warned.

A solid 8/10 shooter overall.

Graphics: 9/10 - It looks great for a 2014 title. The setting and artistic direction makes for a very aesthetically pleasing experience. The mountains are gorgeous, The wildlife is rich and flavorful, the culture and religious figures are fascinating, and the drug induced scenes use colours beautifully to create a fantasy like experience.

Mechanics: 7/10 - The game doesn't really bring anything new or interesting to the table, it's just a standard shooter with standard shooter mechanics. That said it's well polished, glitch free (in my experience anyway) and what else can you really ask for? We don't always have to reinvent the wheel.

Story 8/10: Pagan Min is a great villain. There's an interesting complexity in his personality between flamboyant and menacing that makes for a memorable character. Ajay Ghale, the main character isn't himself as memorable but most of the other characters have strong personalities that have you wanting to know what happens next.

Update (4/5/2023):
A new update for the game was released, and unsurprisingly it broke the game for a lot of users, but thankfully someone found a fix.
I quote:
"One of the changes is removing the distribution.steam file from the game, for whatever reason this file is necessary.

To fix this, simply open notepad and click save as on an empty document, save it as distribution.steam with "All Files" selected for Save as Type.

Be sure to save it to C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Far Cry 4\bin or whatever your Far Cry 4 game's directory is.

Once the file is saved into the folder, the game should run normally again.

The .steam is the EXTENSION of the FILENAME: distribution

MAKE SURE to place the distribution.steam in the Far Cry 4 BIN Folder.

CREDIT: Saprinus from the AC Freedom Cry Forum"

FIX FOR ACTIVATION KEY PROMPT:
Open Notepad
Click "Save as" on a blank text file
Save it as "distribution.steam" (minus quotes) in C:/Program Files (x86)/SteamLibrary/steamapps/common/Far Cry 4/bin

If done correctly, the game should launch through Ubisoft as normal

Far Cry 4 is a first-person shooter game developed by Ubisoft Montreal and released in 2014. It is the fourth installment in the Far Cry series and takes place in the fictional country of Kyrat, which is based on the Himalayan region of Nepal. The game offers players an immersive experience in an open world filled with diverse environments, weapons, and characters.

One of the most notable aspects of Far Cry 4 is its stunning visuals. The game's environment is rich in detail, with beautiful landscapes, exotic wildlife, and intricate architecture. Whether you are exploring the mountains, the forests, or the cities, you will be immersed in the game's breathtaking scenery. The game's graphics are also well-optimized, allowing for a smooth and seamless gameplay experience.

The storyline in Far Cry 4 revolves around Ajay Ghale, a young man who returns to his homeland of Kyrat to spread his mother's ashes. However, he soon finds himself caught up in a civil war between the ruling King Pagan Min and the revolutionary Golden Path. The game offers players a range of choices in how they approach the conflict, with different endings depending on the player's decisions.

The gameplay in Far Cry 4 is engaging and addictive, with a wide variety of weapons, vehicles, and skills to choose from. The game offers players the ability to play stealthily or go in guns blazing, allowing for different playstyles and approaches to combat. The game's AI is also impressive, with enemies responding realistically to the player's actions and tactics.

In addition to the main storyline, Far Cry 4 offers players a range of side missions and activities to complete. These include hunting animals for their skins and crafting materials, liberating outposts from enemy control, and participating in races and other challenges. These activities add depth to the game and provide players with a sense of progression as they unlock new skills and weapons.

One of the most memorable aspects of Far Cry 4 is its villain, Pagan Min. The flamboyant and sadistic dictator is a complex character, with a range of motivations and emotions. His interactions with the player throughout the game are both entertaining and disturbing, adding depth to the game's storyline.

Overall, Far Cry 4 is a well-designed and engaging game that offers players a memorable and immersive experience. With its stunning visuals, engaging storyline, and addictive gameplay, it is a must-play for fans of the first-person shooter genre. Whether you are new to the Far Cry series or a longtime fan, Far Cry 4 is a game that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

You play as Ajay Ghale, a guy who goes to Kyrat to scatter his mother's ashes, but ends up getting caught up in a civil war between the Golden Path rebels and the dictator Pagan Min. 

Playing Far Cry 4 is like taking a vacation to an exotic land where you can do anything you want, as long as it involves shooting things, blowing things up, and running away from wild animals. From the gorgeous mountain landscapes to the intense shootouts with enemy soldiers, this game has it all. Just don't forget to pack your rocket launcher and your sense of humor, because you're going to need both.

You can climb radio towers, ride elephants, and engage in all sorts of other absurd activities that have nothing to do with the main plot. But who needs a plot when you have a grappling hook and a flamethrower? 

The villain, Pagan Min, is a fashion icon with a penchant for pink, making him the most fabulous despot you'll ever encounter in a video game. And let's not forget the game's memorable opening scene, where you are asked to wait while the villain goes to take a phone call, leaving you to sit awkwardly at his dining table. This game has it all: action, humor, and a little bit of awkwardness thrown in for good measure.

The graphics in this game are gorgeous. Kyrat is a beautiful, vibrant world filled with lush forests, snowy mountains, and of course, elephants. The attention to detail is very good.

The gameplay is just as great as ever. The shooting feels smooth and satisfying, and the addition of new weapons like the crossbow and the auto-crossbow (because one crossbow just is not enough) keeps things fresh. You can ride elephants into battle and they will smash everything in their path.

The story is a bit hit-or-miss. Pagan Min is a fantastic villain, and his interactions with Ajay are always entertaining.

This is overall a fantastic game. It has got great gameplay, beautiful graphics, and of course, elephants. Pagan Min may be a terrible dictator, but he sure knows how to throw a party.

[b]In short:[/b] It's another Far Cry game (*), but the gameplay is better than FC3. Skip the DLC as it's mostly garbage. If you're happy running around, blowing sh*t up and gathering collectibles, you'll be fine with the main game.

(*) Charismatic but sadistic villains with no concept of personal space or killing the protagonist when given the chance, 3 standard endings, drugs, supernatural elements, swearing, rape, harrowing cutscenes, collectathons, base assaults, Hurk, Willis, jank and bugginess.

A few notes of warning: The ever-present and unbelievably aggressive animals in this game nearly ruin it. They literally spawn behind you as soon as your turn your back. They can stunlock or instantly kill you, and have so much health that you're forced to carry a LMG and molotovs everywhere to deal with them. I changed my second playthrough difficulty to Easy just because it nerfed the animal damage. The wingsuit will constantly deploy when making even small jumps, instantly killing you. The later Shangri-La quests can also suck a fart out of my @$$ due to difficulty and lack of any meaningful reward.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Graphics, sound and music improvements
+Great voice acting
+More exposure to consistent villain with a few redeeming qualities
+Looting/interacting is easier
+Can move bodies now
+Menu design is much better
+Weapon scopes aren't obscured by scratches
+Not quite so many loot stashes
+Many syringe improvements
+Greater mission variety
+Vehicles handle much better
+Skills and weapons gated much better
+Minigames replaced with repeatable missions
+Few missions that made me genuinely LOL
+Can change difficulty any time
+Save anywhere, no real penalty for death
+Can disable each part of UI if you want challenge/immersion

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Occasional file corruption issues, requiring file verification
~Still easy to max XP and money early in game
~Animated animal cruelty and areas filled with animal gore
~Drug use and more cheap topless nudity
~Arena is an absolute slog, though the rewards are account-bound
~No steam achievements
~Villain is far more likable than your allies
~Weapon balance issues. Many early weapons outshine late ones.
~Quicktime events still in game, but use a consistent button, which is much easier for KB&M players

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-POS Ubisoft Connect launcher and Denuvo
-Wingsuit will frequently get you killed
-Second half of game is crashy, buggy mess
-No volume control! Music is either on or off.
-Unskippable splash screens (without modding command line)
-Some missions have unclear objectives or unfair mechanics
-Still can't fully inspect or compare weapons in shops/menus
-Shangri-la missions are pretty horrible
-DLC not integrated into main game like FC3
-Enemy snipers and vehicle gunners are omniscient hitscanners
-Animals are still ridiculously aggressive, bullet-sponge, cage-breaking, stealth-ruining, teleporting-behind-you assholes

Far Cry 4 is exactly the same as Far Cry 3...

...but significantly worse in almost every way. 

Never in my 15+ years of playing video games, has a game ever made me say out loud "please stop, this isn't fun", quite this often. It's really and truly THAT bad. 

Let's start with Freedom. This is something that FC4 constantly removes from the player. You have no freedom to do whatever you want, and it's been very frustrating for me. I think of a way to do something, and does it work? No, no it doesn't. 

I can't shoot anyone because this mission is mandatory stealth, if someone sees me I instantly lose the mission. 
I can't stealth in the particular way that I want to, for the same reason. If someone sees me, I instantly lose. There are more ways than one to do stealth. 
I gained access to the northern part of the country, and now it's impossible to do my favorite way of capturing missions - turreted trucks - because there's guaranteed to be multiple enemies carrying rocket launchers now. I instantly die.
I can't melee any enemies because each and every single time I get close to them, they bash me with their gun and I get stun locked. I literally can't do anything, get shot, and die. 
And now, just plain shooting someone has become a huge headache because the moment I get nicked by a single bullet, my entire camera shifts upwards, ruining my aim.

I can't even go anywhere I want sometimes, it keeps telling me I'm going out of bounds when I'm very clearly not. The player should be allowed to go anywhere they want to, whenever they want to. Just don't activate the main missions in that area.

Stealth is atrocious. 

If you shoot someone with a silenced weapon, and you miss, oh well... Every enemy NPC becomes superhuman. They know the exact location the shot came from, they look in your direction, they see you from ludicrously far away, AND THEY CAN SEE YOU THROUGH OBJECTS. 

Trees, vehicles, in one case an entire wall, I have gotten seen when I absolutely should not have. They even try to shoot through the same solid objects they see you through, most noticeably trees. Not only is this a problem, but during their superhuman status, they will also notice you extremely quickly. That little "vision bar" fills up nearly instantly, if not literally instantly, if you're in their ginormous field of view.

I tried to force my preferred way of stealth - Loud Stealth, which is using noise and dead bodies to attract enemies away from my position - and it took me two entire hours and I didn't even completely do it. It saved my progress of saving the slaves, but it didn't save any progress I made killing the enemy. The checkpoints in this game are some of the worst I've ever seen, and this is a horrifically beautiful example of how. If I kill people and save a slave, it should also save all the enemies I killed. Basic checkpoint design.

The weapons in this game are better balanced than they were in Far Cry 3, but it doesn't solve the issue that the ones you unlock earliest in the game are pretty much the best weapons you'll have for the rest of the game. It took me all the way to unlocking nearly every single weapon in the game, and there was only 1 weapon for each of my 4 slots I've found to be better than what I immediately had access to from the beginning of the game. This is not okay. Things I unlock, should be better than what I started with.

The graphics are messed up and I can't understand why. There's a forced blur on weapons, and I have absolutely no way of disabling it at all. I've tried following online guides, nothing works anymore. Just nothing. It looks like sh*t. That's not the worst of it, the worst would absolutely be the fact that the game's lighting on weapons is unbelievably bad. I can't enjoy the way my gun looks because it constantly has a shadow casted on it, making almost the entire gun black. I just can't see it, arguably making it a waste of money for me to have bought that skin for it.

The wingsuit is a very good item in concept, but executed awfully in FC4. You press, OR HOLD shift to activate it. HOLD?! YOU CAN HOLD SHIFT?! WHAT???

If you're confused...

When you run and jump, you instinctively HOLD SHIFT during the duration of the jump, don't you? You hold the run button? IT ACTIVATES THE F*CKING WINGSUIT, AND YOU FLY STRAIGHT INTO A WALL AND IMMEDIATELY DIE. Or get needlessly hurt really badly. 

Far Cry 4 also has the exact same problem that Far Cry 3 has - You're not allowed to choose whether you want to physically heal yourself, or use a healing syringe. If I want to heal, no matter what, I use the healing syringe. I am missing 1 bar of health, I don't want to use an item that heals 6 bars of HP to fix that. 

Sometimes when I walk away from an outpost, it instantly starts getting attacked and now I'm forcefully roped into a mission of having to defend the outpost. These suck balls, there are way too many enemies literally everywhere and all I do is die repeatedly in my sad attempts to defend my outpost. I eventually win, but only after dying 5 or so times. It's so stupid it hurts.

Oh, and I can't forget this: Friendly NPCs LOVE to run DIRECTLY in front of your car, you hit them, AND THE GAME PUNISHES YOU FOR IT. IT WASN'T MY FAULT. THEY RAN IN FRONT OF ME... But this never happens with enemy NPCs. They always perfectly run out of the way. So what the hell, are the friendly NPCs just suicidal? God, I don't get it. 

The only genuine improvement that Far Cry 4 has over Far Cry 3, is that the whole place doesn't magically become completely safe after capturing an outpost. There are still enemies roaming around and actually giving you something to do instead of being bored.

Before you buy, inform yourself about the issues of the game.tldr;  Check the web and you'll see, and even the Community Hub on Steam is full of "jokes" about the games bugs and issues. Well, I could fix that one after trying several things, but then...Sound would stop right after the intro - every time I would try. A long-standing issue never fixed, widely known through the web. I'm not going to delete windows system files as some suggest as a fix and risk issues with other properly working games or apps. So, for the moment I continued without sound...After many other "tiny" issues came the worst, which made me ask for a refund, right after the intro, on the very first area you play, there is someone supposed to throw you a rope when you "escape", before actually having completed anything else yet (it's like the first kinda-mission). And this, with several restarts, it just won't trigger. It triggers half of the dialog and the 2nd half - as seen on youtube videos - is when it tells you, he will throw you a rope to climb. If you don't climb up, there is no way to progress. And this 2nd part of the dialog just won't trigger.Borderless mode also just won't work correctly. It shows like half of what should be displayed and the rest is "outside" of the monitor. And the windows key is being blocked by the game. Finally, when exiting, it would simply get stuck and the task manager would be the only thing I could bring up more or less up, and that only being usable, after trying to start the game in windowed mode, otherwise I had to hard reboot. Inform yourself, it's widely known that the game suffers from an incredible amount of never fixed bugs, obviously. Had I seen this before or researched a little (it becomes so obvious if one searches, as people even "joke" about the many issues this game has), I would had probably never bought it. How can a supposed triple-A game be developed to be so badly done? Must have been really bad, if they didn't fix all that, or maybe, it was so deeply bugged, that it was pointless to even try to do so for Ubisoft. I never have issues with games, if any, just once in months the usual tiny thing, which is easily dealt with... but this one, from the very start, before even completing anything, it showed that it's suffering from many issues.

It's just Far Cry 3, done another time but now in the Himalayas. Some things improved, some things decreased in quality (I'd say traversal and collectables were more fun/less annoying in FC3). The story is about of equal quality, but voice acting significantly improved compared to FC3.

THE GOOD: The villain is really, really well written and acted. Progression and open world mechanics feel nice. Good selection of powerful, nice handling weapons. Missions are fun and don't drag on too long. There are even some winks to FC3 and memes from the period this game launched in. Stealth works well enough, but it's not great. Sometimes you really wonder how the heck you were spotted, or why AI acts so dumb when looking for the murderer of their 20 friends.

THE BAD: One major downfall is that the open world can get highly annoying due to ridiculous amount of living world events. Every 2 seconds somebody is getting killed by an eagle, or honey badgers, or tigers. Or attacked by rebels. Or needs help with their car. Or yells at you for some reason. Or you yourself get attacked. The 2 seconds is not even an overstatement, it is that frequent, and it's highly distracting. I've also had quest givers die from dumb stuff like this, resulting in me conversing with the air, with subtitles but no audible voice lines when I start the quest. 

The "backup call token" is the most useless feature ever, can't use it in any situation it would be relevant. 

The main characters Sabal and Amita are annoying as heck and their anger outbursts and bickering make me not wanna help them at all. I don't like either of their characters one bit. The main villain is far more interesting and relatable.

Finally, using the map editor bricks your game. There are also some other major technical issues at times - for example Shangri-La missions tend to completely crash your game on newer hardware (I'm playing on i9/32GB/RTX3070). This makes you have to start over from the beginning with no checkpoints. Those missions nearly made me quit the game, they aren't fun and even less fun when you have constant crashing.

If you just want some more far cry gameplay, climbing towers and claiming outposts, it has all that. If you want eye candy, the whole game is gorgeous. But if you're planning to enjoy this, I hope you have a talent for ignoring plot.
The whole point of the story is to overthrow a dictator and install one of two 'freedom fighter' lieutenants as the new leader of this country. Here's the problem: they're both worse than the actual dictator is. One wants to be a heroin kingpin and raise an army of child soldiers, one wants to enslave the country and slaughter opposition. And every time you pick the lesser of two evils you have to listen to the other one bitch at you for 10 minutes for not siding with them.
The villains, save the main one, are all forgettable, too.
But the worst part, the truly worst part of the plot, is that if you go for the secret ending - which is available at the literal start of the game - you find out (spoilers) the protagonist actually not only has much more reason to side with the bad guy, he has great reason to side AGAINST the so-called 'freedom fighters'! The whole purpose of the protagonist coming here is better served joining the enemy!
This whole plot SCREAMS first-thought 'makes you think!' morality, like someone who saw Kojima and thought "how hard could it be?"
If bad writing bothers you, give this one a wide, wide miss.

The story and the combat are pretty decent, and the graphics can be quite breathtaking... But the game suffers from the Ubisoft Syndrome. Exploration is very modular, with each area having a tower you have to climb. Most locations don't seem unique (I get flashbacks to dungeons in Oblivion). When you unlock a tower, the game shows you the locations of interest nearby, and it's often just a shack or two with nothing interesting in it. Combat is repetitive as well, if you've done 2 or 3 fights, you've done it all. 

Basically the exploration in the game is wide, but shallow. Big area, but not much in it.

Pros:
- Addictive gameplay and gunplay
- Wide variety of weapons and equipment
- Great open world with lots of stuff to keep the player busy
- Beautiful graphics, a solid upgrade from the previous title
- Second most iconic antagonist in the franchise
- Different choices impact on the missions the player will do or how will they end
- You can tame and ride elephants (that's 100% a pro in my books)
- Game is very stable (played on a RTX 3050 with an Intel Core i5 9th Gen and a 1080p Full HD monitor), runs at 60 FPS on high at full resolution with very little visual/gameplay bugs, nothing gamebreaking but might impact the realism of the experience (do people still care for realism?)

Cons:
- If compared to Far Cry 3, the story didn't have that great of an impact on the player, but isn't in any way bad
- As it is the same with many (if not all) Ubisoft games on PC, it is tied to the Ubisoft Connect launcher, a con that's already enough for many people to skip many good Ubi titles

Notes: One of the most fun experiences I've had in a video game, this was probably the last good Far Cry title we'll ever get. 9/10

Far cry 4 has a unique and well crafted setting inspired by Tibetan, Himalayan and South Asian landscapes and cultures. The music and wide variety of wildlife and map features serve to complement this and provide a satisfying open world experience. 
Perhaps most importantly, I find the story to be quite a compelling one. Many action games like this seem to centre around a rebellion against a dictatorship, but Far cry 4 is one of the few which shows the consequences of these regime changes, and how easily one tyrant can be replaced by another (an aspect which is helped significantly by the presence of a charismatic villain). The player has a direct hand in the course of the story, and while the game does not have RPG levels of choice, the player can at certain points take actions which will impact the overall course of the story. In short, some of your actions will have lasting consequences in this game.
The game is not perfect. I find the liberation of camps in the game to be quite repetitive (although the presence of "fortresses" in the game alleviates this somewhat by providing more unique and challenging liberation sections). That said, the dynamic open world still offers a lot of fun activities for players, and many locations to explore. Furthermore, the I personally find that the progression system fits an acceptable balance between being too fast and too slow for the character to upgrade along with the course of the game. A similar thing can be said about the weapons, which generally become available at the right time in the game, and the crafting system, which encourages exploration of the map without being too tedious. 
Overall, I feel the mix of a compelling story and a rich open world environment makes far cry 4 truly memorable, and I have revisited the game many times. I would say that this game is worth a playthrough.

Fuck the eagles. Seriously, fuck the eagles and whoever was in charge of the open world encounters in this game, he needs to have an eagle shoved up his ass and be sent far away from any game development related job. I suggest ornithologist, what with the weird obsession / phobia of eagles. Whoever is this creep, he needs to step away from whatever position he holds in Ubi and really go do something else, preferably far away from people.

The eagles are one of the most annoying enemies in video-games in general, they are fairly small flying enemies that generally attack from the back / blind spot, they are extremely aggro, they spot you long before you can spot them and there is generally no warning. Furthermore, there is about a trillion of them around the map at any given time.

Want to got to mission, go towards a vehicle. Eagle attack.
Get into car, drive to location. Eagle attack.
Start mission, go to target location. Eagle attack.
Finish mission. Eagle attack.
Need to hunt some animals for drops to upgrade, go to animal location, sneaking around to get as many as I can quickly. Eagle attack. All animals run off.
Go to different location. Eagle attack, all animals run off.
Repeat multiple times. Multiple eagle attacks, give up on hunting, go free an outpost instead.
Sneaking into outpost to get clean clear. Eagle attack. Enemies alerted, call reinforcements, get swarmed and die.
Repeat a couple times, couple eagle attacks later give up and go looking for loot chests. Multiple eagle attacks.
Money items gathered, drive to a trader to sell the loot. Eagle attack.
Get out of trader location. Eagle attack.
Go to one of the map reveal towers. Three eagle attacks.
Scale the tower, reveal map locations, go down. Eagle attack.
Hide inside a house because I have to step away from the PC. Come back to NPCs outside the house being attacked by an eagle.
Walk around. Eagle attack.
Take a breath. Eagle attack.
Blink. Eagle attack.
Live. Eagle attack.
Die. Eagle attack.
Eagle attack. Eagle attack.

The rest of the game is fine. It's your generic decent Ubi game, about 7/10, just the bare minimum you would expect from an AAA game. As with the rest of the games, the main issue with FC4 is not the derivative design, it's the fact that even after so much time and tons of games with the same design, they still have the same issues - the general lack of technical polish, janky physics, extremely basic and limited drive model for the vehicles, grindy crafting/progression that is forced on you if you want to carry more than one weapon, two magazines of ammo and a chump change barely enough to buy ammo.

The shooting is okay, the gun selection is okay, the combat balance is okay for the most part with a couple unnecessary bullet sponge enemies as in almost every Far Cry, and so on. 

As mentioned, it's nothing special, except the fucking eagles, and those are not a good addition.

Anyways, if you can grab it under 10 bucks/eur (or whatever your equivalent of 5 cheeseburgers worth is), go for it. Now excuse me while I go commit mass eaglecide.

This game through me for a loop. I really like the core gameplay elements, except the hunting, but the game did not feel as fun and engaging as it could have been. This is my first experince with a far cry game (I bought far cry 3 and above) so I'll update this review to compare them to this one. I just can't find myself recommending this game at full price. I however got it for something like 90% off during a winter sale which I recommend anyone looking for this game do. I've been wanting to expand my gaming experince and decided to start with the far cry franchise (along with some other games which I will be reviewing as I play). Overall I had a decent time with this game. Here is my review.
Things I like about the game (pros)
- Good Shooting mechanics, felt fun to play
- Fun weapon and shop system (though tedious) 
- Good setting 
- Open world 
- Fun to mess around
- Great stealth mechanics (felt very fun to use stealth though you could just shoot everything and be fine) 
- Good villan 
Things I dont like about the game (cons) 
- Lackluster story 
- Empty open world
- Hunting is required to progress the game (ik that is kinda the point but I didn't like it) 
- Chracters lacked depth
- Thrown into the world without much explanation 
- Not much flexibility in playstyles 
- DLC not worth it/not very fun 
- Kind of grindy to complete main quests 
- Lack luster prologue  
- Not much replayability 
- Felt like a worse Just Cause game

Overall I had a fun time but I don't recommend this game at full price. I only enjoy this game for the sake of trying to expand my gaming taste and experinces. 5/10 for me

Far Cry 4 is a thrilling and immersive open-world game that offers players endless hours of excitement and exploration. The stunning graphics and attention to detail in the game's environments and characters are truly impressive, making for a truly immersive experience. The game's storyline is engaging and filled with unexpected twists and turns, making for an exciting and captivating gameplay experience. Additionally, the wide range of weapons and vehicles available to players offers a great degree of customization and variety, allowing players to approach the game in their own unique way. Overall, Far Cry 4 is an excellent addition to the series and a must-play for any fan of open-world games.

I don't know why but it seems Steam deleted my review, so here it is again.

Far Cry 4 is definitely one of my favorites in the series. It took everything what made Far Cry 3 fun (minus the radio towers) and built upon it. Open world freedom, use whatever gun you want from a huge assortment, do whatever mission you want, it's all up to you. All of that in the beautiful Himalaya mountains. Oh yeah and you gotta take out a flamboyant, discount Vaas Montenegro called Pagan Min.

There are some weird things though like people doing the most random-ass Ñ•hit besides the road and all animals want to kill you, but arguably this is just amusing.

One big downside is that co-op is horrible, don't even try it. You can only do small missions and raid outposts together. Anything story-wise is singleplayer only. On top of that, connecting to each other doesn't work most of the time because it's Uplay. A complete miss on that department.

Nevertheless, I've played through the whole game about 4-5 times and it's fun every single time.

[b]1. Personal Opinion:[/b]
I first knew of this game on youtube, this game introduced me into the Far Cry franchise, back at 2014... Now, I've already played every single Far Cry, and this one is still my favourite one.

There's something on this game that tells me, this is Far Cry... Multiple endings and variations of the same endings, a hidden plot behind everything, multiple ways to do things, stealth, silence, unseen, ghost. As well as rushing, explosions, gunshots, powerfire, artillery or simply bait and wildlife... This is Far Cry.

I enjoyed Far Cry, Far Cry 2, Far Cry 3 and Far Cry 5 a lot, but the 4th one, for me, is still the best, there's no other reason for having played this game 17 times... [not a joke]


[b]2. Pros:[/b]
- Great, inmersive, complex and misterious story
- Adictive gameplay: Freedom, your choices matter, AI [b]is[/b]* a threat, choose your way to do things
- Extremely great, inmersive, suitable and perfect OST. [spoiler]LOVE THE LAST MISSION SONG "THE RIVER" it means more than you can imagine the first time you hear it when you hear it[/spoiler]

- Choices you make will alter the story course [spoiler](but you'll get the same ending options no matter what you've elected, with just some variations on dialogs).[/spoiler]

- Cooperative Mode.
- Ultra easy to adquire all the achievements on Uplay

*[spoiler]AI is a threat if you play it accordingly, I mean, AI will adapt to your actions but you can easily overpower it (when on early and mid game) with unlocked late game weapons that you might encounter on some side missions.[/spoiler]


[b]3. Cons:[/b]
- While not doing missions, gameplay can turn boring, not really though there are always tons of things to do, but if you're a "mission mainstream" player then: hook up some friends and do crazy things
- You'll need a low-medium specs pc to enjoy this game, get a high one if you can, you'll enjoy it. 
-You can't do principal missions in cooperative mode
-Buggisoft greatness is ultra present in this game, there are some bugs that will nerve you out, and some other will make you die laughing

This is my favorite game of all time, there's something special that keeps bringing me back to it. I've completed it 4 or 5 times and I still love it as much as I did on my first playthrough. This is quite possibly the best setting in any game I've played. The rich culture and beautiful scenery of Kyrat helps make this an immersive experience that keeps the player interested at all times. Yes the graphics are starting to show their age now, but I still maintain the idea that this game is beautiful. Ajay is an interesting protagonist and he's a lot more likable than Jason in my opinion. The voice acting is very solid and helps bring each of the characters to life. The gameplay is typical Far Cry, which is brilliant. My only gripe with the gameplay is the return of radio towers; I'm glad this is the last game they make an appearance in. The story is very interesting, I like how you are presented with the choice of backing Amita or Sabal and how your choices lead to different mission objectives. There are far more guns than there were in Far Cry 3, including more signature weapons, which have special attributes and mods. Overall, I'd give this game a 9/10. It's a must play for Ubisoft fans and anyone who loves first person shooters.

Valley of the Yetis DLC:
Definitely worth a playthrough if you enjoyed the main game. The story is pretty much nonexistent, but it's engaging enough to make the whole playthrough interesting. Gameplay is identical to the main game, no new weapons or combat skills were added unfortunately. The relay defense missions are fun, as is the relay station upgrade system. The yetis are rather underwhelming unfortunately. Even on the hardest difficulty, I never died to one. Still a fun, worthwhile experience in my opinion. I'd give it a 7/10.

This is by far my favorite in the series. People call this a FC3 reskin, and honestly, though I'd disagree, I don't think that's a bad thing. FC3 was a great game. The QoL updates this one got made it so going back to 3 is a bit disappointing.

Graphically, I love this updated FC3 look, as well. The setting lends well to sweeping landscapes, lush forests, and snowy scenes. The newer games with the new UI just feel worse. Even 6, which I enjoy so far in the demo, has the same boxy, changed feeling that made me loathe 5 off the bat (before the storyline and scant, boring feeling took over).

My only gripe with this game is that it has to be played through UPlay/Ubisoft Connect. I wouldn't even mind that if launching it didn't necessitate both Steam and Connect running since I bought it here. As much as I'd love to just play it from Steam, I'd much rather play it from just Connect than needing both. There are way too many shortcuts to accidentally step on with all the software I have running. But anyway, that's not this games fault. It's still part of the experience, though.

Overall, this game has a lot of replay-ability. I still roam around with the UI off and every so often reset the outposts because it's so fun. I wouldn't do that in any game but this one. 3 is missing QoL updates, 5 is boring to me, and 6's setting doesn't quite make me wanna roam around like this one.

This is the best Far Cry imo. It has the same core gameplay of Far Cry 3, but it's been polished up and feels much nicer. There's tons of content and the gameplay is definitely fun enough on its own to justify a purchase. I think what really stands out about this game compared to others in the franchise is the world building, it is so far above and beyond that of the other games in the series that none come even remotely close. Even if Far Cry isn't about the story, having a truly fleshed out world and characters really added to my enjoyment. Kyrat has a beautiful, unique geography, as well as its own culture, economy, and politics. Pagan Min is easily my favorite villain from the Far Cry series, and the faction you fight for is also one of the most nuanced I've seen. Even so, the story never overstays its welcome or distracts from gameplay. There's also lots of replayability through the arcade and arena once you beat the main story, as well as many side missions. 

That's not to say this game is perfect. Here are my biggest pet peeves:
1) Things get kind of buggy in the second half of the game. Generally, this wasn't a big issue though.
2) The wingsuit can be quite annoying to use, especially because the button to activate it is the same as the sprint button by default. I died many times to accidentally opening my wingsuit when I didn't mean to and I eventually learned to stop holding shift any time I jumped.
3) The arena is painfully grindy. There's one signature weapon that can only be attained by reaching level 10 in the arena. At first it wasn't so bad, but after about level 5, it took an obscene amount of time just to go up one level. My 100% Completion Playthrough took around 50 hours, and probably about 5-10% of that time was spent in the arena, which doesn't seem bad until you realize that I spent a LOT of time exploring the map to collect every single loot chest (which doesn't contribute to completion), so grinding the arena could easily take up 10-15% of a 100% completion run that doesn't include the loot chests. Also, there's almost no variation in the arena mode, so for that entire time you'll be playing on the same map against the same waves of enemies over and over and over and over again. It gets tedious very quickly.

TLDR; Far Cry 4 is the best game in the franchise imo, barring a few nitpicks and a very grindy (but optional) arena mode. If you enjoy open world games and/or first person shooters, I would highly recommend.

WOW!  What can I say? Having played, and thoroughly enjoyed, FAR CRY 3, I approached FAR CRY 4 with the same willingness to suspend disbelief and was rewarded in so many ways albeit one: the Ending, or should I say Endings (plural). Without hesitation, the graphic quality, the open world, the freedom of play, the weapons, the myriad characters, the MOCAP and the voice performances are all spectacular. 165 hours of game play is a testament to this adjective. As a "completionist", I carefully strove to uncover and discover the ultimate outcome of the stated motive of the game: return of the ashes. Thusly, I felt sadly robbed of this satisfaction because of a simple choice made during game play. Without offering spoilers, and knowing that FAR CRY 3 had two endings, I searched on-line and discovered the game had not two, but MULTIPLE endings, all of which were predicated on choices made both earlier in-game, end of campaign, and even post-campaign. Ultimately, having satisfied my need for story-line closure, I have an almost bittersweet recognition and acknowledgement that there are no ideal end solutions, and"choices" do indeed define our reality, whether day-to-day or immersed in the alternate reality of gaming. Cheers!

Honestly, It's not a BAD game. There's a couple things I'd like to say about this game. 
1. The missions are tedious. It's capture this territory, shoot the bad guys, and repeat. There's some collectables too, but again, tedious work for very little reward. There's some hunting quests but they're not very hard. What makes it hard is animal AI, which sucks. 
2. The antagonists just aren't compelling. Without spoiling anything in the game, they're basic textbook bad guys. They technically have a reason for doing what they do but it all boils down to "I hurt people because it's fun muahahahaha" ; and that's just not compelling enough to go through such a long game. 
3. The open world is awesome. There's always something hiding somewhere. Unfortunately some areas are locked until a certain progress is met but beggars can't be choosers. However the NPC's do suck and have no substance, they kinda just walk around and repeat the same 10 lines of dialogue. 
4. It's a very long game if you choose to do everything. I didn't do any of the collectables and I still clocked in 45 hours on the base game, and another 5 with DLC. But I like sneaky tactics which can take longer, so I take a little extra time to plan out my assault. 
5. The absolute worst part of the game are the Yoggi and Reggie quests. They're just so dumb. I don't want to spoil. Google it if you're curious. But oh my, I hated every single quest they gave me. My character had zero reason to keep doing the quests and it felt so out of character that it just took me out the game completely.    
6. Even with 50 hours clocked into this game, I'm going to say, Don't buy this. There's a lot of other games you could play that are better than this. It's not even about the money, it's just not worth sinking so much time into. It's not a compelling game. It's just a time sink.

Overall, I highly recommend Far Cry 4 to anyone who enjoys open-world action games. It's a fantastic game that offers a lot of depth and replay value.
