Put simply, Far Cry 4 is a better game than Far Cry 3, but has more bugs. It's hardly the innovative leap that FC3 was, but for me it meets the same high standard (more or less), does a good job at differentiating itself, and stays interesting through to the end.

First, straight improvements over Far Cry 3:
+ Better graphics and comparable, if not better, performance.
+ In general, side content is much less spammy. There's both [b]more[/b] variety yet [b]fewer[/b] of each type of mission and collectible, and actual side plots that add a touch of continuity. For example, you can collect Masks of Yalung, tokens of The Goat, a serial killer on a killing spree in the name of the demon Yalung. He leaves notes behind at many of the mask's locations that add some lore; I appreciated having small side plots like this to follow outside the main story. There are also a wide variety of people who give you missions, and for a variety of purposes.
+ More verticality: grappling hooks, buzzers (small personal helicopters), and an early-game wingsuit. They're very natural additions to the Himalayan landscape, and also serve to make the game a bit more exciting. I mean, who doesn't love mowing down soldiers from a helicopter with a Tec-9 or grenade launcher?
+ Now, instead of being obsessed with in-law jokes, the journal is a piece of propaganda from Pagan Min. I like the twist.
+ There is a similar parallel of mystical themes, but it's a very different approach that felt novel, original, and even more immersive than in FC3.
+ You can ride elephants into battle. I can't stress this enough.
+ Mortars.
+ Outposts can be attacked by the Royal Army after you take them. It doesn't happen often, but it adds a little more believability to the war.
+ In some ways, the story was a bit less contrived, i.e. your involvement in the plot is a little more intentional, you're not just a student-turned-mercenary. Kyrat is your birthplace. Pagan Min, the dictator, is your [i]stepdad[/i]. Immediately, the plot has intrigue, and the complexities of family give it depth. Some characters are a bit one-dimensional, but it delivers overall.

A few more neutral comparisons and comments:
â€¢ Stealth is a bit harder. Suppressed weapons are more scarce (more on this later), foliage is less dense, and enemies like hunters and snipers can spot you very easily. This is a matter of taste, I did end up going guns blazing much more often, even though I tend to prefer stealth, and I came to enjoy it. Both playstyles are arguably equally viable, which is a lot more than many other games can say. 
â€¢ The fauna of Kyrat is much more hostile than that of the Rook Islands, and lots of things try to kill you. This is explained in the game as a result of heroin and rabies, which isn't ridiculous but a bit odd. It was a little annoying early game (fuck eagles and dholes) but less so once you get strong weapons.
â€¢ Gun progression is weird. You get access to pretty powerful weapons early in the game, and now a big point of differentiation is availability of attachments. For example, many signature weapons are just some other weapon (which doesn't support attachments) with a full suite of pre-equipped attachments and slightly better stats. I can see why this was done, it forces you to expose yourself and be aggressive early on, but it feels bad to lose the customizability, and it's weird for only weaker guns to have it.
â€¢ They kept the cluttery loot system, with random garbage items on bodies worth various amounts of money. It's not that big of a deal, but after seeing that most of the rest of the clutter of FC3 is gone, it's a shame.
â€¢ Some of the interaction hitboxes are obnoxious. It seems to be less common than in FC3, but still present. The worst offender I found was a note that could only be read if I crouch-walked right into it and looked at a specific angle. I think that's unacceptably bad.
â€¢ Pagan Min is not as unique as Vaas. He's very similar to Handsome Jack, similarly morbid, but less funny. That said, he makes up for it in certain ways ([spoiler] You instigated, not him! He kinda wasn't the bad guy! Well, yes, he's a horrible person, but so are Amita and Sabal![/spoiler]), and he obviously has more complexity and depth (than Vaas).

And, now, the problems:
- I have the game set to fullscreen. When I click to start the game, the game exits fullscreen, and I have to re-fullscreen it. I made sure to learn the shortcut for that (Shift+Enter) because I had to do it [b]twice, every single time I launched the game[/b]. Tabbing in and out, and weirdly enough, certain interactions in the menu, caused similar behavior.
- Advice: DISABLE BOTH LOOTING ANIMATIONS AND NOTIFICATIONS. Although the animations are pretty decent, they take WAY TOO LONG. When you're looting after a firefight and you have sit through a solid minute of animations every time, it gets old fast. And, nearly all of the item names are irrelevant, so you don't have to see them anyway.
- Similarly, notifications last way too long. If you unlock/pick up/etc a lot of things in a short time frame, the notifications can lag really far behind. Worst case, I've picked up a journal entry and was able to finish a mission before I was prompted 'Press M to read'. It's very, very annoying to have to wait for a game menu to catch up to you.
- Following missions exist.
- Outpost Master and Kyrati Films missions that you complete don't show any visual change on the minimap, only when you physically walk up to the mission table to accept it. I lost track after beating a few outposts, and that was annoying enough that I decided they just weren't worth doing.
- I find it really irritating that gun stats only exist as a sliding scale without any numbers, and weapon comparison shows bars that I didn't find immediately intuitive (white and red, but does that mean white = the highlighted one is better, or white = the one being hovered over is better?). Also, you can't compare weapon stats across tabs in the shop, so I had to take pictures of my screen to be able to see the stats side by side. Once I had a lot of signature weapons available this got really annoying.
- The buzzer is a literal helicopter, so it makes sense that it has very dangerous blades. It even makes sense that if you make a misstep, you can be decapitated by the blades. However, it's ridiculous how many times I've died due to this. When you dismount, you stand just under the edge of the blades, so if you land on any uneven surface, the buzzer may settle, tip, and instantly kill you. There's no way to turn the engine off before dismounting, so if you land on some rocks and start in the wrong direction, you may just die.
- The wingsuit was a hazard. You get the option to deploy it whenever you're midair at least ~6-8 feet above the ground, and deploying the wingsuit and sprint both use SHIFT. I like to press sprint mid-air to hit the ground running, and this led me to accidentally deploy my wingsuit fairly often. This isn't the worst thing, except way too many times that caused me to "crash" and instantly die, despite [b]not even being high enough up to take fall damage[/b]. Similar is true for the parachute.
- Random bugs and more than one annoying crash.
- Karma levels and skill levels both run out way too early, the upgrades basically stop 50-75% of the way through the game. The fact that there are [b]tens[/b] of levels just dedicated to boosting syringe duration comes off as really lazy design. They are also two huge incentives to do side content, and they become irrelevant mid-game.
- The [spoiler]Yogi and Reggie[/spoiler] missions become a bit stale, and there's not even that many.
- The elephant in [spoiler]Shangri-La Thangka #4[/spoiler] is BUGGY AS HELL and would teleport out from under me and de-aggro. It's also necessary to ride it to progress through one part, but it wasn't communicated well and I ended up restarting the mission.

A very solid Far Cry game with a very well written story. Not as bland and even more in depth than 3. More ways to encourage you to explore using creative thinking. Different ways to get around the map make it refreshing to want to just look at something, and then figure out how to get to it. There's a new vehicle too, It's a one person helicopter that makes travelling the map A BREEZE. Different weapons (and some fan favorites returning as well, which is great to see) and throwables help with finding out different ways to suit a playstyle you find more comfortable instead of awkward. The story alone is interesting with different outcomes YOU get to be a part of, the game itself is very fun. I especially enjoy an NPC named Longinus, and his missions he offers.

I give it 4/5, only because I have noticed some annoying bugs that have been in the game since the third entry, and the enemy AI seems to still be very similar to the past few titles. The friendly AI has improved but they still have a lot of issues with pathfinding. It isn't enough to distract me from a great Far Cry game.

This is the video game equivalent of the proverbial hot blonde â€” stunningly beautiful, but also dangerous and not particularly smart. 

Let's start with the beauty: visually, the game is absolutely stunning. Quite an improvement over Far Cry 3, and still holds up very well even eight years later. The fictional country of Kyrat looks gorgeous no matter where you go. Screenshot-worthy sights are around literally every corner, frequently making your jaw drop. Sometimes you just want to relax for a minute and take it all in, except you can't, because there's probably something waiting to kill you. 

The fauna is extremely aggressive in this game, more so than the previous one I'd say, and it's just as plentiful. While you're taking in those picture postcard views, there's probably a gang of vicious dholes sneaking up on you already, and they have absolutely no instinct for self-preservation and will keep hunting you down and attacking until you reluctantly kill them all, despite their cuddly cuteness. And even if you're careful when sneaking around the pastures and keep your eyes on the ground at all times, you may suddenly get attacked by an eagle mistaking you for its prey. 

In Far Cry 3, you could at least count yourself safe from animal attacks while you were driving a vehicle, but not so in this game, because there's rhinos and elephants who are more than able (and frequently willing) to have a go at you, and if they do, you may end up in a ditch faster than your average drug fiend. 

Of course, it's not just the animals trying to kill you. As usual, the map is also absolutely littered with dumb but trigger happy enemy soldiers, who are always wiling to have a shootout with you. In addition to that, there are now hunters as well, who will attack you with arrows, and due to their sneakiness can be hard to spot. And as if the wildlife wasn't already aggressive enough, they'll lure in predatory beasts to attack you (which, by the way, is an ability you also have). Finally, if they fail to kill you by those means, they can even use fire arrows to set the vegetation around you on fire, which can in some cases cut off your only escape route. 

Fortunately or unfortunately however, the AI is exceedingly dumb, leading it to frequently make extremely clumsy mistakes. Hunters sometimes set themselves on fire by shooting their burning arrows too close, and I've observed soldiers dropping smoke grenades right in front of themselves and then complaining loudly about their inability to see anything. Also, the NPCs are just as likely to be a target for the aggressive wildlife as you are, and because most of them are quite easily killed by one or two gunshots, they frequently fall victim to it en masse. 

Apart from all that, the game pretty much follows the same formula as the previous entries in the series â€” liberate radio towers to uncover more of the map, capture enemy camps to make the area safer by removing enemy spawn points (and creating fast travel points for yourself), raid loot boxes to get money to buy more guns, hunt animals for their skins to craft more gear, and collect plants in order to craft syringes. And of course, if inbetween all this you still have time for that, there's a story as well, which now occasionally confronts you with different choices, although I have yet to see how those play out eventually. 

All in all Far Cry 4 offers cheap and constant thrills in a very appealing package, but it can get dull rather quickly due to  repetitiveness. Apart from the story missions, there isn't really much to surprise you. You just keep doing the same thing over and over, but with more and better weapons and upgraded skills. It's basically like comfort food: predictable but tasty and generally satisifying.

Sweet Jesus. I regret putting the time into the game that I have let alone purchasing it in the first place.

It has it's good points. Some of the side quests and mini missions are fun so it has some okay-ish pick up and put down aspects but that's it as far as the good stuff goes because the rest is an absolute dumpster fire. 

The AI is buggy as hell. If you drive past an NPC too fast they will try to dodge you..... by jumping straight in front of your vehicle..... and then you loose karma. Enemies at times appear to be psychic somehow seeing you through solid objects and at great distance. There also seems to be a 50/50 chance whether or not the suppressor upgrade for your firearms will actually work. 

The lack of ability to make individual saves and load previous saves is beyond infuriating. When attempting to do perfect undetected liberation's of outposts you have to die in order to to go back and make another attempt, although in hindsight that was pretty stupid because the game doesn't reward you any differently when it comes to how you go about it. Whatever you do the outcome is the same. 

The in game economy is pretty pointless. I made it no less than a quarter to a third of the way through the main missions by the time I had most to weapons and attachments unlocked and purchased because there is no limit to what you can sell and how much you can get from "vendors". They may as well have just not bothered with any currency mechanic.

The karma system is completely pointless considering it only has 8 levels which can be gained pretty quickly, yet even so I had all the maps purchased by the time it gave me the first discount which is one of the rewards you get for advancing your karma level. 

The general mechanics of the game are also tremendously bad. Regardless of the enemies strength, rank etc you can't charge them with a melle attack as you will be knocked down 100% of the time and loose 75% of your health in the process. Most of the weapons are barely useful, and even then they are only so for a very limited time. The compound bow for example does a great job at one shotting people in early game but it won't be long before you have to be right behind an enemy giving him a headshot if you want to one shot him. Which is a total shame because doing stealth liberation's with the bow and throwing knives was quite exhilarating and fun. They could have offered various upgrades like higher Ibs rated bow strings or other components. Instead you get two different "optics" only one of which is actually useful.

The upgrading aspect of weapons is also just completely stupid. alot of the weapons have hardly any worthwhile upgrades/ attachments and those that have a plethora have an arbitrary limit as to how many can be used. The signature tier of weapons makes the main weapons tier completely pointless as well.

Cut scenes and voice acting are so terrible and are just pure cringe. Very little thought went into the character development. It's pretty obvious from the outset that you(the protagonist) are basically the pawn of two aspiring dictators and the only likable character is Pagan Min, the currently reigning unapologetic dictator. He is also the only decently fleshed out and voice acted character in the entire game. As for the general theme and style of the world itself, it too is as cringe as the acting if not more so. It feels like a weird mishmash of south pacific and east Asian cultures.

Your options in the story line are quite limited and to say this game has "multiple" endings is very generous. There are only two endings. You either dethrone the current dictator and help another ascend, or you kill everyone and take it all for yourself....

Over all this game had a lot of potential but it shows the dev's just said "ah fuck it I couldn't be arsed, send it". This game could have been so much more. It just feel's like a mishmash of poorly executed ideas that were hobbled together and saddled with a bare basic story.

This will be the last Ubisoft game I dare touch. They are now on my no go list along with EA and Blizzard. It's a shame seeing the companies I grew up with as a kid just going to complete shit and essentially running off with the bag not giving a toss about their fan bases anymore.

There will be spoilers, but first, a little honesty. I felt a lot of frustration from the game play, with vehicles and animals disappearing before my eyes, combat that was not improved from the last title in the series, and times where it took me five minutes to skin an animal because I was interrupted by hawks, patrols, and other animals simultaneously attacking, leaving a trail of forty dead birds, wolves, bad guys, hawks, and yaks. The story however, is brilliantly different from FC3. I hated the choice in the end of FC3 because it made no sense whatsoever. Your character spends the entire game trying to save his friends, only to be given a choice to kill them at the end of the game. While FC3 had bad guys with very clear evil intent, FC4 has nothing BUT hard choices to make. The king of Kyrat (the main protagonist in FC4), IS a tyrant, but is still accommodating and will keep his word to help you spread your mothers ash's at the end of the game (if you choose not to kill him). You must also choose which character to help in rebelling against the king of Kyrat, while doing the main missions in order to get to the end. Both characters are freedom fighters, but have different ideologies as to how to free the country. I am AMAZED that this game has nothing BUT hard choices, and ALL of them seem to have downsides. All of the choices I made playing this game left me with a raw, empty feeling, like I wasn't sure if I'd made the right decision, but that's war, hell on the mind.  Just like FC3, the land is beautiful, and is fun to explore, there is plenty of things to do and people to kill. The setting is different, but the combat is still the same (fun).  With it's few flaws, I highly recommend playing this game, the story is brilliantly simple with complicated decisions! 8/10!

OK so I've said I recommend this game but there's a BIG BUT. For the most part the story and the combat are very satisfying. Taking down the whole garrison of an enemy camp or a fort single-handedly by stealth, without being discovered, with a silenced sniper rifle is the biggest buzz in the game for me. The single seater autogyro is a great piece of kit, especially for getting to the top of the bell towers if you carefully manoeuvre it onto one of the upper platforms. Combined with the one-handed grenade launcher it's a formidable weapon. However the thing that really tanks the game are the drug-fogged missions, most forced on the player when held captive and all based in some fantastical environment that really, really doesn't belong in the game. Instead of fighting baddies with all the combat gear upgrades and skill improvements you've earned you're fighting with a knife or bow and arrows against a swarm of demons that can suddenly evaporate into a mist. To be fair they're armed with knives or bows and arrows too but they NEVER seem to miss because your agility has been seriously compromised! And then because you've been stripped of all your gear you have no recourse to your med kit either so you're laboriously pulling out arrows, patting down the flames on your arms or wrapping yourself in dressings - all actions that seem to take an eternity while said demons advance on you. SO YOU KEEP DYING. Re-spawning and having to go through things all over again from an earlier checkpoint are a real buzz kill. The abandoned gold mine mission in Northern Kyrat has got me so frustrated I'm on the cusp of uninstalling the game because it's just so damned tedious, tedious, tedious. The game doesn't even offer an option to abandon this supernatural nightmare when I just want to get out and fight with the rebels in the real world. Deliberately failing the mission doesn't work either. You just get plonked down right back at the start at the mine entrance with no other choice or direction to go. I can't even find a way to get back to an earlier save in any in-game menu. I guess cleverer people with more knowledge of computers might know how but that's not me. And that rant only makes me feel a little bit better!

I rarely post negative feedback but this time I feel really let down. I have played every Far Cry game and each was somewhat solid, in terms of the story. Playing FC3 was really immersive, you've started as a tourist, fought for your live, developed some skills, got better with guns and finally made it to the end.

There is a downside as well. Since FC2, the end of game phase looks kinda alike. Get to the outpost, clear it out, proceed. Rinse and repeat. But that's acceptable if you are already deep into the story and you can really have fun clearing the enemies with all the combos, explosive arrows or totally Rambo style, opening fire at everything that moves with a machine gun. 

However with the FC4, the game fails to entertain right from the start. Spoiled alert - do not proceed further.

This time we are just a guy trying to fullfill the last wish of the mother. We are being kidnapped by some local king which when compared to Vas, is totally unconvinceable. Anyway, after following the corridor (literally!) we find ourselves in Call of Duty style escape, shooting with the SMG into incoming enemies. Like, yeah, from "I am scared tourist" to "Captain Price" in a mere seconds. And then we have get to the desired point. Which we do by throwing grenades and silent killing dozens of enemies with a knife. Yeah, totally normal for an tourist who just got there. Any backstore? Anything which would turn this plausible? NOPE. Like a wet dream of a teenager, we were thrown into guerilla warfare and we totally outperform Rambo. 

But that's just a tutorial! And it gets worse! We are instantly offered typical missions like "Kill X", "liberate the outpost" and "take down the radio transmitter". Even driving, well, drives you mad because the tunes are like 2 minutes long and repeating constantly. Even the fact that the world is absolutely full of everything - money, ammo, even vehicles! In FC3 finding a car was a great help. Here, ATVs, jeeps, even helicopters, are just scattered in the area. Pick whatever you want. Go, kill, rinse, repeat. And you might think, yeah, the story might save this game. Aaaand we are let down again. The choices have no real impact. The cutscenes are not interruptible. I have played 4 hours and I am this close to uninstalling. 

To sum up, you want to play this game? Get it on sale or skip it completely. You will not loose much.

This is my favorite game of all time, there's something special that keeps bringing me back to it. I've completed it 4 or 5 times and I still love it as much as I did on my first playthrough. This is quite possibly the best setting in any game I've played. The rich culture and beautiful scenery of Kyrat helps make this an immersive experience that keeps the player interested at all times. Yes the graphics are starting to show their age now, but I still maintain the idea that this game is beautiful. Ajay is an interesting protagonist and he's a lot more likable than Jason in my opinion. The voice acting is very solid and helps bring each of the characters to life. The gameplay is typical Far Cry, which is brilliant. My only gripe with the gameplay is the return of radio towers; I'm glad this is the last game they make an appearance in. The story is very interesting, I like how you are presented with the choice of backing Amita or Sabal and how your choices lead to different mission objectives. There are far more guns than there were in Far Cry 3, including more signature weapons, which have special attributes and mods. Overall, I'd give this game a 9/10. It's a must play for Ubisoft fans and anyone who loves first person shooters.

Valley of the Yetis DLC:
Definitely worth a playthrough if you enjoyed the main game. The story is pretty much nonexistent, but it's engaging enough to make the whole playthrough interesting. Gameplay is identical to the main game, no new weapons or combat skills were added unfortunately. The relay defense missions are fun, as is the relay station upgrade system. The yetis are rather underwhelming unfortunately. Even on the hardest difficulty, I never died to one. Still a fun, worthwhile experience in my opinion. I'd give it a 7/10.

So hello everyone. Has been a while since I did review something. so thought it will be the time.
I would like to mention that yeah I'm aware of this game's age. its nearly 9 years old at the time of making this review but honestly I still wanted to share the experience and see how the game is doing.
This wasn't my first playthrough at all, I played the game on the Xbox 360 for the first time but of course. I wanted to experience this game at its max on a high end PC. (9900K+RTX 3080).

Far Cry 4 is a good step forward over the third game in the series by a large margin. not only you get large graphical improvements but overall, the game itself is deeper in terms of the story, adds more variety with your options as a player and in general is annoying more challenging but also felt unique.

Graphics - yeah, the game is old as it came out in 2014 but if I gotta be honest. it doesn't fall off from newer titles by much and looks like way ahead of its time and at maximum settings with high FPS. It was an amazing experience but even on the Xbox 360 which was nearly 10 years when this game came out. it looked reasonably well despite the limitations of the given hardware. overall, the game aged well with lighting and general texture quality + effects.

Story - FC3 was a parody in that regard, it was about Vaas and purely about him. but FC4 did expend upon the idea and gave us more possible views to understand the game by introducing multiple high priority characters and also introducing the element of choice which would affect the outcome of the game. choosing between Sabal and Amita will give you different missions in game. similar but with a different taste

Gameplay - Taking Radio stations feels at times much more difficult as now you have an actual challenge that you need to deal with which is "how I get to the top floor". on FC3 it was simply a ladder while FC4 is far more like a puzzle inspired by platformers.
Then we get to the option of riding an elephant and the introduction of the Bazzer which makes matter so much more comfortable when it comes to long distance rides.

In conclusion? 9/10.
FC4 was indeed an awesome experience that I would people to check it out but unfortunately it wasn't all perfect. FPS drops from time to time (130-140 to 65), Wingsuit being utterly annoying to use and the game doesn't tell at times how to interact with certain items if you are low on HP. but overall. it was an awesome experience and I was glad to revisit the game once more.

Like the other Far Cry games, this one is very visually pleasing and the gameplay is a lot of fun.  The main character isn't an empty shell and is easy to get behind.  I actually prefer the weapons in this game over the ones in 5 and New Dawn.  There's a lot of discussion about how the antagonist is one of the most likable of the franchise.  Indeed, he is charismatic, but I wouldn't say I "like" him.  He's a whackjob dictator who oppresses his people.  Players have a few choices when it comes to the game's outcome, but nothing too impactful.  The plot and story are average, but not bad.  You basically have only two choices at any given moment and none of them are really winners.  You can side with an old-fashioned dude who's traditions consist of women being married in their teens and not treated as equals, or a friggin' harpy who wants to turn the country into a drug state in the name of her warped vision of progress.  Like I said, no real winners there.

I'd have to say my biggest beef was with that Rabi Ray Rana (that Radio Free Kyrat clown).  I know he's a radio personality, but even by those standards he can't seem hear enough of his own voice.  Not to mention the crap he talks about is just stupid.  I'd rather hear the music, or even the propaganda, thanks.

Few bugs here and there, but nothing really game-breaking unless you somehow get stuck outside the map like I did once.  The most frustrating thing is when you're wingsuiting and you brush the side of a tree for an insta-kill.

Overall, if you liked 3, Primal, 5 or New Dawn, you'll like this one.

Compared to Farcry 3, the story is worse. Jason Brody was a party guy with his friends, and his character developed into a psychotic warrior who could kill at a moment's notice. He was a survivor. On his first kill, he actually seems somewhat hesitant and guilty. The story was very consistent. The main character grew, rescued his friends and brother, but became a monster. The two endings allow you to embrace your inner animal and die like one, or remember why you started and save your friends. The story asks "What have you become?" Are you a survivor or an animal?

In FC4, the mc just casually starts killing people. It's really weird. A normal person from the states wouldn't be like that. If you look him up on the wiki he served in the us special forces, but that's not well explained in game. There's no logical reason to leave when the villain tells you to sit and eat. No one wanted to get "rescued" by the golden path. Why is he volunteering to go on these suicidal missions? The golden path ends up being even worse than the previous dictator. You either turn the country into a drug den or let it languish into poverty. I'd call this storytelling noire. He also doesn't really grow as a character either. The story asks "Why are you doing this?" And I don't have an answer. Pang is "a bad guy?" OK, what does that make you? Turning the country into an impoverished starvation bin? Turning it into a drug den so it can profit off of other people's suffering?

Compared to Farcry 3, the gameplay is better. The environment is beautiful, the challenges are more tactical. Scouting is easier and your arsenal is larger. I found the bow much less useful then the previous game, but the rest of the kit was exceptional. The son of Mohan is much stronger than jason brody. But his enemies are stronger too.

Overall I would only recommend this game if you don't care about the story and just want more FC3 gameplay. Other than that this game feels like an attack on the player. It effectively insults you for enjoying killing in your spare time.

The foundation of a typical Nepali meal is a cereal cooked in plain fashion, and complemented with flavourful savoury dishes. The latter includes lentils, pulses and vegetables spiced commonly with ginger and garlic, but also more discerningly with a combination of spices that may include coriander, cumin, turmeric, cinnamon, cardamon, jimbu and others as informed by culinary conventions. In an actual meal, this mental representation takes the form of a platter, or thali, with a central place for the cooked cereal, peripheral ones, often in small bowls, for the flavourful accompaniments, and the simultaneous, rather than piecemeal, ingestion of the two in each act of eating, whether by actual mixingâ€”for example of rice and lentilsâ€”or in the folding of oneâ€”such as breadâ€”around the other, such as cooked vegetables. Dal-bhat, centred around steamed rice is the most common example. as well as dairy and sometimes meat, is the most common and prominent example. The unleavened flat bread made from wheat flour called chapati occasionally replaces the steamed rice, particularly in the Terai, while Dhindo, prepared by boiling corn, millet or buckwheat flour in water, continuously stirring and adding flour until thick, almost solid consistency is reached, is the main substitute in the hills and mountains. Tsampa, flour made from roasted barley or naked barley, is the main staple in the high himalayas. Throughout Nepal, fermented, then sun-dried, leafy greens called Gundruk, are both a delicacy and a vital substitute for fresh vegetables in the winter.

TLDR: buggy mess of a game

Ubisoft's last far cry with decent storytelling and game mechanics. Unfortunately, 8 years and several games later, that suffer from the same issues, Ubi developers put out unfinished products every single year. It's the game I probably put the most time in, and I've only recently ported to PC, and I can't bear myself to play anymore, the game has by far the best stealth system, in theory only, in practice, the developers make it feel like it was rushed in a couple of weeks with 0 playtesting. I won't focus much on loud gameplay since it's very basic and there's not much to talk about. The worst offenders are the character controller and the dogshit AI. To keep it short, the movement feels very stiff, you bounce off anything Ubisoft didn't intend you to be able to climb onto, which is the case for the vast majority of ledges, not to mention the awful delay to having the climb button pop up, EXTRA: (which is present even in takedowns, I've failed plenty of stealth attempts because I would press F too quickly and the game wouldn't register it as a takedown and as a melee hit, which no matter where it lands, it alerts the guard in front of you alongside the entire map. The AI is awful, in most cases the moment they spot you or hear noise(bullet passing by their head/hitting some surface close to them, the gun itself[silenced weapons still make noise], running or walking) they alert the entire map even if they are killed the next second, thus the only way you can kill enemies is by landing one-shots and takedowns as even an extra bullet hitting their corpse will alert the enemies near.
Animals are superior to humans in almost every way, they soak bullets like an armored enemy unit to the point where it takes two sniper shots to take out a small dog, which has the power to instantly alert the entire map once it starts barking. )

In conclusion, Ubisoft will go out of their way to ensure you play their way and to have the least fun possible. Every action you do has an animation for it(climbing on a small elevated surface? the game climbs on top or over instead of letting you jump on top), the game wants you to play stealth as slow as possible, because of the awful movement system, running around taking out enemies fast is very difficult and takes a lot of skill since you're trying to get around all this crap, and it's the only reason I'm still playing the game. 

You'd think they'd fix all this in the future games, and while stealth is easier because of the brain dead AI, the exact same issues are still present, reason why I cannot stand the stealth in FC5, it's a buggy unfinished mess. FC6 does fix a couple of them, but manages to introduce others. I'm not even going to consider trying out the next Far Cry, since I know for certain it will suffer from the same problems as it predecesors.

Some people really like to downplay just how good of a game Far Cry 4 really is just because it's one of the later titles in the franchise. Right off the bat, the game is super familiar to it's precursors, and its graphics have improved drastically; it is an insanely beautiful game. Though not too much changes apart from the more high-definition textures and higher quality cutscenes. Even the UI is practically an exact replica, just designed the slightest bit better. Again, it's no surprise considering this game came out two years after its previous mainline title. But I would describe Far Cry 4 as a different experience entirely, despite carrying over a lot of the features from its predecessors.

Because this world is set in the Himalayas, Far Cry 4 gives you a plethora of locations to use your wingsuit, alongside the new addition of the grappling hook. The map is designed very well, and doesn't at all feel bloated. Loot and collectibles populate the map just enough that exploration isn't quite the hassle that it would be in other open-world games. Something I appreciate about this game is that it really likes to emphasize on its inclusion of animals. Stealth has become much more fun with the addition of bait, and the ability to ride elephants into battle adds a new spin to combat.

Although not much of the gunplay has changed since its predecessors, some of these guns are still quite powerful. If you struggle to get past story missions, it might be worth it to invest in the Buzzsaw and the Auto-Cross early game. The Buzzsaw just straight mows down tank enemies like it's no problem, and the Auto-Cross is basically just a throwing knife but a bow. These guns really made every mission after obtaining them feel like a breeze to get past. Fortunately, you get both of these as a reward for liberating the 17 Bell Towers, which makes exploration a must. My personal loadout includes the Buzzsaw, Auto-Cross, Bushman and the M-79 just for good measure.

Before Far Cry 3, the franchise never really had a status of creating the 'larger-than-life' villains that they do today. I think that Pagan Min really helped solidify that for Far Cry; him and Vaas are usually the two characters that come to mind when someone says 'Far Cry villain'. I think that because of him, this game exudes a type of charisma you genuinely wouldn't find in other Far Cry titles.

Having to live up to the expectations of Far Cry 3 must have been quite difficult to do. Since 3's whole schtick was that the kill count you rack up throughout your playthrough completely demoralizes you by the end of the story, that concept was something really unique and one that couldn't be replicated by it's successors. I think that Far Cry 4's story still does a good job at presenting the player a moral dilemma in the first place. If you're going into it blindfolded, it can definitely be quite charming and clever. I personally enjoyed it, anyway. The story ends in four different ways, with two epilogues based on which person you chose to lead the Golden Path. It's worth it for you to try and figure out some of these endings on your own. Just make sure to regularly back up your saves. This is especially important after the Payback mission.

This game really makes you FEEL like you have a father figure that genuinely cares about you.

This is such an awful game. 

I enjoy the Far Cry series, I've played most of them. I enjoy the loop of expanding the map, liberating outposts, unlocking more guns, yadda yadda. 

This entry is just awful. It literally SEEKS to make every step of the way more unfun. 

- The game takes place in the freakin' HIMALAYAS but anything sharper than a 35 degree incline will make you slide down. 

- Where in the world are eagles legitimate threats to humans? Anywhere? Well in this game they are ever-present and will take your health down to zero even after health upgrades. EVEN THE NPCS are constantly screaming about them. I'm not even kidding. 

- You want to walk a mere 100km to get to a mission start? Sorry, there's a pack of wild dogs. Now your ammo is gone. Gotta go back and refill. Oh wait sorry also now you have to go back and defend an outpost you already liberated. Oh wait now there's two or four "Karma" objectives in your way too. 

- Within the first hour of the game my "wallet" was full??? I had to go out of my way to kill a specific animal just to increase my wallet size to over 250k??? Who thought this was a good idea. 

- Same as above within first hour but for the worthless "loot" bag. Loot is just random nouns you extract from chests that serve as nothing more to turn into money at stores. But oh wait you can't do that right now because your wallet is full. (Can I open up a savings account or something???) I CANT CARRY ANYTHING ANYMORE. 

- The acting, per usual, is pretty quality, but holy shit I don't have patience for this dude to do his best King Lear monologue after all the aforementioned has exhausted my patience with this game. 

- Speaking of the acting, you will be pulled between two main protagonist characters and whomever you choose you will literally have to sit through extended cutscenes where the other is just berating you for choosing that way. Again, who thought this would make the game enjoyable?

- There's an early mission where you are transported to the high Himalayas, wind and snow whipping everywhere, an Oxygen meter (aka a timer), and it ends up being a glorified fetch mission where you go to four corners of the map to loot bodies to find nothing. And while I was doing this mission, there was a point where whilst getting shot at, I was also attacked by TWO mountain lions and an eagle at the same time. Did anyone stop to think if any of this crap would be fun?

- The healing system is stupid.

- There's a gladiator arena in the Himalayas??? Ridiculousness aside, again, this is an unfun mission that they also will let you go back to play again and again (no thanks). 

- There's a set of missions where you're always "tripping out" and while I guess creative they are just frustrating and confusing. 

- Hipfire headshots are easier to hit than looking down the sights. 

If you really want to play Far Cry, go play 2, 3, or 5.

Far Cry 4 is, strangely enough, the fourth main game in the Far Cry franchise. You play as Ajay Ghale, the son of Kyrati freedom fighter Mohan Ghale, who is returning to his mother's home nation of Kyrat to spread her ashes after moving to the United States when you were a child. You're caught in the middle of a political struggle between eccentric zealot Pagan Min (who claims he had a relationship with your late mother) and the Golden Path, a rebel group attempting to wrest control of the current regime. After being rescued and recruited by the Path, you have to choose between the differing approaches of their two leaders: Sabal, a traditionalist, wants to protect people and honor the ways of the Path, while Amita, the radicalist, wants to try new, controversial angles and stop playing by the Path's rules. This is the core story, and while the idea of choice in the narrative and mission structure is interesting, the fact that neither Sabal nor Amita ever seem to be best option kinda removes that illusion a little bit. I honestly wish there was a third option to balance out the choices just a little bit more. The story is also pretty paper thin, there's not much more nuance outside of the core premise. 

The gameplay is very similar to Far Cry 3, with the game being mostly open world (parts of the world open up as you progress through the story) and the ability to choose multiple approaches to any confrontation is still a really fun aspect of these games. I, however, think this game's mechanics are more fun that 3's, with the addition of new weapon, riding elephants, driving flying vehicles, and more helping to give you even more routes to success. Capturing radio towers to clear up the map and raiding outposts are still the main non-story world activities, but there are additional missions including hunting rare animals, finding and delivering supply drops, and Karma missions that affect your stock with the Golden Path that add more variation to when you're just farting around in the open world.

The graphics in this game are still great to this day. Character designs are vibrant and interesting, the world is gorgeous and feels very similar to traditional Pan-Asian and Indian culture, and the HUD is clean. Voice acting is well performed and the game can occasionally bug out, but more often than not the result is hilarious rather than intrusive. Ultimately, I'd give it an 8/10, a very fun open world shooter with a predictable but serviceable story.

What's it like playing Far Cry 4 in 2022? Still fun if you like the Far Cry formula, which gives you plenty of things to do in a massive and still graphically impressive open-world setting. The trick with all the Far Cry games, I think, is not to get sucked into completing everything. Different players will enjoy different kinds of missions, so I'd recommend resisting the obsessive urge to complete and collect to 100% and just do what's fun. Even then, Far Cry 4 offers a good 50-60hrs of gameplay. OCD completionists might clock in twice as many hours.

Personally, I find unlocking towers and taking out outposts undetected the most enjoyable aspect of the game - combined with the open-world exploration and the relaxing 'puzzle game' aspect of negotiating the landscape to find treasures, masks, letters and whatnot. It's only when this open-world gameplay narrows down in certain scripted missions that the fun factor can diminish and frustration levels rise. I generally avoided anything involving escorting supply trucks, beating the clock, or bossfights - but that's just me. It's all very subjective and I guess it's to the credit of the Far Cry DEVs that so much is put on the table for you to choose from.

On my system (GTX1080, i7 9700k, 16MB DDR4 3200 RAM), the game ran well at 1440p almost maxed out. Following online advice (and some crashes - especially in the Shangri-La missions), I avoided any of the special Nvidia settings and turned off the fur effects. Using 4xMSAA, the game typically ran at 50-80FPS at Ultra.

What about the story? Do we play Far Cry games for the story? I guess it's OK. Pagan Min is an engaging villain (if that's the right word) and your character Ajay isn't the annoying frat-boy that Far Cry 3's tonally deaf protagonist was. Of course, you 'win' the game basically by shooting almost everything and everyone in sight, so I wasn't sure what all those karma points earned really amounted to. That's when I spared a thought for it in the interludes between indulging the glorious power fantasy, blood-frenzy of the OP and aptly named Buzzsaw. I know. Coming back as a cockroach, right?

Particular likes? The more vertical aspect of the Far Cry landscape is fun. The wee Buzzer helicopter is a neat addition that is fun to fly and that helps traversing the game's alpine settings. Of course, you still have the hang-gliders, wingsuit, etc.

I thought the Shangri-La missions were imaginative and striking, and that they presented a great contrast to the regular game-play.

Particular dislikes: the Steam/U-play interface is tiresome to negotiate when starting up the game

Only a single save slot

This is just a really good game. It has a very interesting storyline with multi-faceted characters. The graphics, especially the character rendering is beautiful. What I found amazing was that the animators were able to convey subtleties like body language so easily -- it was truly like watching a movie. I would have liked a little more of the backstory to be spelled out, by the time I had finished the game, I was still a bit confused as to who had done what to whom, and what was motivating the story. As far as the game play is concerned, as other reviewers have said, it is a Far Cry game, if you have played any of the others, you know what to expect. If you haven't: the game gives you the option to use stealth, or brute force. I greatly enjoy playing with stealth. There are a fun variety of vehicles, including mini-helicopters, speed boats, and elephants. Some of the vehicle controls were a little fussy, but on the whole, they were easy to get the hang of. A nice variety of weapons to choose from, again, allowing you to play towards stealth or brute force. My biggest complaints were the game play was HUGE with fewer respawn spots than I would like, meaning you could spend an hour crossing the map, only to get killed in a random accident and respawn back where you started, forcing you to do the whole thing all over again. My other complaint is that I did not think that there were enough Experience Points upgrades. About halfway through the game, I had leveled up my character almost to the maximum and had purchased or won most of the weapons. After that, I didn't feel much motivation to go on side-quests because while I kept earning Experience Points, I didn't have anything to spend them on. These are fairly minor complaints, though, on the whole an excellent game!

My favorite Far Cry game ever. The setting and story are great, although FC3's story is better. However, the gameplay more than makes up for it. This game has by far the most amount and most diversity in weapons of any Far Cry game that I've played (3, 4, 5, Blood Dragon). Compared to FC3, lots of game mechanics have been improved, making the gameplay much smoother than it was in FC3. I'm not going much into detail here, but I'm talking about little changes here and there. The graphics are a lot better too! The music chosen in this game (most of it from The Bombay Royale) fits the setting and Indian/Nepali culture beautifully. The Himalayas are beautiful, and the wildlife is fantastic too. The eagles are a bit annoying sometimes though.

Pagan Min might not have a lot of screen time, but I like him. He comes across as mannered, organized, yet insane at some level. He often contacts you through your radio and rambles a bit. It's pretty funny sometimes. There's a lot of mystery surrounding Ajay's parents, specifically the relationship between his mother (Ishwari) and Pagan Min, and his father, Mohan.

The story is built on a moral dilemma between old, religious values (which is what Sabal wants) and modern values, centering profit and the economy (which is what Amita wants), For nearly every story mission, Sabal and Amita each have their own approach to completing it, and you choose which way to go. One of them will become the leader of the Golden Path at the end of the game.

I played Far Cry 4 when it first came out on a console. In the years that followed, I forgot everything except for the game's main villain, Pagan Min, and the little ramshackle helicopters I constantly crashed into trees. Returning to it years later on my gaming rig, I have found that it's still a fun, serviceable shooter with a lot of side content. Most of that side content is pretty samey, so a player's mileage may vary. Pagan Min remains a highlight and the primary draw of the game's story for me. He is probably second only to Handsome Jack in terms of "over the radio" banter with the player character. I feel that this is the last time that Far Cry came close to making an actual statement with the story it told, so its worth experiencing that too, especially if you've never played it before.

By far the most underrated Farcry game: gameplay refinement hits its peak, and while the many prefer Vaas to Pagan Minn and the protagonist of Far Cry 3, Ajay Gale has a much deeper connection to Kyrat and Pagan Minn specifically which adds quite a bit of intrigue and depth to the story if you want to engage with it on that level.

Play with a bow/crossbow, lean into stealth/takedowns and use your guns sparingly. Lean hard into creative takedowns (you can jump assassinate really often if you are creative) and you will have a blast with a surprisingly deep and free form spectacle stealth shooter. Game really specialises at making you feel like a badass.

Honestly, you don't need to beat the game to know that Far Cry 4 isn't a step up compared to Far Cry 3 (Far Cry 4 even steps back in several aspects when compared to the previous release; Far Cry 4 stumbled and it got up thinking that no one had seen it. I can't play this game without thinking all the time that I'm not playing "Far Cry 4", if not, that I'm playing Far Cry 3 with mods, this feeling is shocking once I you finish Far Cry 3 and start Far Cry 4, that realization hits you like a truck. Really the improvement is MINIMUM; same gameplay, same mechanics, with the exception of something new, because of course, they can't sell you the same game twice... RIGHT?.

Keeping the core of a game with each new release is not bad, it's something that many franchises do, but we have to learn that keeping the core of the game does not mean recycling the same things from the previous games: Better graphics and different characters is not a "new game".

In matters of history I do not recommend this game either, it makes no sense. Although Far Cry 3 did not have the most credible story, the characters were charismatic, they had reasons to do what they were doing, FR 3 left memorable characters that people still remember today. But what about Far Cry 4? More of the same but worst implemented, another crazy villain who has an army of people at his disposal, how original. Ajay is the flattest thing that exists, this character has no motivation, no personality: "Oh yes, I came to this island to fulfill my family's last wish, I don't know anyone, I'm not a soldier, I have no experience in combat and I've probably never killed anyone, but I'm going to help the people on this island (people I don't know) who are at war, who have hundreds of soldiers with more experience than me, but who are completely incompetent and can't move forward until a nobody, son of a supposed legend shows up. And now I, like I said, not being a soldier and not having any military experience, I'm going to take out entire armies myself because that's what the script says." I'm not going to talk about Amita and Sabal, it's physically impossible for me not to fall asleep while these characters are talking, flat and filler characters, useless more than anything. Pagan is another character who at first seems to be the only interesting character, but he is completely another excuse and completely boring. It's hard for me to empathize with the characters in this game, they don't seem memorable to me, they seem boring.

The only reason to buy this game (And even then, it doesn't seem like a good enough reason to me), is if you like the Far Cry 3 gameplay loop, since it's the same thing; You free the towers, clear camps full of enemies and shoot everything that moves. Do not buy this game thinking that it will be a new experience. Far Cry 3 is a better game, if for some reason you haven't played it and are thinking of starting with Far Cry 4, go for FR 3 and don't waste your time with this game.

This game really gets on my nerves. 

The graphics look very nice when standing still, However as soon as I move in this game there's like a visible zone a couple of meters infront of the character where the graphics change to the better (Pixelated Artifacting). It's ugly as hell seeing shadows and textures change as I move back and forth. Apparently it's part of how the engine works to reduce pop-ins but it looks horrible. 

The fights are decent but there's so much annoying crap. Quick time events, slopes you can't climb normally, constant animal attacks that makes the game feel so retarded. Mixing bears, wolfs, tigers, elephants, eagles all in these areas is so dumb. They really needed to tone down the animals aggression and numbers. It's laughable how many tigers and other predators there are running around attacking humans. I'm surprised they didn't add polar bears as well. 

There's a whole myriad of things that just feels badly balanced and wrong. 
Being able to deploy the wing suit 5 feet above ground from you moving at running speed jumping over some tiny rock. Dying from wing suit by touching a branch.
Dying or getting seriously injured from a 1m drop of a ledge or something. 
Shooting animals or people with a high powered sniper rifle in the chest and they take 2-3 hits before going down. 
The story characters blabbering on radio for minutes about total random bullsh*t I don't wanna hear and being unable to skip it.

The story is a joke. I started the campaign and got a choice of two missions. Because I choose to help get some intel the other guy is now actually accusing me of not saving his men from the other mission. I can't believe they actually wrote this garbage. Even if the rebellion was only made up of the three people involved and the law of physics only allowed one mission to be carried out at the same time, he still has the gall to blame the player character for something he could have done himself. It's not like he's in a wheelchair or anything. The very idea that the player character who just arrived and started to help is now somehow sole responsible for their whole combat operations is laughable and retarded.
Normally games try hard to make a player feel like they are part of a large organization, here instead they tell you outright that you are the only person fighting and handling everything. It's beyond retarded. 

I seriously hate most of the allied NPCs and I straight up want to murder Reggie and Yogi along with rabi ray rana and join pagan min. 

The franchises love of mixing in pointless and stupid drug sequences is baffling and does nothing but trivialise story and boss elements.

The commonly used phrase "wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle" comes to mind several times playing this game.

After playing Far Cry 3 and enjoying that game so much, I was destined to play another Far Cry game, and that lead me to Far Cry 4!   I saw the screenshots, saw the trailer, I thought to myself, this game looks stunning, and it was, so I contemplated it for a while, then I broke down and bought it.   The game is a lot of fun, I really enjoyed every hour of it, and it's a beautiful, vibrant, colorful game.

  Story: You are Ajay Ghale who's returned to Kyrate to achieve his mothers last dying wish, and that's to spread her ashes at Lakshmana.  But, Ajay finds himself trapped in the middle of a war between, The Golden Path, The Royal Army, and Pagan Min a corrupt dictator.  It's up to Ajay to decide which side of The Golden Path he wishes to help most, and in the end to debate who gets control.   

  The gameplay I find to be rather smooth and tons of fun creating chaos.  Only complaint is the Damned EAGLE!!!!!!!  The Eagles are a pain, but just keep a look out, cause they do massive damage causing you to use a syringe.

The AI is rather stupid, lol!  I don't know what it is, but NPC's for some reason will run right into your Vehical, dying, and the game will tell you to not kill civilians.  My bad, the guy just ran in front of me, instead of getting out of my way!  

Keeping this short, I'd recommend playing if you wanna get into Far Cry, or go Buy Far Cry 3, still a great game.

Ah yes Far cry 4 the middle child of sorts. I originally finished playing through this multiple times a year after it's release, but back then I had bought a physical copy of the game which I unfortunately lost. So when I saw that the gold edition with all the DLCs were on sale on steam I was bought it because all the nostalgia of trekking through the Kyrat's borderline mystical setting came flooding in.I am one of those people that severely missed the immersion Far Cry 2 conveyed through it's environment and overall gritty aesthetics, I felt that Far Cry 3 was lacking in that sense, but it seems that Ubisoft picked up on that factor when making Far Cry 4 because the immersion I have felt in this game is very similar to that of Far Cry 2. Even after picking it up in 2022 I am still mesmerised by Kyrat just like I was the first time I played the game. Maybe it is because I can resonate with the setting a lot. The small bits of Hindi spoken by the grunts, old Indian movie songs played by Rabi Ray, the mythology and the snowy mountains all remind of me places that I have gone to. The exploration, the environmental storytelling when uncovering Yalung's masks, and of course Shangri-La all form an intriguing setting. The different environments and the various types of guns all fir in well with the story. Although the main quest may be dogwater compared to Far Cry 3, the rest of the game is exceptional. I wouldn't buy it full price though. Wait for the gold edition to go on sale and then buy. It is an old game and the graphics might not be upto the taste of newer player, but the game is breathtaking. The outposts are also very well designed and the strongholds will be very challenging. Would recommend over the cut and dry Montana setting of Far Cry 5.

Far Cry 4 was a definite hit and successor to Far Cry 3 when it was released in 2014. It built much and improved on many areas than its predecessor but kept the original aesthetic Far Cry games are known for.

I for one, believe that Ubisoft creates some of the best gaming introductions and villains. Far Cry 4 is no exception, the intro to this game is classic and really gives you as a player an insight and thought on what you are about to embark on.

You are the protagonist Ajay Ghale in a Himalayan based countryside but a fictional area called Kyrat. Kryat is riddled with Narco- Guerrillas, rich Kirati inspired cultural history, and an ongoing civil war between the rebel Golden Path and the forces of Pagan Min. The game draws heavily from Nepalese influences including drawing the games real world design, gameplay and characters from local other countries, cultures and lore. 

There is much on improvement here, in terms of graphics, a diverse but very dense and large map, new weapons, animals to hunt, challenges, side quests, locations to explore.  Things such as utilizing and riding elephants, flying miniature helicopters called a gyro copter. You have the choice to attack with brute force or to have a stealthy approach. They have also introduced fortresses which are much tougher than a simple compound and require more planning before attacking. You are also encouraged to do other quests from a range of characters in the game to proceed further in the story as well as increase your skill points to use.

I have to applaud the characters in this game, incredible really. Golden path characters like Sabal and Amita struggling for power with one another while trying to lead the Country in the best way they see politically, traditionally, progressively and resourcefully fit. Whilst Pagan Min is the acclaimed antagonist to the story and is of a some what eccentric, calculated but a calm character, with his passive aggressive and carefree attitude takes on a different personality approach to previous, predictable hardcore villains in other games. 

There are also other side kicks and goons to both sides who bring richness and a story of there own which ties into the realm of and predominantly are dominoes to the story that is Kyrat.

I will say that, the game also at times is not without its psychedelic qualities. Taking you on many paths which appear hallucinogenic and transmundane like. As the player you will have choices along the golden path as the symbol of the people and this will reflect what occurs at the end of the game. 

I did not have many technical issues with this game if at all. It still requires Ubisoft interface to connect to whilst playing.

The "Modern Warfare 2" to FC3's "Modern Warfare". It's FC3 with more sandbox tools, a weaker story, co-op gameplay, and Himalayan setting. It doesn't have the same charisma that FC3 had, and you wont be as invested in the main character as FC3, but its still totally worth your time.

PROS:
- Gameplay variety that actually uses the new mechanics without being gimmicky.
- Kept the FC3 mechanics that worked well.
- Fun and unique setting.
- Great gameplay feel, guns feel and sound great. I'll come back to play this game just for the elephant gun alone.
- Co-op play is a good addition, but is pretty restricted.
- Great bang for your buck. This game has a surprising amount of content, even it's not immediately obvious.

CONS:
- Forgettable story
- Forgettable characters all around. Protagonist is forgettable. Side villains are forgettable. Other main characters are forgettable, etc.
- The only characters I can actively remember from this game are the Radio DJ, and the main villain.

CONCLUSION:
If you liked FC3 for the gameplay loop, this game is for you. It's surprisingly easy to waste 10-20 hours in FC4 just messing around and trying out different gameplay styles. While it doesn't have FC3's charisma or character moments, this game very much has a charm of it's own. It's story and characters might be forgettable, but you'll remember the gameplay moments you create for yourself.

Oh, and the Signature weapon "Buzzsaw" is basically a cheat weapon. Join co-op with someone who has it, have them give it to you in the early game to unlock it permanently- and leave a path of destruction in your wake.

One of my personal favorites of the Far Cry franchise, exploration of the Himalayan map brings a fresh new feeling to this new and unique story, which allows you to shape the future of a nation at war. Various updates to old User Interfaces has made the day to day usage of various menus and maps much more enjoyable and smooth.

Far Cry 4 takes what Far Cry 3 does good, and does it ever so slightly better. Similar to Far Cry 3, you essentially start as an outsider, who evolves into a one man army, taking down the bad guy, who is a dictator by the name of Pagan Min, who is in a war with a faction known as the Golden Path, lead by Amita and Sabal, two very different people, with very different ideas for Kyrat's future.

Ajay as a protagonist starts out boring, and ends up - boring as you dont learn much about him. He does not seem to have any kind of reaction about suddenly being put into the middle of a raw civil war in a foreing country although that could be chalked up to the fact that according to the lore, Ajay was in the army when he was younger, and was fully aware that there was a civil war going on in Kyrat when he arrived. Right from the start you're thrown in to the action, and treated as the key piece to winning the war and everyone just accepts that, and the members of the Golden Path promise to help you accomplish the goal you came there  to do, scatter your mother's ashes at the peak of the highest mountain in Kyrat. 
As for other characters, I enjoyed the conflict between Amita and Sabal and how it intensified as the storyline progressed. As a returning character, we get to once again see Willis, who in Far Cry 3 was a delight, but in Far Cry 4 he was turned into an unlikeable douche. 

Kyrat as a map was beautiful, and the missions that took place in Shangri La were also a fun change of pace, though they were incredibly linear compared to the main game. 

While the gameplay is enjoyable and you can approach missions either guns blazing with grenade launchers and flamethrowers in your arsenal, or as an assassin sneaking around with simply a bow and your knife as your companions, towards the end I felt the game kept dragging on and getting repetitive. 

Many upgrades and weapons in the game are locked behind you completing additional tasks around the map, such as taking over radio towers, or killing animals for their skins, to craft equipment that would allow you to expand your arsenal, and the only drawback in that system is that some of the animals tend to be overpowered, and you can sometimes  even get stunlocked and die to an animal while trying to kill it to upgrade something you need.

Overall I'd say it was easily worth the 10â‚¬ I spent on it, and I would recommend the game to anyone who is reading this, especially if you're looking for a gameplay experience similar to Far Cry 3.

A game that makes you wonder why more villains donâ€™t wear snazzy suits: +5 to CHA/10

-REVIEW-

Imagine youâ€™re a young adult going back to the country of your birth, attempting to honor the last wish of your late mother to bring her ashes home, only to find yourself caught up in a civil war between the haughty rich and the desperate poor, doing whatever you can to hopefully unseat the horrible dictator if only it will get you closer to fulfilling your parentâ€™s last request.

Now imagine trying to remind yourself how important that task is while a local radio DJ spits out a bunch of material that constantly wavers between chuckle-worthy and cringe inducing. Yeah, this game is a bit more comical than the last, but donâ€™t let that scare you off-itâ€™s actually a lot of fun, and definitely improved on quite a few things from Far Cry 3.

Letâ€™s start with the story, an element that, while still very enjoyable, Iâ€™m admittedly a bit divisive on. Ajay Ghale(yes, itâ€™s pronounced more than one way in the game, so Iâ€™ll leave how you say it up to you) is coming home to return the ashes of his mother to her home country of Kyrat. His arrival in the country is a rather unpleasant one; he gets caught in the middle of a standoff between country officials and a group of rebels. He survives the minor onslaught, only to meet with Pagan Min, the ruler of Kyrat that rocks an arrogant mindset as much as he rocks a snazzy tux. From there, Ajay has a couple choices: listen to Pagan and be done with the game in 15 minutes(Iâ€™m pretty sure the whole world knows about this secret by now) or escaping the palace and, you know, PLAYING THE GAME, where Ajay will wind up joining with a movement called the Golden Path, a resistance movement started by Ajayâ€™s late father, hoping to topple Paganâ€™s regime. Only with their aid does Ajay have a chance at returning his motherâ€™s ashes to their proper resting place.

The question is, is this story better than Far Cry 3? Iâ€™ll be honest, itâ€™s a tough question for me to answer. For one, FC4 definitely has a more interesting world, as thereâ€™s not just an evil group to stop, but also a team of allies to help. Furthermore, the Golden Path itself is caught in itâ€™s own civil unrest, thanks to its two leaders, Sabal and Amita, constantly at each otherâ€™s throats over what path the movement should take. Amita favors more equality between genders and dropping outdated traditions, but isnâ€™t above using unsavory means to make the group prosper, including profit by drugs and forced conscription. Sabal favors a more traditional foundation meant to preserve the groupâ€™s honor, but has no issue with denying womenâ€™s rights, executing Amitaâ€™s supporters, and putting a girl named Bhadra in a supposedly honorable position that is likely far more unsavory than it sounds. It makes for quite an interesting scenario.

That said, what I donâ€™t like is that, while they are fun to talk to, most of the characters are pretty much there for getting quests from and thatâ€™s pretty much it. Itâ€™s kind of sad to be honest, especially since they all have enjoyable personalities; they can entertain you for sure, but only if they have a mission available. Far Cry 3â€™s side characters werenâ€™t a whole lot better, but the fact that most of them were friends that you had to rescue gave them a bit more purpose in the story, and they all had fun personalities to boot. Furthermore, Pagan Min, despite being an amazing villain, is simply not as good as Vaas. Pagan has what I call â€œSarevok Syndrome;â€ you see him at the beginning, and at the end, and one other short scene in a mountain prison, and thatâ€™s pretty much it. Iâ€™m not saying he had to be in every second of the game, but Vaas being around more in FC3 made him more exciting and unpredictable, as you had no idea when heâ€™d pop in to ruin things. Pagan, meanwhileâ€¦well, heâ€™s on the radio a few times! Yay?

Gameplay, on the other hand, is a definite improvement. Everything in this game is better. The gunplay feels better, animals are easier to find and hunt, skill point upgrades are more clearly defined in terms of when you can get them, driving is a bit more funâ€¦even the radio towers are better! The actual act of capturing outposts hasnâ€™t changed too much, but it still carries a good deal of excitement, especially when you go after lieutenant strongholds. The only thing I didnâ€™t really enjoy were the Shangri-La side missions, simply because it was hard to get used to fighting with only a magic bow and little else(it was still enjoyable in terms of mythology). Yeah, thereâ€™s a ton of stuff to do in this game(Thanks, Ubisoft), but like in the past, you donâ€™t have to do absolutely everything.

As is usually the case with ever increasing sequels(even if theyâ€™re indirect, as with this franchise), the graphics continue to improve, and this game looks really good, considering how old it is. Far Cry 3 already looked impressive to begin with, but this title raises the bar further still, especially in how the world looks. The character models are nice, but the island you move through, complete with forests, mountains, and even the interiors of strongholds, look very impressive. Sound design is also amazing, with well-performed voice acting(Troy Baker needs no introduction) and enjoyable music that, like in previous entries, amplifies the tribalistic setting that this game employs.

Say whatever you want about Ubisoft, but no matter how much they cling to old traditions. Sure they get old fast, and they certainly donâ€™t guarantee good games. That said, Far Cry 4 was a blast for me; it was simply a better version of FC 3 in so many ways. Thanks for reading!

What the hell is this crap?! This is an ugly Far Cry setting, boring story and the game is just NOT FUN.

OK, sure, buy this is you're absolutely DESPERATE for more Far Cry, because that's ALL it is, but there's no way you'll want to play this given the options of playing Far Cry 3, Far Cry 3 Blood Dragon, Far Cry 5, Far Cry New Dawn, Far Cry Primal, Crysis, Crysis Warhead, Crysis 2, Crysis 3, Fallout 4 or the Outer Worlds. There's simply nothing better about Far Cry 4 than any of these other open world games from approximately this same generation.

Above all, Far Cry 4 is by FAR the LEAST engaging setting and cast of characters I have ever seen in a Far Cry game, like, they're bad, as in PATHETIC. ALL YOU SEE IS MOUNTAINS IN FRONT OF YOUR FACE EVERYWHERE, IT DEFEATS THE PURPOSE OF THE FAR CRY SERIES' OPEN WORLD OF ALLURING VISTAS! As soon as I got into the game I simply didn't care about the entire place or any of its denizens, and the huge mountain valley thing is just a trashy way to make an open world game, you see nothing but steep hills, cliff faces and upward climbs everywhere you look and it's just a chore to navigate, as well as not being very pretty, despite standard Far Cry photorealism, on account of this kind of mountain valley environment being just boring to begin with, with a boring color palette and annoying rope-climbing obstacles literally everywhere to the point of it being a nuisance (you use a grappling hook, whoopie, it's freakin' LAME). The only way to have made this better would have been to completely axe the grappling hook in favor of making some legit alpinist parkour the equivalent of Mirror's Edge in the mountains, but I doubt Ubisoft would put THAT much effort into gameplay mechanics as they seem content to simply continue re-skinning Far Cry with minor adjustments, and, regardless, it WOULDN'T have made the setting any more palatable. It's just an ugly world, and not fun with nothing really cool about it beside it being more Far Cry if you're really that desperate.

In Far Cry 3 we had Vaas, one of the coolest and most memorable video-game villains since Sephiroth, and Citra, who was an engaging and sexy supporting character and eye-candy. Brody being a college kid in the islands with his friends, girlfriend and brother and getting caught up in bad business with Vaas was a great setup for adventure that felt like you were in a movie similar to something like The Beach or Into the Blue. Where does Far Cry 4 put you? IN NORTH KOREA? OK Kim-Jong Ubi, whatever, I'd rather be in the Vietnam War or something than fighting your weird, re-imagined hybrid of the KPA and the Khmer Rouge in the Tibetan Himalaya. I think the big thing here is that Ubi simply tried too hard to do something very different and none of it paid off.

I am not recommending playing this above any of the other games I mentioned, it's simply not worthwhile when it takes twice the disk space of the vastly superior and infinitely more entertaining Far Cry 3 and Blood Dragon games combined, which were actually fun gems, particularly for their time. Far Cry 4 is just more of the same done worse in a time when there are so many better games to invest your time in.

Good Fried Chicken Recipe:

In a large mixing bowl, whisk together buttermilk, hot sauce (optional, for added flavor), salt, and pepper in a mixing bowl. Add in chicken pieces. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate 4 hours.
When ready to cook, pour the vegetable oil in a skillet until it is about 3/4 inch deep. Heat to 350 degrees.
Prepare the breading by combining the flour, cornstarch, onion powder, garlic powder, oregano, basil, white pepper, cayenne pepper, paprika, and salt in a gallon sized resealable plastic bag or shallow dish. Mix it thoroughly.
Working one at a time, remove chicken pieces from buttermilk mixture. Shake it gently to remove the excess. Place it in the breading mix and coat thoroughly. Tap off the excess.
Place the breaded chicken into the 350 degree oil. Fry 3 or 4 pieces at a time. The chicken will drop the temperature of the oil so keep it as close to 350 degrees as possible. Fry each piece for 14 minutes, turning each piece about half way through, until the chicken reaches an internal temperature of 165 degrees F.
Remove from the oil and place on paper towels. Let them rest for at least 10 minutes before serving.

I loved Far Cry 3; everything about it was beautiful, from level design to combat mechanics. Far Cry 4 takes all that a step further. If you loved Far Cry 3 then give this a go, you won't be disappointed.

There's plenty of side missions and extra content to keep you busy for months; my first play through took me a little over 25 hours and that was nowhere near fully complete. Honestly, the open world is so well put together you'll find yourself just driving around, slotting the odd enemy you find or just hunting...just watch out for honey badgers, the vicsious little shits.

Storyline is solid enough, with the usual misanthropic Far Cry flavour to it proving once again that people really are just a bit crap, and no matter what you do, evil will usually find a way through one way or the other.

Graphics are good, game play and combat is smooth and there aren't too many bugs; I certainly didn't find any that were game breaking.

The one gripe I have, and it was the same with 3, is UPlay. I already have a similar piece of software...it's called Steam and it works just fine. The only bonus with it is it does give you the option of adding a weapon for free (if you have the UPlay points, obviously) and a weapon bundle for PvP. Honestly, I'd take not having that as a trade of for not having to have UPlay installed. 

Bottom line, go for it. It's certainly worth the full price (25.99 GBP at time of writing this) and if you have the opportunity to get it on sale then definitely go for it, because that'd be an absolute steal.
