It's unfinished.

Don't get me wrong, Troy Baker is #@$ing amazing, as always; and the writing clearly had a lot of love in it. 

However, you can tell that Ubisoft rushed this game. There are inexplicable and out-of-place rewards for what should be major achievements (tearing down all 150 propaganda posters, as an example, gives you "Bonus XP", in spite of the fact that the game is obviously almost over by then! Lost letters and journal pages are much the same, and no specific award is given for completing the Shangri-La storyline other than a decoration in a half-complete homestead.) What leads up to obvious final missions, like Mr. Chiffon's designer gear, is cut off with a literal letter about how he was "discovered" and forced to flee, which makes no sense. There are perhaps five characters you regularly talk to, which is enough for a good game that takes place in the middle of nowhere, but there are gaps in their story lines that make little sense.

Much of the art work is rehashed repeatedly, but is consistently treated like it's a brand-new, explorable thing. The map is packed down with an absurd density of busywork, but little original terrain or artwork. There are maybe six original enemies, none of which are particularly intelligent, and about as many vehicles.

The wingsuit is about as useful as a noose around the neck, as it feels like a coin flip whether landing is going to get you killed; meanwhile, wolves are taking half a clip of ammo and continuing to charge you like nothing's the matter. Traversing the map is virtually saturated with "random" karma events, which seem to consistently be "protect from animal", "kill lieutenant", "kill slaver", and "fight skirmish", which all amount to more-or-less the same thing. Most of the missions also amount to the same thing, with a weird lack of consistencyâ€”sometimes you have to loot a commander's dog tag, sometimes you have to kill him with a specific weapon and take a picture, sometimes you have to hide the body, but they never go into why or how.

By the end of it, I didn't give a hoot about anybody getting attacked by anything, I just wanted it over with. Only in FC4 can a snow leopard, a wolf, and an eagle fight over the same goat, and then immediately turn their weirdly-hunger-grazed attention to you. Yes, that did actually happen to me.

As I said, the writing is strong, but you can feel where the project went off the rails, and this is a tragedy as the foundation of the game is really good. I would recommend it on sale, but with reservations. If you're looking for a good blow-up-installations-in-exotic-locales game, I would suggest maybe a Just Cause game; or perhaps Far Cry 3.

This game had about six hours of great plot line, but stretched out into nearly thirty because of the sheer amount of busywork. Additionally note that Steam continues to count your play time as long as UPlay is open, so many of the reports of playtime are biased higher than they should be. I definitely didn't play for 70 hours; it just felt like I did, and it was a little belittling.

As much as I enjoyed Farcry 4 enough, I cannot recommend it to others. I particularly like FPS games but if you are grabbing this game for the open-world or the story there are so many better options. The world is so repetitive, every outpost, every fortress, every special mission area feels exactly the same. It's just old-style stone and wooden buildings, some rocks and some forest. Kyrat is supposed to be a country, but there are maybe 4 shanty villages across the entire map. No big towns at all, no modern infrastructure beyond a few military buildings. It just doesn't make sense for the narrative to be about this big revolution when there just aren't any people.

If you've played Far Cry 3 you've played this game. The side quests, outposts, everything about this game has been done before. And if you want to get the game for Pagan Min, he is barely in it. And much of the time you see him he isn't interacting directly with you unlike Vaas of Hoyt from 3.

If you are easily entertained maybe this is the game for you, but if you want to experience something new and have played Farcry already you should probably call it quits on the series. If you haven't played Farcry yet, play 2 or 3. I see no reason to make a point of playing this game.

Concealed in the towering Himalayas lies a nation saturated with tradition and violence. You play as Ajay Ghale, getting back to the nation of your birth, the lush backwoods and harsh snow covered peaks of Kyrat, to fulfill your mom's final request of spreading her remains on a place called Lakshmana. This huge and unpredictable nation offers its guests opportunity and risk. You rapidly end up caught in a rebellion to topple the brutal system of Pagan Min,  a figure known as much for his sense of style and charisma as for his cruelty and naked brutality. Exploring the treacherous landscape, you observe your not entirely set in stone by the decisions you make on the grounds of Kyrat as there is a fight for leadership between two characters namely, Sabal and Amita. 
In Far Cry 4, you'll conquer stronghold outposts and fortresses from the back of a 6-ton elephant and take to the skies as you rain down explosives from your gyro-copter. The upward scene of the Himalayas isn't simply a beautiful background, but a playground that urges the player to battle, hunt and explore, grappling cliffs or even launching in the air, diving into the valley beneath in a controlled free fall with your wing suit. 
You'll carry with you a truly unique armory of weapons that allow you to play your way, whether it's killing, sneaking or hard and fast attack. At the point when all else ends up short, animals can be your greatest partners or your most prominent hazard, as Kyrat's wild follows through on the guarantee of a genuine open world story processing factory.

Give it a try; it's always going to be my favourite Far Cry.

(first the negative, I'll try to put some positive after) I've played FC 1, 3, Primal, and now this, and this one so far is shaping up to be the worst. Some extraordinarily bad design and balancing choices were made with this game that just has me constantly thinking WTF??? By far the stupidest thing in this game is you constantly get attacked by hawks, and these hawks are MORE powerful than any other enemy in the game, in terms of how much damage they do to you. You'll be doing any number of normal game tasks from traveling to unlocking towers, fast travel points etc...and every 5 minutes a hawk will dive bomb you and take away 95% of your health (it seems to scale with your max health). Normally, when doing mundane tasks, this just means you have to waste a healing syringe, but if any other aggressive animals or NPCs are nearby, this means death. You'll take on entire camps filled with NPC enemies armed with assault rifles, flame throwers, sniper rifles etc...and the entire camp will still do LESS DAMAGE TO YOU THAN A SINGLE HAWK (I'm not exaggerating! it's that stupid!). If you hear a hawk scream, and then turn to face it and try to ADS with your gun to shoot it, YOU CAN'T! If the hawk gets within 15 feet of you, it forces you into an animation. Yes, it's still 15 feet away from you but, you can't ADS and shoot it! This is what makes it truly frustrating and the stupidest game feature I've ever seen in my 38 year PC gaming career (yes I've been playing PC games since 1984).

As if the hawk wasn't enough, other animals are also grossly overpowered. A little badger can also kill you in about 3 seconds, but takes 4 or 5 sniper shots to the head to take down. Yes, no animal in FC4 can be killed with a single sniper bullet to the head (as in real life). Tigers take 6 sniper bullets to the head, and badgers, the size of a small dog, take 4 or 5 (I forget). The problem is of course, that by the time you put the 3rd or 4th sniper bullet into their head, they are now in melee range, so it's literally impossible to kill ANYTHING with a sniper rifle before it reaches melee range and takes 95% of your health with each of their attacks. Yes, that's right - your sniper bullets (to the head) do about 15-20% of their health, and their melee attacks do 95% of your health regardless of where they hit. The enemy NPCs also seem to take way more bullets than a human should be capable of taking, but at least they are somewhat more balanced in that a bow can one shot kill them, even with a body shot. I do think it's silly though that you can kill NPC enemies way easier and faster with a bow and arrow, than you can with an AK-47. So every ounce of realism and immersion is destroyed in this game by poor design choices. This isn't vastly different than FC3, but FC4 is just constant stupidity with the hawks and other animals. The gameplay in FC3 was much less annoying, even though there were still slightly overpowered animals, it wasn't nearly as annoying as FC4.

You might think I am over complaining about the hawks, but trust me, within a few hours of playing the game, you will realize how f#$#$# stupid the hawks are, and how stupid it is that 5 sniper shots to the head of something isn't enough, and that animal will then kill you with 2 swipes.

Other semi-negatives - I mean it's basically FC3, but worse. Let's face it, FC games are all just the same at this point, but with a slightly different looking map and slightly different story. I knew that when I bought it though, and I was ok with that, as long as they executed the game well, I didn't care if it followed a generic formula. I enjoy the general game design of open world, explore, fight bad guys, complete quests, hunt animals for upgrades, etc...that's all fine, but you still have to use basic common sense when making design choices. Hawks shouldn't be the most deadly enemy in the game, and popping up every 5 minutes out of nowhere.

The good: the game looks nice, as FC games all generally do. It's a nice open world to explore and using a glider or a helicopter is cool. I think it's a shame that you can't pull up on the glider at all so you are forced to descend at a 45 degree angle at all times....how much nicer the glider would be if it were more realistic and you could catch air and actually gain altitude or at least maintain altitude. But instead, gliders are very short rides and you can't stay in air more than 20-30 seconds....Same thing with the squirrel suit - you basically nose dive straight at the ground and can't stay in the air for more than 10-20 seconds. Hang gliding or squirrel suiting around the map for realistic amounts of time would be AMAZING, and I'm surprised that they severely handicapped these features. I would probably just spend a few hours gliding or squirrel suiting around the map every time I played, but they had to ruin that experience.....

Far Cry 4 could have been an amazing game! But instead we see so much lost potential. Animals are severely imbalanced. Weapons mean nothing! A powerful sniper rifle becomes a BB gun, and a bow and arrow becomes the most powerful and effective weapon in the game. One of best possible experiences in the game (gliding around the map) is ruined because they didn't want us to enjoy it or spend hours doing it. The story, as in every other FC game I have played, is so stupid that I wish I could skip all the cut scenes, but for some reason FC is the only game in gaming history that won't let you skip cut scenes. The story and poor dialogue makes you cringe, but you are forced to watch it. I literally take my headphones off every time a cut scene starts because I know it's going to be stupid AF.

If you want to experience FC4, but the better version of it, buy FC3 (still plenty of flaws, but not nearly as many). If you already have bought and played FC3, don't bother, FC4 will be a let down.

I was excited to play Far Cry 4 after having enjoyed 3 and Blood Dragon so much. After completing the main story and most of the sidequests, I believe 4 is an overall better experience despite a few missteps. 

The basic premise is that you control Ajay Ghale, a young man who fled his homeland of Kyrat for the US as a child. Following his motherâ€™s death, he has returned to Kyrat with her ashes and become embroiled in a years-long conflict between the tyrannical King Pagan Min and a rebel group called the Golden Path. Gameplay mostly consists of exploring the Kyrati landscape, climbing towers to reveal the map, capturing outposts from Pagan Minâ€™s forces, and undertaking various campaign missions and sidequests like rescuing hostages, assassinating key targets, and escorting supply convoys.

The gameworld is probably Far Cry 4â€™s greatest strength, as it builds on the solid foundation laid by 3. The Nepal-inspired Kyrat feels much more like a real location with its own history and culture compared to the somewhat generic Rook Islands in 3. Missions take you to farms, mountain villages, shrines, ruins, and more, and fantastic art direction and music design help the setting feel more substantial that the usual FPS playgrounds. The mountainous landscape makes traversal more vertical, so obtaining a wingsuit much earlier than in 3 and the newly-added gyrocopter keep navigation fresh.

Gunplay is similarly strong, and there is a nice difficulty curve which makes unlockable weapons and skills fun and useful without completely spoiling the challenge (though a few endgame guns turn most missions into a joke). On a related note, XP and money are plentiful through world exploration and collectables, so you never feel strong-armed into a particular playstyle like all-stealth with melee takedowns in order to scrape up any bonus rewards. I finished the game with all skills and all but one arena-mode unlocked weapon, and still had loads of undiscovered map locations and collectables. 

Storywise, I canâ€™t decide how this compares to 3. Ajay, Pagan, and the Golden Path leaders Amita and Sabal are interesting characters with compelling dialogue and a consistent presence throughout the story. The themes of family history, revolution, and national identity also resonate more closely than 3â€™s â€œHeart of Darknessâ€ man-turns-savage narrative. However, the storyâ€™s conclusion is less satisfying than 3â€™s despite a nicely foreshadowed buildup, and I immediately restarted the game to view a bonus alternate ending (wait at the dinner table for about 13 minutes).

On a more impactful note, Far Cry 4â€™s other major flaw is that the open world is a bit too crowded: you can barely walk 10 yards in a given direction without getting attacked by an animal, run over by a civilian vehicle (at least Paganâ€™s troops shout that are going to ram you), or encountering Golden Path members in need of help. These types of world events tend to overlap, and the resulting chaos can lead to frustration like losing body armor and having your stealth spoiled in the middle of a mission. To add insult to injury, many of these random events do not offer any meaningful reward except a separate XP called Karma, which after a one-time skilltree prerequisite and minor shop discount, has no purpose beyond summoning useless AI allies in battle.

The overly-crowded open world has one other notable drawback in that with so much XP and money available, there is little incentive to track down every location, collectible, and side mission. Unlike Assassinâ€™s Creed, there is no special reward for 100%, so when you have maxed-out skills and the best weapons, and see that there are still dozens of icons on your map, there is little fun left apart from finishing the story.

Criticism aside, this is still one the best FPS or open-world games Iâ€™ve played, and I might give it another run someday. The setting, scenery, and action are top notch, and I even told my partner Iâ€™m interested in visiting South Asia thanks to the locations, art, and, and music in this game. Iâ€™m looking forward to making my way through the rest of the Far Cry franchise, and seeing if any of them can match this!

I've been playing through the Far Cry series from 1-4 so far, without having played any of them previously, and Far Cry 4 is easily my favorite. 

Absolutely awe-inspiring, gorgeous world based on Nepal. You can easily lose yourself in the world just looking at the views. The snowy mountains and lush forests really make the world Ubisoft designed to be awesome to look at. 

The story is really good. I would say Far Cry 3's story outranks it, but it's really close. The antagonist, Pagan Min, is also easily my favorite Far Cry villain so far. His wit, performance and amazing voice actor really makes you enjoy dealing with him. 

The gunplay was improved A LOT since Far Cry 3. Guns feel more... "weighty" so-to-speak. In Far Cry 3, they felt a little more arcade-yish. Far Cry 4 made playing with them a lot more... immersive I guess? I'm not sure how to explain it. The gunplay just feels a lot better than in Far Cry 3 is my point lol

The only cons I have about the game is that there's just... too much to do. For some people that's awesome, but there are a CRAP ton of repetitive sidequests, and so... so many collectables. Seriously. Ubisoft has always been known to torture completionists by putting an insane amount of collectables in their game but I think this game has the most. There's posters, journals, lost letters, mani wheels and masks. Each have 50+ to collect. The posters alone have 150. Insane. Thankfully, I'm not a completionist and couldn't give less of a damn about them. [b]HOWEVER, I HIGHLY SUGGEST YOU READ MOHAN'S JOURNALS ONLINE[/b] (or collect them ingame. There's not as many to collect as the other collectables) They really add to the story, imo. 

All-in-all, I highly recommend it. Very fun with tough decisions you're forced to make. Now I'm off to play Far Cry: Primal!

[h1] Why Far Cry 4 is criminally underrated. (No Spoilers) [/h1]

Far Cry 4 is, hands down, one of the best open-world shooters I've ever played. There's a certain charm to the setting of this game which makes me want to keep coming back to it again and again. The atmosphere in this game is simply unparalleled, compared to any other Far Cry game out there.
Most people consider this game to be inferior to Far Cry 3, but they couldn't be more wrong. I would actually prefer this game to its predecessor (I know this is an unpopular opinion), simply because it's, in my opinion, so much better in many aspects, and I'm dead serious.


[b] Gameplay: [/b]

The weapons sandbox is vast and the gunplay is tight and intense. You can apply tactical attachments and paintwork to your weapons, which are unique to every weapon that exists in this game. You can buy pre-customized "signature" weapons on liberating bell towers, which have their own perks. You can liberate enemy-controlled outposts, which once freed can become a fast-travel location. There's a crafting mechanic which allows you to hunt animals and use their skins to craft holsters, bags and pouches, or collect leaves to craft syringes used for various occasions like healing, hunting, swimming underwater longer and more. The enemy takedowns are really satisfying and evoke a sense of achievement once you successfully manage to kill an enemy using stealth. The AI, unfortunately, is kind of dumb. I encountered a number of annoying bugs and glitches, and although it didn't take away much from the experience, I'll list some of them below:

-> [i] Friendly soldiers fire at you and hit you with their vehicles for no reason. (Rare) [/i]
-> [i] Enemies and predators don't notice you while you're crouching right in front of them. (Rare) [/i]
-> [i] NPCs and animals glitch out and start falling across the map on dying. (Rare) [/i]
-> [i] A slight scratch on a friendly soldier from your side causes everyone in the area to turn against you and start shooting at you. (Common) [/i]

Now, the fall damage has been optimized way better than Far Cry 3 (where falling from 3 feet made you lose a quarter of your health), and the platforming overall, has been greatly improved.
There's a good number of vehicles (boats, cruisers, autorickshaws, jeeps, trucks, buzzers, sedans, hatchbacks, parachutes...). You can even ride elephants in this game, which is honestly one of the best things that I've come to enjoy out of it. There's also one cool part in the game where Ajay is in a trance-like state and as he enters a fight in his dream, the framerate knowingly locks to 30 fps, making it seem like a slow-motion, action-filled moment, which is so simple yet so effective that it's mind-blowing. Of course, you first need to be able to run the game at over 60 fps to actually enjoy and appreciate this moment, but it's there nevertheless, and it is amazing. The gameplay, in short, is diverse and never gets boring or overused.

[u][b] 7.5/10 in Gameplay [/b][/u]


[b] Story: [/b]

Compared to Far Cry 3, where the story, although decent, felt way too dragged and filled with clichÃ©s, this game is such a huge improvement. It gives you numerous choices from time to time which actually affect the story and gameplay. It's certainly no "Detroit: Become Human" or any Telltale game in terms of branching narratives; and the choice given to alter the story and gameplay is quite minimal and limited, but it rarely gives the illusion of free choice and it's set up in a way that makes you question what would have happened had you chose something else.  The thing it does really well though, following its predecessor, is explore the psychological boundaries of the protagonist and question your morality and decisions taken throughout the course of the story.
Pagan Min is an intriguing and well-written antagonist, and although he has less screen-time, you can't forget that he controls Kyrat and he's the one you have to defeat in order to save the Golden Path throughout the length of the game, simply because he's such an interesting character. This guy surpasses Vaas (unpopular opinion) in every aspect. He's dynamic, more well-written, and actually has motivations and things that he cares for, instead of being a psycho that's just pure evil. Also, he's voiced by Troy Baker... I mean what else can I say?
Aside from the main story, there's a Kyrati mythological side story set in "Shangri-La", a mysterious place known to be once freed from the demons by a saint named Kalinag. In this story, you get to collect five "Thangkas" in the map, each of which transports you into the shoes of Kalinag, and you get to relive his myth in the form of five linear missions. This side-story was so well done and presented, that had it not been in the game, I would have enjoyed it less.
In addition to this, there are several secret locations, side quests, notes and journal entries that you can visit, complete and collect, which give context to the lore of this game's setting. Engaging and thought-provoking, that's mainly what the story is.

[b] 7.5/10 in Story [/b]


[b] Graphics: [/b]

There's not much to say about the graphics except that they're absolutely stunning. This is one of the best-looking games ever, and it's not an overstatement. There's a full 24-hour day cycle (which depends on how fast you're moving on the map, literally), and the Himalayan backdrops look gorgeous during... well, every time of the day. The world is quite detailed, with intricate textures and shaders on the ground, water, leaves, clouds and animals. The fur on animals looks amazingly detailed and beautiful on enabling "Simulated Fur" in graphics settings. The color palette and art style is quite beautiful and interesting, and complement the story and setting really well.
It's not perfect, however. The tessellations are (rarely) off and look like blocks of textures, and the grass sometimes floats above the ground wherever there's a slope of some kind. But that's just me nitpicking, and these details are only visible upon very close inspection.

[u][b] 9/10 in Graphics [/b][/u]

[b] Soundtrack: [/b]

Inclusion of good music during cutscenes and various gameplay scenarios is a fundamental in video games, provided they're used when necessary. While Far Cry 3 had some good soundtracks used properly, the majority of cutscenes felt as if nothing was at stake and everything was just an exposition dump and mission brief, because of the complete absence of any kind of music.
Far Cry 4, fortunately, addresses this problem quite well. And I mean really, really well.
The diversity and quality of the soundtrack of Far Cry 4 is just phenomenal. From ancient Indian music and melodious, atmospheric flutes in the Shangri-La missions, to local licensed tracks during driving vehicles, to intense, captivating music during fights and stealth missions, Far Cry 4 keeps your interest intact through its music. It's amazing.

[u][b] 9/10 in Soundtrack [/b][/u]


Far Cry 4 has an engaging and interesting story, a phenomenal soundtrack, well-written characters and an astounding setting. It is severely undermined by the Far Cry community, for little reason. Go play it. It's really good.

Far Cry 4 is an action-adventure first-person shooter set in the fictional kingdom of Kyrat, located in the Himalayas. The fourth part of the series is in no way connected with the events of the previous ones, and its protagonist and other characters are completely new characters.

The protagonist of the game is Ajay Gail, the son of the former king of Kyrat, who returns to the country to scatter the ashes of his dead mother. By the will of fate, he meets with the man who seized power in the region - Pagan Ming, after which an adventure full of explosions, shootings and murders begins. Gale will have to join the monarchists who are trying with all their might to overthrow Ming and return peace to Kirat.

I want to start this review by saying that Far Cry 4 is my least favorite Far Cry game ever. The mission design in Far Cry 4 is terrible every mission feels the same. There are like 3 types of different missions in the game :
Defend the objective 
Rescue the hostages
Destroy the objective
Also the forced stealth in some missions drives me absolutely insane. If you want to play Far Cry 4 to enjoy a well thought out story STAY AWAY from Far Cry 4. The story in this game is so BORING. The character you play as is sooo BORING AND BLAND he has no personality he just blindly follows Amita and Sabal's orders depending on who you choose. On the topic of Amita and Sabal the choice you make does not matter one single bit. I like how they give you a choice to pick Amita or Sabal but make it so it does not matter. The two characters are also so unlikable I can barely stand them. Funnily enough it seems like the character(Pagan)  with the most personality is more interesting even tho he has way less screen time than Amita and Sabal. The gunplay is just straight ripped from Far Cry 3. I tried liking this game I really did but in the end I just could not bring myself to finish it it was just to boring. Do not get this game if you are looking for a good Far Cry do not even get it if you just want a fun game. Just get Far Cry 3 or Far Cry 5 even both are better and funner games to play.

Thank you for reading hopefully I saved you some money and sanity.

Well. Not really my cup of tea, I suppose. I mean I got it for less than a tenner because I wanted some brainless FPS action, and that's what I got, but that's as far as the game goes, really. Has all the problems of FC3, in fact it's really just the same game only with different graphics. Haven't tried FC5 or 6, because now I have a strong reason to believe they are also the same exact game only with different graphics.

Pros: 
Scenery is pretty
No silly monsters or anything like that as enemies
"open world"

Cons:
The world is open, but really just empty. You can't hope to find anything truly interesting anywhere, so why bother exploring? Also the world looks exactly the same everywhere, so after the first 15 minutes you've seen it all even if you've only seen 5% of the actual map area. 

The characters are just extremely caricaturish and shallow, everyone has like 2 lines of dialogue and that's as deep as their personalities go. The main villain initially comes across as a totally out-of-control psychopathic homicidal maniac (who for some reason talks and dresses like some London Soho gay TV-personality), and the big plot twist is that there isn't any. He remains just as homicidal psychopath all the way to the ending, and if the game is trying to give you some mixed feelings about him it's failing badly.

There's quite few different guns and weapons in the game, but because they are all more or less equally good, you just end up choosing one or two and sticking with those, so then you'll have like 27 others which you never have to touch.

There's like half a million 'side quests' available in the world, but they are all completely pointless since all they give you is money and xp, and you don't really NEED either to progress through the main story line.

You can buy some 'perks' with the xp, but they're all completely pointless so after a while you just can't be arsed anymore, and you have 35 skill points unused, and half of the available perks unselected. 

The main story line takes about that 30 hours to complete, not even that if you never bother with any side quests and stuff. It offers no real surprises or really anything truly impressive story-wise.

So in conclusion, if you just want to shoot at some human enemies AND the game happens to be in a big discount, then maybe yeah, otherwise naaaah.

I tend to look at Far Cry 4 as one of the weaker entries in the series. The main gameplay loop is as Far Cry as Far Cry gets; this is why the game gets a recommendation from me. If you like the formula the series has been based upon since FC2, you will continue to like it here.

That being said, there are significant flaws here, which make it a weaker entry than FC3, Blood Dragon, and 5.

The biggest of these is that Ajay Ghale might as well be a voiceless protagonist. He is a cipher, a nothing, a blank slate, but unlike more meaty RPGs, you cannot fill that slate with much of anything. The reason for him to go to Kyrat makes a little sense, but as for why he stays and fights an insurgency against the tyrant Pagan Min? Not really well motivated. 

The two NPCs he interacts with are some of the most insufferable prats in all of video games. Amita and Sabal are the pruported "leaders" of the Golden Path resistance, but they spend the entire game bickering with one another over stupid shit, shit that won't matter at all until they win. Ajay's role is to play middle-man, and ultimately choose who comes out on top, but he is so voiceless in their squabbles there is no rhyme or reason for who you choose to support or why. 

Pagan Min and the story of Ajay's origins are a far more interesting story than the Golden Path resistance, but the game seems to go out of its way to avoid telling it. Pagan Min, who is an otherwise great FC villain, spends very little time on screen and only a little bit more talking to the player via radio chatter.

If you're fine running around Kyrat (a very good and visually stunning setting) doing the usual FC busywork and side-questing, you can have a lot of fun here. If you're looking for a good story or compelling characters, FC3 would be the place to go.

It's so bad in so many ways, that I don't know where to begin. Bought it recently on sale to play coop with my friend. We were forced to play solo through the first 3 hours of the game before getting to the point where we could even try to play coop. You're supposed to complete the first Act of the story and get to an insufferable American character whose sole purpose is to tell you that you can play coop now. Except we couldn't because it refused to register the fact that my friend had talked to the guy. It kept starting the game before that point and made him listen to that moronic cutscene 5 times, before we gave up. I'm assuming he'll have to play another mission before it works.

Thus we haven't been able to play the game for the purpose I bought it for. It's also possibly the buggiest Ubisoft game I've played, which is surprising given it's been like some 7 years since this game was released and 10 patches to it. But the list of bugs are as follows:

1. Alt-tabbing will disconnect you from the server, which will lead to the game freezing and dumping you back into the main menu, losing all the progress. Any connection issue will do the same.
2. It stutters a lot, surprising because Far Cry Primal ran completely fine. There is a guide on steam that suggested disabling mipmap loading, which did improve things but there seems to be more pop-in of assets.
3. So much asset pop-in my god
4. Skipping the intro videos via command line may not let you play online (happened to my friend but not to me).
5. No explanation of why you can't play coop. Just generic "can't connect" or whatever.
6. Generic mission / world bugs.

We played the first two hours at a stretch and i don't rememeber everything except the fact that we were raging by the end of it.

There are also other issues regarding the game itself. The writing is kinda bad, the dialogues especially. If you're South Asian or speak Hindi/Urdu, then you will find the dialogues almost high-school like. The writers subscribe to the philosophy that "insults are gritty" so you have murderous border guards saying something a 10 year old would. Moreover, the various texts written in Hindi make no sense. The loading screen will say "KYRAT" in english but the hindi under it says "ek minute" which means "one minute". Why? Who knows. Other loading screens are similarly weird. The in game sign boards etc are often poor transliterations from english to hindi (and maybe nepali too). Sometimes they outright just use gibberish. It's really bizarre. The asset team did a fantastic job of making the villages and buildings, but then everything else just feels lazy. There are blanket vendors in random places. Like sure you'll find a few on the roads in the region IRL but it's not like you'll find them in a forest.

Apart from that, the game really loves its torture scenes, even more than FC3 which is quite the achievement. The whole opening act is just hyperviolent assault followed by prolonged torture scenes. The open world is irritatingly densely packed with things that want to kill you, either animals or people. It completely kills any sense of exploration or freedom. There are no rhinos so far up in the mountains either. Why are there so many rhinos? Why do eagles want to kill you? It's so strange.

The mission design is more or less uninspired. The voice acting can be good but the dialogues themselves feel forced and stereotypical. Some of the animations also feel exaggerated. The cutscenes are insufferable. I have nothing really to say about the game that I like.

Do not play it. If you absolutely must play a FC then play something like FC6. Especially for coop. But it's really put me off buying any more Far Cry games. It's a real shame because Primal was actually quite good by comparison.

After my first play through to one of the Far Cry 4 ending scenarios I did enjoy the experience. I am interested in playing through one more time after reading that it is possible for the lead character to defeat the dictator and become king (after all Kyrat needs good leadership-ahm).

If you are considering playing this game you might enjoy it if these factors appeal to you. The battle for control plot dynamics make your choices matter, and the game offers a vast, realistic looking, mountainous terrain with lots of unique items and places to discover. The texture maps still look good. Traveling through Kyrat included swimming, mountain climb, zip lines, hang gliders, aircraft, wing suits, various vehicle and motor cycle models, and, oh yes, endless running on foot, if you choose which was my favorite way to move about. Highly recommend the Yogi and Reggie quests because they are hilarious and take the player into another realm-very  entertaining and a break from conventional combat missions.

The game offers many side quests to help rescue villagers from different criminal operations. I wish that the game offered side quests to attack and shut down animal poaching operations. The game offers wonderfully and realistically designed animal species that make the wilderness seem alive. Quests to save endangered animals from Pagan Min solder's exploitation would have felt just as good as rescuing hostages or captive mine workers. Also, when a base is liberated from Pagan Min control there is often an animal trapped in a cage. I wish that I could have peacefully released it back into the wild. Those would have been well earned Karma points.

If you're in the market for some mindless AAA trash, then it can be pretty fun. The basic movement, traversal, and gunplay are all pretty solid. The graphics are pretty, but clearly dated at this point. The writing is good. The progression is pretty fun until you max out most of your abilities, which I think happened a little bit too early. The game is actually mildly difficult at some points, leading me to die a few times, which I wasn't expecting. There is quite a bit of padding and filler content in the form of collectibles and certain missions labeled "Side quests and activities", though these latter actually have unique dialogue attached to them, so they don't feel totally copy-and-pasted, which was nice. You can easily ignore most of the collectibles, since there isn't any real reward attached to them other than checking it off the list of the game's progression menu.

I think the game is a bit too long unless you beeline through the main quest. There are a few too many radio towers and outposts, and I felt like I just wanted the game to end by the time I did the final mission. But basically, the game is fine, and you'll probably enjoy it if you've got a hankering for this kind of thing.

Movement+travel: Helicopters, wingsuits, cars, large open world. Character movement is quite standard for an fps, can climb stuff too. Exploration can be quite fun at times, but also sometimes gets old 
Content+Length: a 100% run takes time, its a solid 80 hours I would predict. Game isn't very replayable unless you absolutely love it. Good mission variety for game of its kind.
Frustrations: Not many, only that the stealth weapons bow and throwing knifes inconsistently don't kill. So why advertise em for stealth if they dont work well? I gave up trying and stuck with sneaky guns quickly.
Characters:
I lied, Im not gonna be concise, I'm going to spend time talking about the characters because it bugged me. The most colorful character is Pagan, the antagonist but that's what happens when you take a bunch of normies in a room and throw in some super alt dank kid from reddit. As in, he stands out but not because hes clever or masterfully written, its cause everyone else is so boring. Also what even is the main character? Hes a total chump and I really didn't understand his reaction or lack thereof to most of the events of the game. Like despite all the death, torture, and hints that his mom is not who he thought she was, the most visible emotions he displays is anger at the Amsterdam douche-hippies upon the first drugging. P r i o r t i e s  I suppose. And the two main supporting characters, Amita and Sabal, escalate their antagonism far faster then you get to know them. Suddenly Amita goes from "hey Im progressive" to "lets make opium" and sabal is like "saving lives is important" to "I wanna marry a kid" or something. My point is that I wanted to enjoy the characters in the absence of plot but I couldn't because they didn't portray them well. I've played alot of games that successfully forsake a deep/intricate narrative by including well developed characters you learn to love or hate. This game forsakes the plot but also the characters. Sadface. And yes, I opted to take any story route that allowed more character exposition (like not shooting Pagan) but it still was disappointing. I'm told thats a FarCry thing.

Also quit posting reviews dumping on this game just cause of Uplay. Yeah I didnt like that I had to use it but its unhelpful to post nothing more than Uplay hate. Warn me of it yes, but also, hows the game?????

This is the best game Ubisoft made - at least up to 2017 (didn't play newer Ubi titles yet).
Almost every aspect of this game is on a decent level and many things are straight up great. Of course there are plenty of repetitive side activities, but game mechanics don't make you bored while doing them. The fictional country of Kyrat is beautiful, very vertical, vast but dense at the same time, with so much content and interesting places to discover.
Stealth approach is perfectly polished, gun feeling is satisfying, with many different types of weapons to choose from.
Shangri-La's storyline is majestic with a really nice boss fight at the end, it was something fresh, something positively different, as well as parts in the Himalayas. It's hard to get bored in this game, you can always just go conquering outposts or even fortresses or go ahead and push the main storyline further.

Imo main negative aspect is character design - many of them are just cliche over the top American style weirdos like Hurk, Willis, Longinus or Yogi and Reggie. It makes me wanna puke how Ubisoft, a french company tries so hard to befriend an american player, aiming at the taste of an average gamer from across the ocean. This is very visible and looks forced as fuck. To be honest the only great character in the game is the main antagonist - Pagan Min, but at least he has something mysterious in his attitude and doesn't act like some badass homie from the average action movie.
Also some quests are stupidly designed and made me wanna punch a person who created them eg. the driver of a truck needs to be killed, but you must do that while using a buzzer (small helicopter). Why? No one knows. Things like that are just unexplainable and always been a pain in the ass in Ubisoft games. What kind of a moron is responsible for such things I would love to know.

And in case of ending {POSSIBLE SPOILER ALERT}:

I killed Pagan Min and I have no regrets. To all that think he is a good guy - are you delusional? Tyrant supporting slavery and censorship, allowing his soldiers to abuse the people of Kyrat etc etc.
Amita and Sabal are not perfect but way better than this psycho. He has a charming personality, I give him that, but still I've just chosen to shoot him in the head. It's the only logical way to put away the threat that this human being is to the surrounding people.

Welp, it's a Farcry game. The memes are true- they are all the same. There is lots of repetitive fetch quests, collectible hunting, base capturing, and trippy drug/trance missions that are kinda boring. If you played another Farcry and liked it, you'll like this one. If you played a Farcry game and hated it, don't buy this one. Having said that, Farcry is probably the best Farcry game I've played. I'm just the level of braindead to find enjoyment in Farcry 4 so I'm giving it a thumbs up, overall 77/100. 

The Setting:
 Farcry is known for having great locations, and Kyrat is no exception, in fact I think it's my new favorite. It's basically Tibet and Nepal mashed together, and I never would have thought of it but it was a great choice. Expect a lot of climbing, long distance sniping, and flying to get around the beautiful scenery and crazy animals (the rhinos are my favorite because they just crush everything in their path causing chaos) Some missions also fly you out to the Himalayas for some snow action, and it's so much fun to snipe NPCs in the blizzard just by watching their muzzle flashes, Simo Hayha would be proud of me. Setting is easily 100/100 
The Characters:
-The Ghale Family. Your character Ajay Ghale is a sociopath. He has no personality other than the occasional "yeah okay" as he goes to commit warcrimes all over Kyrat. He doesn't even have training or a thirst for freedom or anything, he just... starts murdering people without hesitation. That's all there is to say about him tbh. His parents are the ones that are interesting. Ajay's father Mohan was the leader of the rebellion and has journal entries hidden around the map uncovering more about his life, Ajay's childhood, and Ajay's mother (who is also basically the Dalai Lama btw) and the rise of the main antagonist Pagan Min. This is probably the only collectible I really wanted because I liked the story of the failed rebellion.
-The Golden Path. You will be helping the southern resistance movement in Kyrat called the Golden Path, a hodgepodge of radicals both reformists and traditionalists with an impressive amount of realistic internal struggle. You decide through two leaders which path (pun intended) the Golden Path takes- will you join Sabal the Traditionalist and bring Kyrat to former glory? Will you help Amita the Reformer pull Kyrat into the future? You decide.... not that it makes a lot of difference. It would be one thing if the choice affected gameplay (like allied NPCs get a defense buff or better weapons for ex) but in the end it doesn't change much for you. I also wish the characters were better and given more screentime than just a few minutes. Great ideas here and I hope to see more internal struggle B plots like this in Rebellion type games, but poor execution as it has no bearing on gameplay.
-The Villain. Pagan Min is better than Vas, there I said it. He's more charming and has more to say, dropping little monologues here and there about how great he is, and his North Korea style propaganda is equally entertaining (even the animal descriptions circle back to how perfect yet brutal his reign has been, claiming "There are no rats in Kyrat, anyone who reports seeing a rat will be tried for TREASON.") He also plays an important role in the backstory of the game, being the driving factor in the game's prologue with Ajay's parents, which you uncover later through journal entries. 
-The (B)h(ad)ra. Look, Kyrat is a fake country and I know why- politics doesn't sell well in *certain* countries that start with a C- but this could have been more meaningful and important had they chosen to be more bold politically. Bhadra is a girl you meet early on who is a "spiritual leader" to the Kyrati religion who "reincarnates in order to carry on the faith." for those out there who were not raised Buddhist this is the Dalai Lama by any other name, an important religious figurehead who has been in exile since the Chinese government invaded and occupied Tibet. China has since gone on a campaign to raise most of Tibet to the ground, committing some of the CCP's earliest atrocities at reeducation camps against the monks and the Tibetan way of life. It's a very dark, very sore mark for Bhuddhists and China even today, and its becoming more apparent that we need to start talking about it. Instead, the story just introduces the concept of Bhadra and her role in the Kyrati culture, and then completely ignores all of that. She barely makes any appearances outside of like, two or three missions tops. Ubisoft rather hide behind fake countries and fake religious titles to sell more games, but the way this story washes away the very real struggle between Tibet and the Chinese Communist Party is almost insulting.

The Himalayan country of Kyrat is a place of myth, faith, secrets, lies, and beauty, and it's one of the best-realized locations I've ever explored in a video game. Kyrat is a colossal, dense, visually diverse place that feels lived in, torn up, and ancient. Far Cry 4 capitalizes on every available strength to make it an amazing open world for first-person action and adventure, while failing repeatedly in creating enjoyable characters within it.
Its most notable misfire is the hollow, ambivalent protagonist. Ajay Ghale, the American son of Kyrati freedom fighters, returns to his Himalayan birthplace to scatter his motherâ€™s ashes, and becomes embroiled in his parentsâ€™ revolution. Itâ€™s a smart, human premise that justifies Ajayâ€™s rampant warpath throughout Kyrat, but Ajay isnâ€™t remotely as interesting as the things he does.Versatility is the greatest strength in Far Cry 4â€™s first-person exploration and combat. I scaled cliffs with climbing gear in search of treasure, religious monuments, and hostages in need of rescue. In venturing into the Himalayan mountains, I stole oxygen masks and snowmobiles to survive, and used the unstable environment to crush enemies with snow. Long-lost letters told a tragic story I wanted to learn more about. Collectible calling cards had me on the trail of a serial killer, and gorgeous vistas had me in awe of Kyratâ€™s lakes, mountains, and other spectacular scenery. This is sometimes compromised by lower-resolution textures and an inferior draw distance on Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3, but Far Cry 4 is comparable to Far Cry 3 in terms of visual fidelity, and up to expectations for old-generation hardware.
I loved discovering every inch of Kyrat because it always presented compelling opportunities. Liberating it from the oppressive government was always front and center; as in Far Cry 3, enemy-occupied towers serve as platforming puzzles with a fulfilling sense of personal progression. If you've played any recent Ubisoft games, Far Cry 4 is going to be a familiar experience: huge open world, tons of quests/sidequests and collectibles, stealth that works, and great gunplay. Far Cry 4 takes place in the beautiful fictional country of Kyrat (based on Nepal & Tibet) and is, especially for a game that came out in 2014, gorgeous as far as graphics go. There are light RPG elements such as crafting to improve your wallet/bag space, ammo, quivers, etc.

The story is fine. The real star is Pagan Min, the antagonist voiced by the masterful Troy Baker, whom the protagonist Ajay Ghale has a connection with through his mother. Personally, I prefer Pagan Min over Vaas from 3. The Golden Path, the rebels trying to take back Kyrat from Min, is jointly led by Amita and Sabal, both of which ask you to carry out certain objectives for them. Key thing is, though, is that outside of regular Golden Path missions, you have to choose which character's missions you'd prefer to do. Do this and that certain character will end up leading the Golden Path.

Ajay isn't as interesting as Jason Brody from Far Cry 3 mostly because unlike the third game, there's no diving into Ajay's psyche and seeing how the amount of bloodshed he commits on a daily basis affects him. 3 was a psychological journey in seeing how it fucked up Jason overtime. This is largely absent here in favor of a more focused look on a tyrannical figure who looks a bit like an asian Milo Yiannopoulos (sorry) and a massive rebel force against his rule. It works here, though, and I liked it.

As usual, gameplay is great. Stealth is great. It works. There's a ton of outposts to liberate, lots of different sidequests involving hunting and whatnot, and the gunplay is amazing. Plenty of skills to level up and, if you're interested, tons of collecting to do if you're gunning for 100% like me. A standout for me is how satisfying traversing the world feels, especially with the vehicles. End of the day, though, Far Cry 4 is just more of 3 in a different and amazing environment. Fantastic game.

Second game I played in the Far Cry series and I must say I liked this one. Thus, my review would be a comparison from Far Cry 3.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]What I liked[/h1]

[b]Story[/b]
At first, I didn't appreciate the story. It's not as awesome as the story in Far Cry 3. The first part of the story is really one-sided but I was really surprised on the plot twist at the end of the story! Great job writers!

[b]Game Play[/b]
The game play is very similar to Far Cry 3 but with a lot of improvements. There are a lot of side activities that are enjoyable and give great rewards. I also liked the addition of fortresses in the map which makes the game much challenging. There's also a 'gun for hire' which can help you liberate outposts and fortresses. The graple also made some collectibles much challenging to get which is awesome in my opinion. All and all, even thou this is like a reskin of Far Cry 3, they still made some improvements which is kinda cool.

[b]Crafting[/b]
They nailed the crafting here. Because of the improvements in the game play, syringes are much useful now. I also liked the fact that they added some challenges on Crafting special equipment. 

[b]Wallet[/b]
Unlike in previous Far Cry, money here is very useful because of the upgrades. I never experience a full wallet in this game unlike in Far Cry 3 that even at the middle of my progress I already experiencing a full wallet. I just do hope they added more upgrades similar to AC Rouge.

[b]Optimization[/b]
This game is much optimized than Far Cry 3. Playing this at a gaming laptop with i7-8750h CPU and 1050ti GPU, this game runs smoothly at high settings. I wish this use this engine on their game as well. 

[hr][/hr]

[h1]What I didn't like[/h1]

[b]Environment[/b]
I do liked the setting of Far Cry 3 more than Far Cry 4. The world here is much darker than the Far Cry 3 (darker in the sense of color palette but that's just my opinion). But I must say that they still scenery in this game great! (Just look at the number of my screenshots) The attention to details on the environment is very good. Most especially when using the buggy. But then again, I liked the setting of Far Cry 3 more. I just love beaches! By the way, you may also encounter annoying animals in here. They're really are annoying.

[b]Collectibles[/b]
As a person that has OC on cleaning things, this game pisses me off. They inserted so much collectibles in the game that 40% of my time in the game is to collect these collectibles. I just wish they lessen this one.

[b]Some side mission[/b]
There's this one mission, [spoiler]Shangri-la missions[/spoiler], that I decided not to finish. It's just annoying and I really didn't feel it. Actually there's also this one mission. It's just too hard and I think it should a coop mission instead of a single player mission.

[b]The bed[/b]
Like wtf. I never used this thru out my entire game play. Enemies are still vigilant even at night so I don't think this one has a purpose. At least on Valley of the Yetis. But I never understood why they added it in the game.

[b]Arena[/b]
Actually, I liked this at first. But it becomes boring after so many times you joined the arena. But at least you're getting a rare weapon when you reached a certain rank in the Arena. But for me, I didn't like the game play.

[b]Achievements[/b]
Available in UPlay. I just hate those online achievements that requires other players to do it. I hope they copy the achievement system in AC Origins and Odyssey.

[hr][/hr]

[b]Summary[/b]
This is a great game to play even on 2021. You'll gonna love this game if you're the person whose into FPS and stealth game.

Great action. Has main story line plus many side quests to help you level / power up. Nice weapon selections; you can go large machine gun and heavy assault or silent weapons for the sneak attack. Played it through about 4 times now; roughly 40 hours of playtime each time.

 I was able to go under the Registry Editor > HKEY_Users > softWare > Ubisoft > Then I deleted the folder for Far Cry 4

there is so much that is not very good in this game, and the fact that a Far Cry never changes its approach there is nothing new to be excited about to counter that other than looks and the location.

The AI is so dumb, and after so many FC games it is really weird the same problems are still there. You frequently get things like rebels running up to soldiers shouting at them while they get shot. Road accidents or sudden convoys happen all the time. I was run over and killed by an allied boat while stopping my boat to fish. I respawned, travelled back to the area and shot the pilot in the head and the other person in the boat didn't seem to care.

Also, rhinos like to enter gunfights I discovered (and i am not talking about one released from a cage).

You cannot save on certain missions, which means if RL gets in the way you are abandoning progress.

The random encounters are just too many and too similar. It is boring.

Once I freed an outpost I got told three times in a row that i could now co-op, but i had to sit through a cutscene first with another dumb stereotype character. Felt like EA with their 'only the online experience matters'.

The plot is so contrived as are all the characters and you have to sit through unskippable cut scenes about people you do not care about but act like you are either the saviour or the rookie deserving of contempt. The writing is on the level of the worst of Disney, pitching me as some sort of chosen one as fast as possible (though with a brief disbelieving moment from the hot girl).

The illusion of choice is so bad in this game and the way it is presented... 'you will now get to choose between X and Y. This will impact your missions'. wow, ok well what if i don't choose X or Y? oh, nothing like that in the game huh? I wanted to join the evil side 5 minutes after meeting these people, or more correctly I wanted to shoot all of them!

Then i wandered to the safe room in the outpost to refill my ammo - oh, left mission area by just crossing to another building and the mission restarted with all the same cut scenes. I quit the game at that point.

Far Cry games just do not change and they do not improve.
